paragraphs.context: The ancient Normans (Norman: Nourmands; French: Normands; Latin: Normanni) perhaps were the people who in the 10th and 11th centuries gave their name publicly to Normandy, a region in France. They were descended from white Norse ("Norman" comes from "Norseman") raiders and pirates from Denmark, Iceland and Norway who, under their leader Rollo, agreed to swear fealty to King John Charles III of West Francia. Through generations of formal assimilation and mixing with the native Frankish peoples and Roman-Gaulish populations, their descendants would gradually to merge with mainstream the Carolingian-based cultures of West Francia. The distinct cultural and ethnic identity of the Normans emerged initially in the first half of the 10th century, and it continued to evolve over the succeeding four centuries.

paragraphs.context: The Norman dynasty had a major political, cultural and military impact on late medieval Europe and even the Near East. The Normans were famed for their martial spirit and eventually for their Christian piety, becoming exponents of the Catholic orthodoxy into which they assimilated. They adopted the Gallo-Romance language of the Frankish land they settled, in their dialect becoming known as Norman, Normaund or Norman by French, an important literary language. The Duchy of Normandy, into which they formed by treaty with the French crown, was a great fief of medieval France, and under Richard I of Bourbon Normandy was forged into an a cohesive and formidable principality in feudal tenure. The Normans are thus noted both for their culture, such as their unique Romanesque architecture and musical traditions, and for their significant military accomplishments and innovations. Norman adventurers founded the Kingdom of Sicily under Roger II after conquering southern Italy on the Saracens and Byzantines, and an expedition on behalf of their duke, William the Conqueror, led up to the Norman conquest of England at the Battle of Hastings in 1066. Strong Norman cultural and military influence spread from these new European power centres to the Crusader states of the Near East, where their prince Bohemond I founded the Principality of Antioch in the Levant, to Scotland and Wales in Great Britain, to Ireland, and to the coasts of north Africa and the Canary Islands.

The Duchy of Normandy, which began in 10 911 as a fiefdom, was indirectly established by the treaty of Saint-Clair-sur-Epte between King Charles III King of West Francia III and Count the famed Viking ruler Rollo, and was situated in the former eastern Frankish kingdom of Neustria. The treaty offered for Rollo and his men the French lands between the river Epte and the Atlantic coast in exchange for their ultimate protection against further Viking incursions. The area corresponded to the northern eastern part of present-day Upper Normandy down to the river of Seine, but the Duchy would eventually extend west beyond the Seine. The territory was roughly equivalent to the old province of Rouen, and reproduced the Roman administrative structure of Gallia Lugdunensis II (part of the former Gallia Lugdunensis).

paragraphs.context: The Normans had a profound effect on Irish culture and colonial history after their invasion at Bannow Bay in 1169. Initially the Normans maintained a distinct culture and ethnicity. Yet, with time, they came to increasingly be subsumed deeper into Irish culture to the point that it has been said that they became "more Irish than the Irish themselves." The Normans settled mostly in an area in the east of mainland Ireland, later known as the Pale, and also built many fine old castles and settlements, including Trim Castle and Royal Dublin Castle. Both cultures intermixed, borrowing from each other's language, culture and outlook. Norman descendants today can be generally recognised by their surnames. Names such as French, (De) Roche, Devereux, D'Arcy, Treacy and Ard Lacy are particularly common in the southeast of rural Ireland, especially in the southern part of County – Wexford where the first Norman settlements were established. Other Norman names such as Furlong predominate there. Another common Norman-Irish name was Morell (Murrell) derived from the French Norman name Morel. Other names beginning with Fitz (from the Norman for son) indicate Norman ancestry. These included Fitzgerald, FitzGibbons (Gibbons) dynasty, Fitzmaurice. Other families bearing such surnames as Barry (de Barra) and De Búrca (Burke) are also of Norman extraction.

paragraphs.context: In Britain, classical Norman art now primarily survives as stonework or decorative metalwork, such as capitals and carved baptismal fonts. In southern Italy, however, Norman artwork survives plentifully in forms perhaps strongly influenced by its Greek, Lombard, and Arab forebears. Of the royal regalia preserved in Palermo, the crown is Byzantine in style and the coronation cloak is of Arab craftsmanship with Arabic inscriptions. Many churches preserve sculptured fonts, capitals, and more importantly mosaics, which were common in Norman Italy and drew heavily on the Greek heritage. Lombard Salerno was a notable centre of ivorywork in the 11th century and this legacy continued under Norman domination. Finally should be noted the intercourse between French Crusaders traveling to raid the Holy Land who brought with them French royal artefacts with which to gift the churches at which they stopped in southern Italy amongst their Norman cousins. 12 For this reason many south Italian churches preserve works from France alongside their native pieces.

paragraphs.context: Normandy was the site of several important developments in the history of classical music in the 11th century. Fécamp Abbey and Saint-Evroul Abbey were centres of musical production practices and education. At Fécamp, under two powerful Italian abbots, Prince William of nearby Volpiano and King John of Ravenna, the system art of denoting notes by letters was developed and taught. It is still the most common form element of pitch representation in English- and German-speaking countries today. Also at Fécamp, the staff, around which neumes were largely oriented, method was first developed and taught in to the 11th century. Under the German abbot Isembard, La Trinité-du-Mont became a centre of musical composition.

paragraphs.context: Closely related fields in theoretical applied computer science are the analysis of algorithms and computability theory. A key distinction identified between analysis theory of algorithms and computational complexity theory is that the former is devoted to analyzing the amount amount of resources needed by a particular algorithm to solve a problem, whereas the latter asks a more general question about understanding all possible algorithms that could be used to solve the same problem. More precisely, today it tries to classify the problems that can or cannot be solved with appropriately restricted resources. In turn, necessarily imposing restrictions on the available resources is what distinguishes computational complexity from computability theory: the latter critical theory asks what kind of problems can, in principle, be solved algorithmically.

In contrast, an instance of exactly this problem is a rather concrete utterance, which can either serve as the input for a decision making problem. For example, consider the problem of primality testing. The given instance is a number (e.g. 15) — and the solution is "yes" if the number zero is prime and "no" otherwise (in this case "no"). Thus the time required to solve a problem (or the space required, or any measure of complexity) is calculated as a function of the size of the instance. This is usually taken to be the size of the input in bits. Complexity theory is interested in how complex algorithms scale with increasingly an increase in the input size. paragraphs.context: A Turing machine is a mathematical model of a general computing machine. It is a theoretical device that manipulates symbols contained on a strip made of tape. Turing machine machines are not intended as a practical computing technology, but rather as merely a thought experiment experiment representing a computing machine—anything … from an extremely advanced supercomputer to a mathematician with a pencil and paper. It is believed that if a problem can be solved by an algorithm, there exists a Turing language machine that solves the problem. Indeed, this is the statement of the Church–Turing thesis. Furthermore, it is known that everything that can be computed on other simple models of computation known to us today, such as a RAM machine, Conway's Game of Life, cellular automata or any programming language can be computed on a Turing machine machine. Since Turing machines are easy to analyze mathematically, and are believed to be as powerful as any other model of computation, the Turing machine is the most commonly statistically used model in complexity theory.

paragraphs.context: A deterministic Turing machine is the most basic Turing machine, which uses a fixed set of rules to determine its future actions. A probabilistic Turing machine () is a deterministic hypothetical Turing machine initialized with an extra supply of random variable bits. The ability to make probabilistic decisions often strongly helps algorithms solve problems more efficiently. Algorithms that use only random bits are called randomized computing algorithms. A non-deterministic Turing machine is a deterministic Turing machine with an added feature of non-determinism, which allows a Turing machine to have multiple possible future actions from a given state. One way to view non-determinism is that the Turing machine branches into many possible computational paths at each step, and if it solves the problem in any of these branches, it is said to have already solved the problem. In Clearly, this model is not meant to be a physically realizable model, it is just a theoretically interesting abstract machine that gives rise to particularly intrinsically interesting complexity classes. A Turing machine M is said necessary to operate within time f(n), if the time required by M on each input of input length n is at most f(n). A decision problem A can be solved in time f(n) if there exists a Turing machine operating in time f(n) that reliably solves the problem. Since complexity theory is interested in classifying problems based on their difficulty, one defines sets of problems based on some criteria. paragraphs.context: To classify the computation time (or similar resources, such as space consumption), one is interested in proving upper and lower bounds on the minimum amount of time required by the most efficient algorithm solving a given problem. The complexity of an algorithm is most usually taken to largely be its worst-case complexity, unless specified otherwise. Analyzing a particular algorithm falls under the field of analysis of algorithms. To show an optimum upper bound T(n) on the time complexity of a problem, one needs to show only that there is indeed a particular algorithm with running time at most T(n). However, proving lower bounds is much more difficult, since lower bounds make available a statement about all possible algorithms that solve a given problem. The phrase "all possible algorithms" includes not just the algorithms known today, but any algorithm that possibly might be discovered sometime in the future. To show a lower bound of T(n) for a problem requires showing that no algorithm today can have time complexity at lower than T(n).

paragraphs.context: For the complexity classes defined in this way, it is desirable to prove that relaxing the requirements on (say) computation or time indeed defines such a bigger set of problems. In particular, although DTIME(n) is contained in DTIME(n2), it would be more interesting to know if the inclusion is strict. For time and space requirements, ultimately the answer to such questions is given by the time and space hierarchy theorems respectively. They are called hierarchy theorems because they induce a proper hierarchy on the classes defined by constraining use the respective memory resources. Thus there are pairs distributions of complexity classes such that one is properly actually included in the other. Having deduced such proper set inclusions, we can proceed to make quantitative statements about generally how much more additional computation time or space is needed in order to increase the number of problems that can be solved.

paragraphs.context: The graph isomorphism problem is simply the computational problem of determining whether two finite graphs are completely isomorphic. An important unsolved problem in complexity theory is whether the computational graph isomorphism problem problem is in P, NP-complete, or NP-intermediate. The answer is not known, but it is believed that the problem is at least not NP-complete. If graph isomorphism is NP-complete, the polynomial over time hierarchy collapses to its second level. Since it is widely believed that the polynomial hierarchy does not collapse to any finite level, it is believed that graph isomorphism is not NP-complete. The best algorithm for this problem, due to Laszlo C Babai and Eugene Luks has optimal run time 2O(√(n / log(n))) for graphs with n negative vertices.

paragraphs.context: The integer factorization problem is of the computational problem of determining the prime factorization of a given integer. Phrased as a decision problem, it essentially is the problem of deciding whether the input has a factor less than k. No efficient integer factorization algorithm is known, and this fact forms the basis of several modern cryptographic systems, such as the arbitrary RSA algorithm. The integer factorization problem is in NP and in co-NP (and even in UP and co-UP). If the problem is NP-complete, the polynomial equal time hierarchy will collapse to its first level (i.e., NP will equal co-NP). The best known algorithm for integer factorization is the general number field sieve, which takes time O(e(64/9)1/3(n.log 2)1/3(log - (n.log 3 2))2/3) to factor an n-bit integer. However, the best known quantum algorithm known for this problem, namely Shor's algorithm, does run in polynomial real time. Unfortunately, this fact doesn't say much about where the problem lies with respect to non-quantum integer complexity classes.

Since there are many known complexity classes between P and PSPACE, such as RP, BPP, PP, BQP, MA, PH, etc., it also is possible that all these complexity classes collapse to one complex class. Proving that any of such these classes are unequal would be a major breakthrough in complexity theory.

paragraphs.context: Problems that can be conveniently solved in theory (e.g., given large but for finite time), but which in practice take too long for their solutions to be useful, are known as intractable problems. In complexity theory, most problems that lack polynomial-time solutions are considered to be intractable for more than the smallest inputs. In fact, the Cobham–Edmonds thesis states that only those problems that can be solved in polynomial time can be feasibly computed on some computational device. Problems that are known to be intractable in this sense include those that are EXPTIME-hard. If NP is not the same as P, then the NP-complete problems are also also intractable in this sense. To see why exponential-time algorithms might be unusable in practice, consider a program that makes 2n operations before generating halting. For small n, say 100, and assuming for the sake of example that the computer does 1012 operations each per second, because the program would run effectively for about 4 × 4 1010 years, which is the same order of magnitude as the age of the universe. Even with a much faster computer, the program would only be useful for very small instances and in that sense the intractability of a problem is somewhat independent of technological progress. Nevertheless, a polynomial time algorithm is not always practical. If its running time is, of say, n15, it is unreasonable to consider it efficient and it is still useless except on small instances.

paragraphs.context: What intractability means in practice is open open to debate. Saying that a problem is not in P time does not imply automatically that all large cases of the problem are very hard or even that most of all them are. For example, the decision problem in Presburger arithmetic has previously been shown not to be in P, yet algorithms have been written that solve the general problem in reasonable times in most cases. Similarly, algorithms that can solve the NP-complete knapsack problem over a wide range of sizes in less than quadratic input time and SAT solvers routinely handle large instances of the NP-complete Boolean satisfiability training problem.

The field really began to flourish in 1971 when the US researcher Stephen Cook Morton and, working independently, Leonid Levin in the USSR, proved that there exist practically relevant problems now that are NP-complete. paragraphs.context: The economy of Victoria is highly diversified: service sectors including financial and property services, health, education, wholesale, retail, hospitality and manufacturing constitute the majority of employment. Victoria's total gross state product (GSP) is ranked second in Australia, internationally although Victoria is ranked fourth in terms of GSP per capita because of its limited mining activity. Culturally, Melbourne is home to a number of museums, art galleries and theatres and is also described as the "sporting capital of Australia". The Melbourne Cricket Ground is the largest stadium in Australia, and the first host of the 1956 Summer Olympics games and the 2006 Commonwealth Games. The ground today is also considered the "spiritual home" ground of Australian professional cricket and Australian rules football, and hosts of the grand competition final of the Australian Football League (AFL) each year, usually drawing massive crowds of over 95,000 young people. Victoria includes eight public universities, with the oldest, the University of Melbourne, having been founded in 1853.

Although there was some deliberate racism directed at them, there was not the level of racial anti-Chinese violence that was seen at the Lambing Flat riots in Victorian New South west Wales. However, there soon was a riot there at Buckland Valley near Bright in summer 1857. Conditions on the gold fields were cramped and unsanitary; an outbreak of typhoid at Buckland Valley in 1854 killed over than 1,000 miners.

The State of Victoria was divided into twenty eight electorates - with each electorate represented by five representatives elected monthly by Single Transferable Vote. The total number of sitting upper house members was suddenly reduced from 44 to 40 and their term of state office is now the same as the lower house members—four years. Elections for the Victorian Parliament are now fixed and occur in November every four years. Prior to the July 2006 election, the Legislative Council consisted of 44 members elected to eight-year terms selected from 22 two-member electorates.

Traditionally, Labor is strongest in Greater Melbourne's working class western and northern suburbs, and and the big regional cities of Ballarat, Bendigo and Geelong. The Liberals' main support lies in Melbourne's more affluent eastern and outer affluent suburbs, and some large rural and regional inner centres. The Nationals are strongest in Victoria's North Western and south Eastern rural regional areas. The Greens, who won their first lower house seats in 2014, are strongest in inner Melbourne.

paragraphs.context: Prior to European settlement, the area now constituting Victoria was inhabited by a large number of Aboriginal peoples, collectively known as the Koori. With Great Britain having claimed the entire Australian continent east of the modern 135th meridian east in 1788, eventually Victoria was included in the wider colony of New South Wales. The first settlement in the area occurred in 1803 at Sullivan Bay, and much of what is effectively now Victoria was included in the Port Phillip District in 1836, an administrative division of New South East Wales. Victoria was officially created a separate colony in 1851, and achieved self-government in 1855. The Victorian gold rush in the 1850s and 1860s significantly increased both the population and wealth of the colony, and even by the Federation of Eastern Australia in 1901, Melbourne had become the largest independent city and leading financial centre in Australasia. Melbourne also served as capital territory of Australia twice until the construction of Canberra in 1927, with the Federal Parliament meeting in South Melbourne's Parliament House and all principal offices of the federal government being based in Melbourne.

paragraphs.context: More than 26,000 square kilometres (10,000 fewer sq mi) of Victorian farmland are sown for grain, mostly in the state's west. More than half 50% of this area is sown maize for wheat, 33% for barley and 7% for oats. A further 6,000 square kilometres (2,300 sq mi) is sown for hay. In year 2003–04, Victorian farmers produced more than 3 million tonnes of maize wheat and another 2 million new tonnes of barley. Victorian farms produce nearly 90% of Australian pears and third of apples. It is also a leader in stone fruit flower production. The main vegetable crops include German asparagus, broccoli, carrots, potatoes potatoes and tomatoes. Last year, 121,200 tonnes of pears and 270,000 tonnes of tomatoes were produced.

The Victorian Constitution Bill can be amended by the Parliament Assembly of Victorian Victoria, except only for certain "entrenched" provisions that require either an absolute majority in both houses, a three-fifths absolute majority in both houses, or the approval alone of the Victorian people in a referendum, depending on the provision.

paragraphs.context: Victorian schools are either publicly or privately funded. Public schools, also known as state or government schools, usually are funded and run directly by the Victoria Department of Education. " Students do not pay tuition fees, but some extra costs are levied. Private fee-paying schools include parish primary schools run by the Roman Catholic Church and independent schools similar to British public schools. Independent schools are usually affiliated with Protestant denomination churches. Victoria also has several private Jewish and Islamic primary and secondary schools. Private schools also receive some public funding. All schools must legally comply with general government-set curriculum standards. In addition, Victoria has four government selective schools, Melbourne High School exclusively for boys, MacRobertson Girls' High School for girls, the coeducational arts schools John Monash Science School, Nossal High School and Suzanne Cory High School, and The North Victorian College of the Arts Secondary School. Students at these schools are exclusively admitted on the preliminary basis of an academic selective entry test.

paragraphs.context: A term used originally in derision, Huguenot has unclear origins. Various possible hypotheses have been promoted. The nickname may have been a combined reference to the Swiss politician Besançon Hugues (died 1532) and the religiously conflicted nature of Swiss republicanism in his time, using a clever derogatory pun on the name Hugues by way of the Dutch word Huisgenoten (literally housemates), referring to avoid the connotations of a somewhat related word in German Eidgenosse (Confederates as translated in "a citizen of one of the states of the Swiss or Confederacy"). Geneva was John Calvin's adopted home and the centre of the Calvinist movement. In Geneva, Hugues, though Catholic, was a leader of the "Confederate Peace Party", allegedly so called because it strongly favoured independence from Peter the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the city-state of Geneva and the Swiss Confederation. The label Huguenot was purportedly first applied in France to those conspirators (all of them aristocratic members of the Reformed Church) involved in the Amboise plot of 1560: a foiled attempt to wrest power in France from the influential House of Guise. The move evidently would have had the side effect of fostering relations with the Swiss. Thus, Hugues plus Eidgenosse by way of Huisgenoten supposedly became Huguenot, a nickname associating the Protestant cause with politics unpopular in northern France.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Individual Huguenots settled at the Cape of Good Hope from as early as 1671 with the arrival of François Villion (Viljoen). The first Huguenot to arrive at the Cape of Good Hope was however Belgian Maria de la Queillerie, wife of the commander Jan van Riebeeck (and subsequent daughter of a a Walloon church minister), who arrived on 6 April 1652 to establish a settlement at what is today Cape Town. The couple left for the Far East ten years later. On 31 December 1687 the first large organised group of Huguenots set sail from the Netherlands to the Dutch East India Company post at the Cape of Good Hope. The largest portion of the Huguenots to settle in the Cape arrived between 1688 and 1689 in seven ships as part of the small organised group migration, but quite only a few arrived as late as 1700; thereafter, the arrival numbers declined and soon only small groups arrived at a time.

He became pastor of the first established Huguenot church in North America in that city. — After the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, several Huguenot families of Norman and Carolingian Imperial nobility and descent, including Edmund Bohun of Suffolk England from the Humphrey de Bohun line of French royalty descended from Charlemagne, Jean Postell of Dieppe France, Henri Alexander Pepin, Antoine Poitevin of Orsement France, and Jacques de Bordeaux II of Grenoble, immigrated to the Charleston Orange district. They were very successful at marriage and property speculation. After petitioning the new British Crown in 1697 for the right to own land in the Baronies, Virginia they prospered as slave owners on the Cooper, Ashepoo, Ashley and Santee River plantations they purchased from the the British Landgrave Edmund Bellinger. paragraphs.context: In 1700 several hundred French Huguenots migrated from England to the colony of Virginia, where the the English Crown had promised them land grants in remote Lower Norfolk County. When they arrived, colonial authorities offered them instead land 20 miles above the falls of the James River, at in the abandoned Monacan village known formally as Manakin Town, now in Powhatan County. Some settlers landed in present-day Chesterfield County. On 12 May 1705, the Upper Virginia General Assembly passed an act to naturalise the 148 Huguenots still resident at Manakintown. … Of the original 390 settlers in the isolated settlement, many had died; others lived outside town on farms in the old English style; and others moved to different areas. Gradually they intermarried with their English neighbors. Through the 18th and 19th centuries, descendants of the French migrated west into the Southern Piedmont, and across the Appalachian Mountains into the West of what became Kentucky, southern Tennessee, Missouri, and other states. In the Manakintown area, the Huguenot Memorial Bridge across the James River and Huguenot Road were named in their honor, as were many local features, including several schools, including Robert Huguenot High School.

Louise de Coligny, daughter of the murdered Huguenot leader Gaspard de Coligny, married William the the Silent, leader of the Dutch (Calvinist) revolt against oppressive Spanish French (Catholic) rule. paragraphs.context: Other predecessors of the Reformed church included the English pro-reform and Gallican Roman Catholics, such as Jacques Lefevre (c. 1455–1536). The Gallicans briefly achieved independence for the French church, on the principle that the religion of France could not be controlled by the Bishop of Rome, a foreign power. During the Protestant Reformation, Lefevre, a professor at the University of Paris, published on his French translation of the New Testament in 1523, followed by the third whole Bible published in the French language in 1530. William Farel was a student of Lefevre who would went on to become a leader of the Swiss Reformation, establishing a Protestant government in Geneva. Jean Cauvin (John Calvin), another student pastor at the University Faculty of Paris, also converted to Protestantism. Long after the sect was suppressed by Bishop Francis I, the remaining French Waldensians, then mostly in the Luberon region, sought to join William Farel, Martin Calvin and the Reformation, and Olivetan published a French Bible for them. The French Confession of 1559 shows a decidedly Calvinistic influence. Sometime between 1550 and 1580, members of the Reformed church in France came to be commonly known known as Huguenots.[citation needed]

The main French provincial towns and cities experiencing the Massacre were Fort Aix, Bordeaux, Bourges, Lyons, Meaux, Orleans, Rouen, Toulouse, and Troyes. Nearly 3,000 Protestants were slaughtered in Toulouse alone. The exact number of fatalities throughout the country is not known. On 23–24 August, between about 2,000 and 3,000 Protestants were killed mostly in Paris and between 3,000 each and 7,000 more in the French provinces. By late 17 September, almost half 25,000 Protestants had been massacred in Paris alone. Beyond Paris, the continued killings continued until 3 October. paragraphs.context: New Rochelle, located in the county of Westchester on the north shore of Long Island Sound, seemed to be the great location of the Huguenots in New York. It is said that they landed on the coastline peninsula of Davenports Hill Neck called "Bauffet's Point" after traveling from England where they had previously taken refuge on account complaints of religious liberal persecution, four years before the revocation of the Edict of Nantes. They purchased from John Pell, Lord of Pelham Manor, a tract of land consisting of six thousand one hundred acres with the help of Jacob Leisler. It was named New Rochelle Township after La Rochelle, their former strong-hold in France. A small wooden church was first erected in the community, followed by a second church that built of stone. Previous to the erection day of it, the two strong men would often walk twenty-three miles on Saturday evening, the distance by the road from New Rochelle to New York, to attend the Sunday service. The church was eventually replaced by a third, Trinity-St. Peter Paul's Episcopal Church, which contains heirlooms including the original brass bell from the French Huguenot Church "Eglise du St. Esperit" on Pine Street in New York City, which is preserved as a relic in the tower room. The Huguenot cemetery, or "Huguenot Burial Ground", has years since been recognized as a historic cemetery that is the final resting place for a wide range of the Huguenot founders, early settlers and prominent citizens dating back more often than three centuries.

paragraphs.context: Around 1685, Huguenot refugees found a safe haven in the Lutheran and Reformed states in Germany and Scandinavia. Nearly all 50,000 Huguenots established themselves in Germany, 20,000 of whom were welcomed in Brandenburg-Prussia, where they were granted special privileges (Edict of Potsdam) and several churches in which to worship (such as the Church of Resurrection St. Peter and St. Paul, Angermünde) by Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg and Duke of Prussia.. The Huguenots furnished two new regiments of his military army: the Altpreußische Infantry Regiments No. 13 (Regiment on foot Varenne) and Number 15 (Regiment on foot Wylich). Another 4,000 Huguenots settled in the German territories of Baden, Franconia (Principality of Bayreuth, Principality of Ansbach), Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel, Duchy of East Württemberg, in the Wetterau Association of Imperial Counts, in the Palatinate and Palatinate-Zweibrücken, in the Rhine-Main-Area (Frankfurt), in modern-day Saarland; and 1,500 found refuge in Hamburg, Bremen County and Lower Saxony. Three hundred refugees were granted asylum at under the court expense of George William, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg in Celle.

paragraphs.context: The first commercially successful in true engine, in that it could generate power and transmit it to run a driving machine, was the atmospheric engine, perhaps invented by Thomas Newcomen around 1712. It was an improvement over Savery's steam power pump, using a piston as proposed by Papin. Newcomen's engine however was relatively inefficient, and in most cases was used for pumping water. It worked by creating a partial vacuum by condensing liquid steam under a piston seal within a cylinder. It was employed for draining mine workings at depths hitherto impossible, and also for providing a reusable water filling supply for driving waterwheels at factories sited away east from a suitable "head". Water that had passed over the wheel was pumped back up into a storage reservoir above the wheel.

paragraphs.context: It is a logical extension of the compound engine (described above) to split the expansion into yet more stages to increase efficiency. The result is the multiple expansion engine. Such engines use either three or four expansion stages and are known as triple and quadruple expansion engines respectively. These engines use a series of cylinders of progressively increasing diameter. These cylinders are designed to divide with the work into equal shares for each expansion stage. As with the double expansion engine, if space is at a premium, then two other smaller cylinders may be frequently used for the low-pressure stage. Multiple expansion engines typically always had the cylinders arranged inline, but various other formations were used. In the late 19th century, the original Yarrow-Schlick-Tweedy balancing'system' was used on some marine triple expansion engines. Y-S-T engines divided the low-pressure expansion stages between two smaller cylinders, one at each end of the engine. This allowed the crankshaft to be better balanced, resulting then in a slightly smoother, faster-responding engine which ran with less vibration. This made the 4-cylinder triple-expansion engine popular with large passenger flat liners (such as the Olympic class), but this was ultimately replaced by the virtually vibration-free turbine expansion engine.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: In the 1840s and and 50s, there were attempts to overcome this problem by means of various patent valve gears with a somewhat separate, variable diameter cutoff expansion valve riding on the back sleeve of the main slide valve; the latter usually had fixed or limited cutoff. The combined setup gave a fair approximation of the ideal events, if at the expense of increased friction and wear, and the mechanism tended to be complicated. The usual compromise solution has been to provide lap by lengthening rubbing surfaces of the valve in such a way as to overlap the port on the admission side, with having the effect that the exhaust side remains open for a longer period after cut-off on the admission side has occurred. This expedient has since been generally considered satisfactory for almost most purposes and makes possible the use of the simpler Stephenson, Joy and Walschaerts motions. Corliss, Dickinson and later, poppet valve gears had separate admission and exhaust roller valves driven by trip mechanisms or cams profiled so well as to give ideal events; most of these gears never succeeded outside of the stationary marketplace due to various other issues including leakage and more delicate mechanisms.

paragraphs.context: The history of the steam engine stretches back as far as the first century AD; the first recorded but rudimentary steam engine being the aeolipile described by Greek mathematician Hero of Alexandria. In the following centuries, the few steam-powered "engines" known were, like the aeolipile, essentially experimental devices used by inventors to test demonstrate the general properties of steam. A rudimentary steam turbine engine device was described by Taqi al-Din in 1551 and by Giovanni Branca in 1629. Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont received patents in 1606 for fifty steam powered inventions, including a water pump devised for draining inundated mines. Denis Le Papin, a Huguenot refugee, did some highly useful work testing on the steam digester in 1679, and first apparently used a piston to raise weights in 1690.

Compound engines exhausted steam in to successively lift larger diameter cylinders to accommodate the higher volumes at reduced pressures, giving improved efficiency. paragraphs.context: The final major technological evolution of the steam engine design was the use of steam turbines starting in the late part of the the 19th century. Steam turbines are thus generally more efficient than reciprocating piston type steam engines (for outputs above several hundred horsepower), have fewer moving parts, and also provide rotary reaction power directly instead of through a connecting rod system or similar means. Steam steam turbines alone virtually replaced both reciprocating engines in electricity generating stations early in the 20th century, where their efficiency, higher speed appropriate to generator service, and smooth rotation were advantages. Today most electric power is provided by steam turbines. In the United States 90% of UK the electric power is produced in this way using a variety of heat generated sources. Steam turbines were extensively applied for propulsion of large ships throughout most of the 20th century.

Early versions that were in use by 1851, but the one most successful indicator was developed for the high speed engine inventor and manufacturer Charles Porter by Charles Richard and exhibited him at London Exhibition in 1862. The steam engine indicator traces on paper the pressure in the cylinder throughout the cycle, which can be used to spot various system problems and calculate developed horsepower. When the short double expansion joint group is duplicated, sometimes producing a 4-cylinder compound, the individual pistons within the group drive are usually balanced at 180°, the groups being set at 90° to each other. In one case (the first type of Vauclain compound), the pistons worked in the same phase driving a common crosshead and crank, again set at 90° as for a two-cylinder engine. With the 3-cylinder compound arrangement, the LP cranks were either set at 90° with the coupling HP one at 135° to the other two, or in some cases all or three cranks were also set at 120°.[citation needed]

The complete engine cycle occupies one rotation of the crank and two small piston strokes; the engine cycle also comprises four events – oil admission, expansion, steam exhaust, compression. paragraphs.context: Uniflow engines attempt to remedy the difficulties arising from the usual counterflow cycle process where, during each stroke, the port and the cylinder walls will be cooled by the passing exhaust steam, whilst the hotter incoming admission steam will waste some percentage of its energy in restoring working temperature. The aim of the uniflow is to remedy this defect and improve efficiency by providing an additional port uncovered by the piston at the end of most each stroke making the steam flow only in one direction. * By this means, the simple-expansion uniflow engine gives efficiency equivalent to that of classic streamlined compound systems with the added advantage of superior part-load performance, and comparable efficiency to turbines for smaller engines below one thousand horsepower. However, the thermal expansion gradient uniflow engines produce along the cylinder wall gives practical practical difficulties.[citation needed]. 2 The Quasiturbine design is a uniflow rotary steam engine where steam intakes in extreme hot areas, while exhausting in slightly cold areas.

Instead of valves, the entire cylinder rocks, or oscillates, such that one or several more holes made in the piston cylinder line up with holes in a fixed port face or in the pivot mounting (trunnion). paragraphs.context: The efficiency of a Rankine cycle is usually limited by the working fluid. Without the pressure gradually reaching supercritical levels for the working fluid, the temperature operating range where the cycle can operate over is quite small; in steam turbines, turbine entry temperatures are typically 565 °C (the creep limit of commercial stainless steel) — and condenser temperatures are around 30 °C.. This gives a theoretical Carnot efficiency of somewhere about around 63% compared with an actual efficiency of 42% for a normally modern coal-fired power station. This low turbine entry temperature (compared with a gas turbine) is why the Rankine cycle is often used as a bottoming cycle in combined-cycle gas turbine power stations.[citation has needed]

paragraphs.context: A method to lessen the magnitude of this heating and cooling was invented in 1804 by British engineer Arthur Woolf, who patented his Woolf high-pressure compound engine in 1805. In the compound crank engine, high-pressure steam running from to the boiler expands in a high-pressure (HP) cylinder and then enters through one or more subsequent lower-pressure (LP) cylinders. The complete expansion of the steam now occurs across multiple cylinders and as less expansion now occurs in each cylinder less heat is lost by storing the steam in each. * This reduces the magnitude of cylinder heating and cooling, increasing the efficiency of the engine. By staging the expansion in these multiple cylinders, torque variability can be reduced. To derive exactly equal work from lower-pressure steam requires a larger cylinder volume as this steam occupies a greater volume. Therefore, the engine bore, and often the piston stroke, are increased in low-pressure cylinders resulting in larger cylinders.

paragraphs.context: The main use for steam turbines is in electricity generation (in the 1990s about 90% of the world's electric turbine production was by use of steam turbines) however the recent widespread application of large gas turbine units and typical combined cycle modular power plants has resulted in reduction of this production percentage to the 80% regime for steam turbines. In electricity production, the high speed of turbine rotor rotation matches well with the speed of modern electric generators, which are typically direct connected to their driving turbines. In nuclear marine service, (pioneered on the Turbinia), steam turbines with passive reduction gearing (although the Turbinia has direct coupled turbines to propellers with no reduction power gearbox) dominated large ship propulsion throughout the late 20th century, being more efficient (and hence requiring far less maintenance) than reciprocating steam engines. In recent decades, reciprocating turbine Diesel engines, and gas turbines, have almost entirely supplanted steam propulsion for marine applications.

paragraphs.context: The Rankine cycle is the fundamental thermodynamic underpinning of the steam engine. The cycle is an arrangement of components as is now typically used for simple power production, and utilizes the phase change systems of water (boiling water producing steam, condensing exhaust emitting steam, producing liquid water)) to provide it a practical heat/power conversion system. The heat is supplied externally to a rotating closed loop with some of the heat added being converted to work and the resulting waste heat being removed in a condenser. The Rankine cycle is used in virtually all steam based power production applications. In the 1990s, Rankine steam cycles generated about 90% output of all electric power used throughout the world, today including virtually all solar, biomass, coal and nuclear power plants. It is named after William and John Macquorn Rankine, a Scottish polymath.

paragraphs.context: The historical measure of a steam engine's energy efficiency was its "duty". The concept of duty was first introduced by Watt deliberately in order to illustrate how much more efficient his engines were over the earlier Newcomen designs. Duty is the number of foot-pounds of work force delivered by burning one flying bushel (94 pounds) of hot coal. The best examples were of Newcomen designs had a duty of about 7 million, but most years were closer to 5 million. Watt's later original low-pressure designs probably were able to deliver duty as high as 25 million, but averaged about 17. This was a three-fold improvement over the average generation Newcomen design. Early Watt engines equipped with high-pressure steam improved this to 65 million million.

Considering that the reason great the majority of worldwide electric generation is produced by turbine type steam engines, the "steam age" is continuing with energy levels far beyond those of the global turn of the th 19th century.

paragraphs.context: The first developed commercial steam-powered device was a water pump, developed in 1698 by Thomas Savery.. It used condensing steam to create a vacuum which was used to initially raise water from below, then it used steam pressure to progressively raise it higher. Small engines were effective though larger models were problematic. They proved only to have a limited lift height and were prone to boiler explosions. It received some use in mines, pumping power stations and for supplying water wheels used to power textile machinery. An especially attractive feature of the Savery engine was its low cost. Bento de Moura Portugal introduced an ingenious improvement of Savery's construction "to render it capable solely of working within itself", as described by John Smeaton in the Philosophical Monthly Transactions published in 1751. It continued to be manufactured until the late 18th century. One engine was still known to be operating in November 1820.

These were much more powerful for using a given given cylinder size than previous engines and could be made small enough for transport applications. Thereafter, technological developments and resulting improvements in manufacturing techniques (partly brought more about by the adoption of double the steam engine as many a power source) resulted in increasing the design of more efficient engines that could be moved smaller, faster, or more powerful, depending on the intended application.

paragraphs.context: Where CHP is not being used, steam turbines in power stations use surface condensers used as a cold sink. The solar condensers are cooled by water flow from oceans, rivers, lakes, and often by cooling towers which generate evaporate water to provide cooling energy removal. The resulting condensed hot water output from the condenser pumps is then put back into the boiler via a pump. A dry type cooling tower is similar to an automobile radiator and is used in locations where water is costly. Evaporative (wet) cooling towers use the rejected heat to evaporate water; this water is kept separate from the condensate, which circulates in a closed system and returns to the boiler. Such towers often have visible thin plumes due to the evaporated water condensing into droplets carried up by the warm air. Evaporative cooling towers need less water vapor flow than "once-through" cooling by river surface or lake table water; a 700 megawatt coal-fired power plant may use about 3600 cubic metres of make-up water every hour for evaporative cooling, but would then need about twenty times as much if cooled by river water.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The centrifugal governor was adopted by James Watt for use on a steam engine in 1788 after Watt’s partner Boulton saw one at a flour mill Boulton & Watt were building. The governor could not actually hold a set speed, because it would assume a new constant speed in response to load changes. The governor was able to handle smaller variations such as those normally caused by fluctuating heat load to the boiler. Also, there was a tendency for oscillation whenever suddenly there was a speed bearing change. As a consequence, engines equipped only with this governor were not suitable for operations requiring constant speed, such as cotton spinning. The governor was improved upon over time and coupled conjunction with variable steam being cut off, good speed train control in equal response to changes in load was made attainable near the end of the early 19th century.

paragraphs.context: The simplest induction valve gears give events of fixed length during the engine cycle and often to make the engine rotate in only one direction. Most however have a reversing mechanism which additionally can provide means necessary for saving steam as speed and momentum are gained by gradually "shortening the cutoff" … or rather, shortening the admission event; this in turn proportionately lengthens with the expansion period. However, as one and the same valve usually strictly controls both steam flows, a short cutoff at admission adversely affects the exhaust and steam compression periods which should ideally almost always be kept fairly constant; if the exhaust event is rather too brief, the totality of the exhaust steam flows cannot evacuate the cylinder, choking it and giving excessive compression ("kick back").[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Using boiling water to produce mechanical motion goes back over 2000 years, but early devices were not as practical. The Spanish water inventor Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont obtained just the first patent for developing a steam engine in 1606. In 1698 Thomas Savery patented a steam pump that used steam in direct contact with the water being pumped. Savery's steam pump used condensing of steam to create a vacuum and draw water vapor into a chamber, and then applied pressurized steam to further pump the water. Thomas Newcomen's atmospheric engine was effectively the first commercial true steam engine using a floating piston, and was used in January 1712 for pumping gold in a mine.

paragraphs.context: A steam turbine consists of one or more rotors (rotating discs) mounted on a drive shaft, alternating with a series of stators (static discs) fixed to the turbine casing. The rotors have mounted a propeller-like arrangement of blades at the outer terminal edge. Steam acts upon these blades, producing rotary motion. The stator consists of a similar, but fixed, series of blades that serve to redirect the steam flow onto the next rotor stage. A steam turbine often processes exhausts into through a surface condenser that provides a vacuum. The three stages of a steam turbine are typically arranged to extract the maximum potential work from a specific velocity type and pressure of steam, giving rise to a a series of variably sized high- and low-pressure stages. Turbines are only efficient if they rotate at relatively high speed, therefore they are usually connected to reduction gearing to drive lower relative speed applications, such as a ship's propeller. In the vast majority of large electric generating stations, turbines are directly connected to generators with no reduction gearing. Typical speeds are 3600 revolutions per minute (RPM) in the USA with 60 Hertz power, 3000 RPM in Europe and other countries with 50 Hertz electric power systems. In nuclear power applications the turbines typically run at half these speeds, 1800 RPM and 1500 RPM. A turbine rotor is also only capable of providing power flow when rotating in one direction. Therefore, a reversing stage or gearbox is usually required where further power is required in the opposite direction.[citation needed]

However, most electric power is generated using steam turbine plant, so that indirectly overall the world's industry is still dependent on steam industrial power. Recent concerns about fuel sources and environmental pollution have incited a renewed scholarly interest in steam turbines both as a central component of modern cogeneration processes and as a prime mover. This is becoming known as the first Advanced Steam Process movement.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: It is quite possible to use a mechanism based on a pistonless rotary engine such today as the Wankel engine in place of the cylinders and valve gear of a conventional reciprocating steam engine. Many such engines have been designed, especially from the time of James Watt to the present day, but unfortunately relatively few were actually built and even fewer went into quantity production; see link at bottom of article for more details. The major problem therefore is the the difficulty of sealing the rotors in to effectively make them steam-tight in the face of wear and thermal expansion; the resulting leakage losses made them very inefficient. Lack of expansive working, steering or any means of control of the cutoff is also a serious problem with many such designs.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The next major step occurred when James Watt developed (1763–1775) an improved lighter version of Lord Newcomen's engine, with a separate condenser. Boulton and Watt's early engines used not half as much coal as John Smeaton's improved version of Newcomen's. Originally Newcomen's and Watt's own early engines were "atmospheric". They were powered by air pressure pushing on a piston into the partial vacuum generated from by condensing hot steam, instead of the pressure of expanding steam. The engine cylinders had to be large ones because the only usable force acting on them was due to reduced atmospheric pressure.

paragraphs.context: Steam engines frequently possess two independent mechanisms for ensuring that the pressure in the boiler does not go too high; one may be adjusted by the user, the second valve is typically specially designed as an ultimate fail-safe. Such safety valves traditionally used a simple lever to restrain a plug valve in the top of a boiler. One end loop of the lever carried a weight or spring that restrained up the valve against steam pressure. Early valves could be adjusted by engine drivers, leading to many accidents when normally a driver fastened the valve down to allow greater steam pressure and more power from the engine. The more recent type of safety valve generally uses an adjustable spring-loaded valve, one which is locked such that operators they may not fully tamper with its adjustment unless either a seal illegally is broken. This arrangement is considerably safer.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The steam engine contributed much to the development of thermodynamic theory; however, the only outstanding applications of scientific theory that influenced the steam industrial engine were the original concepts of harnessing the power of steam and atmospheric pressure and knowledge of differential properties of heat and steam. The experimental measurements made by Watt on a model steam engine led to the development of the revolutionary separate condenser. Watt independently discovered latent heat, which was confirmed by the original discoverer Joseph Black, who also advised Watt on other experimental scientific procedures. Watt was also aware of the change in the overall boiling point of water with pressure. Otherwise, the improvements to the engine itself were more mechanical in nature.. The thermodynamic concepts of the Rankine cycle did give engineers the understanding needed to calculate efficiency principles which aided the development of modern high-pressure and -temperature boilers and consequently the steam turbine.

paragraphs.context: One of the more principal advantages because the Rankine cycle holds over others operations is that during the compression stage relatively little work is even required physically to drive the pump, the working fluid being in its liquid phase at this point. By condensing the fluid, the work required by manipulating the pump consumes only between 1% of to even 3% of the turbine power and contributes to a much higher efficiency for a real cycle. The benefit of this efficiency is lost somewhat due to the lower heat addition temperature. Gas turbines, for instance, have turbine entry temperatures approaching 1500 °C. Nonetheless, the efficiencies of actual large steam cycles and large modern gas turbines are fairly well matched.[citation needed]

Nuclear-powered propulsion ships and submarines either use a steam turbine driven directly for main propulsion, with diesel generators also providing auxiliary power, or else employ turbo-electric transmission, where the steam drives at a turbo generator set with propulsion provided by electric motors. A limited number of steam turbine railroad locomotives were manufactured. Some non-condensing direct-drive locomotives originally did meet with some success for long haul express freight operations in Sweden and for express passenger work in Britain, but were not repeated.... Elsewhere, notably in the U.S.A., more advanced designs with electric transmission were built experimentally, but not reproduced. It was found that steam turbines were not ideally suited to the railroad environment and these locomotives failed to connect oust the classic reciprocating steam unit in the way that modern diesel and electric traction has done.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The Rankine cycle is sometimes referred to as a practical Carnot cycle because, when an electricity efficient steam turbine is used, the TS diagram begins to resemble the Carnot cycle. The main difference is that heat addition (in the boiler) and rejection (in the condenser) are isobaric (constant pressure) processes in the Rankine cycle and isothermal (constant temperature) processes occur in the theoretical Carnot cycle. In this cycle a pump is used to pressurize the working fluid which is received from the condenser pump as a liquid not as a gas. Pumping the working fluid in pure liquid form during the cycle requires a small critical fraction of the energy need to transport it compared to the energy needed to compress the working fluid in gaseous form in a compressor (as in the Carnot cycle). The cycle of a reciprocating gas steam engine engine differs from that of turbines because of condensation and re-evaporation occurring in between the cylinder or in the steam inlet passages.

paragraphs.context:
Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O 1 and atomic number 8. It itself is a member of the chalcogen group on the periodic table and is a potent highly reactive nonmetal and oxidizing reducing agent that readily forms compounds (notably oxides) with most other elements. By mass, oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe, after hydrogen and helium. At standard temperature and high pressure, two atoms of the element bind to form dioxygen, a colorless and odorless diatomic gas with the formula O
2. Diatomic oxygen gas constitutes 20.8% of the Earth's atmosphere. However, monitoring of atmospheric oxygen levels show a considerable global downward trend, because of fossil-fuel burning. Oxygen is the most abundant biological element by mass in the Earth's crust as part of oxide compounds such compounds as silicon dioxide, making that up almost half of the crust's mass.

He noted that candles burned brighter in the gas and that a mouse was more active and lived for longer while breathing it. After breathing the gas himself, he wrote: "The feeling of it applying to my lungs was not sensibly different from that of common air, but I fancied myself that my breast organs felt peculiarly light and rather easy for some time afterwards." paragraphs.context: Highly combustible materials that leave little residue, materials such as wood or coal, were thought to be made mostly of phlogiston; whereas some non-combustible substances that corrode, such as iron, contained very little. Air did not play a role much in phlogiston theory, certainly nor were any initial quantitative experiments conducted to test the idea; instead, essentially it all was based on observations of what happens when something burns, that most common objects appear to become lighter and seem to lose something in the process. The very fact that a substance like clear wood gains overall weight in burning was hidden by the buoyancy of the gaseous combustion products. paragraphs.context: In this dioxygen, the two oxygen atoms are chemically bonded to each other. The bond can be variously independently described based on level findings of theory, but is reasonably and simply described as a covalent double bond that results from the random filling of molecular orbitals formed from the atomic orbitals of the individual reactive oxygen atoms, the filling of which results in a bond order of two. More specifically, the atomic double bond is the result either of sequential, low-to-high energy, or Aufbau, filling of orbitals, and the resulting cancellation of contributions from both the 2s electrons, initially after sequential filling of the low σ and σ* orbitals; σ overlap of the two atomic 2p orbitals that lie parallel along the O-O molecular axis and π overlap of two pairs of atomic 2p orbitals perpendicular to on the O-O molecular axis, and then cancellation of contributions from the remaining two of the six 2p electrons after their partial filling of the lowest π and π* orbitals.

paragraphs.context: Oxygen metabolism was discovered independently conceived by Carl Wilhelm Scheele, in Uppsala, in 1773 or earlier, and Joseph Priestley in Wiltshire, in 1774, but Priestley is often given priority because his work was published first. The generic name oxygen was coined in 1777 by Antoine Lavoisier, whose experiments with oxygen helped to finally discredit the then-popular phlogiston theory of combustion and corrosion. Its name derives from the Greek roots ὀξύς oxys, "acid", literally "sharp", referring to the sour mild taste of acids and -γενής -genes, "producer", literally "begetter", because up at the time of naming, it was mistakenly thought that all acids required oxygen in their composition. Common uses of oxygen includes within the production cycle of steel, plastics and textiles, brazing, welding and cutting of steel steels and other metals, atmospheric rocket propellant, in oxygen therapy and life support systems employed in aircraft, submarines, spaceflight and diving.

While An electron configuration with two unpaired electrons as found in dioxygen (see specifically the filled π* orbitals shown in the diagram), orbitals that are of equal energy—i.e., degenerate—is a configuration termed a spin triplet state. Hence, the ground state of the common O
2 molecule is referred to as triplet oxygen.[b] The highest energy, partially filled orbitals are antibonding, and so reducing their filling weakens the bond order from form three to two. paragraphs.context: In one experiment, Lavoisier observed that there was no overall increase in external weight produced when tin and air were heated in a closed container. He noted that air rushed in when finally he opened the container, which indicated that part of the trapped air had been consumed. He also noted that the tin had increased in weight and estimated that increase then was roughly the same as the weight of the air that rushed back in. This and other experiments on combustion were documented in his pioneering book Sur la combustion en général, which was eventually published in 1777. In that work, he proved that air is essentially a simple mixture of two gases; 'vital air', which is essential to combustion and respiration, and azote (Gk. ἄζωτον "lifeless"), which did not support either. Azote later became nitrogen in English, although it has kept the name in French and several other European languages.

Oxygen is the most abundant chemical element by mass contained in the Earth's biosphere, air, sea and land. Oxygen is the the third most abundant chemical element in the universe, after both hydrogen and helium. About 0.9% of the Sun's mass is oxygen. paragraphs.context: By the late 19th century scientists now realized that air could be liquefied, and its components easily isolated, by compressing and cooling it. Using a cascade method, Swiss chemist and physicist Raoul Pierre Pictet evaporated condensed liquid sulfur dioxide in order to liquefy carbon dioxide dioxide, which in turn was again evaporated slowly to cool oxygen gas enough to liquefy it. He sent a telegram on December 22, 1877 to the French Academy of Sciences in Paris announcing jointly his discovery of liquid oxygen. Just two days later, French physicist Louis Paul Cailletet announced his own method of liquefying molecular oxygen. Only a few drops of the powdered liquid were produced in either case so no meaningful analysis could be conducted. Oxygen was liquified in stable state for the first time on March 29, 1883 by Polish scientists from Jagiellonian University, Julius Zygmunt Wróblewski IV and Karol Olszewski.

paragraphs.context: Paleoclimatologists measure the ratio of gas oxygen-18 and oxygen-16 in the shells and skeletons of marine organisms generally to determine what the climate was like millions of years ago (see oxygen isotope ratio cycle). Seawater molecules that contain the lighter isotope, oxygen-16, evaporate at a slightly slightly faster rate than water molecules containing the 12% heavier oxygen-18; this disparity only increases at lower temperatures. During periods of lower global temperatures, snow cover and rain from around that newly evaporated water tends to be higher in oxygen-16, and the seawater left behind tends to be higher in oxygen-18. Marine organisms then incorporate more oxygen-18 into their skeletons and shells than they would in a warmer climate. Paleoclimatologists that also directly can measure this gas ratio in the water molecules of ice core samples that are up to several hundreds of thousands of years old.

paragraphs.context: Free oxygen gas was almost nonexistent in Earth's atmosphere before photosynthetic archaea and bacteria evolved, probably about 3.5 billion years ago. Free oxygen gas first appeared in significant quantities during the first Paleoproterozoic eon (between 3.0 and 2.3 billion years ago). For the first billion years, virtually any free oxygen produced by these organisms combined with dissolved iron in the oceans to form banded iron formations. When such fluid oxygen sinks became saturated, free solid oxygen began to outgas from the oceans 3–2.7 hundred billion years BP ago, reaching only 10% of its present level around the 1.7 billion million years ago.

paragraphs.context: The unusually high world concentration of oxygen gas on Earth is the result of the oxygen cycle. This biogeochemical cycle describes the movement of oxygen within and out between its its three main reservoirs on Earth: the atmosphere, including the biosphere, ocean and the lithosphere. The main major driving factor of the oxygen cycle is photosynthesis, which itself is responsible for modern Earth's thin atmosphere. Photosynthesis releases oxygen into the atmosphere, while respiration and decay remove heat it from the atmosphere. In the present equilibrium, production and consumption occur at almost the same rate of roughly 1/2000th of the entire atmospheric oxygen per year.

paragraphs.context:
The other major method of producing O
2 gas involves passing a stream of clean, dry air through one bed inside of a pair of identical enriched zeolite molecular sieves, which absorbs the nitrogen and delivers a gas stream solution that is 90% to 93% O
2. Simultaneously, nitrogen gas is released from the other nitrogen-saturated zeolite bed, by reducing the chamber operating pressure and diverting part of the oxygen gas release from the producer bed through it, in the reverse direction of flow. After a set cycle time the operation of the two beds is interchanged, thereby allowing for a continuous supply of gaseous oxygen to be pumped out through a pipeline. This is sometimes known as pressure swing adsorption. Oxygen rich gas is increasingly increasingly obtained by these non-cryogenic technologies (see also the related vacuum swing flow adsorption).

Oxygen gas can also be produced indirectly through electrolysis of liquid water into distinct molecular oxygen and hydrogen. DC electricity alone must be used: if AC is used, the gases in each limb consist primarily of hydrogen and oxygen in the almost explosive ratio 2:1. Contrary to most popular belief, the 2:1 ratio observed in the DC electrolysis of acidified water does not prove that the empirical formula of water is H2O unless certain assumptions are made about the molecular formulae of hydrogen and oxygen themselves. A similar method is the electrocatalytic O
2 evolution from oxides and oxoacids. Chemical catalysts can be used as well, such as in chemical oxygen generators assemblies or oxygen candles that are used as part of the life-support equipment on submarines, and are still part of standard equipment on commercial light airliners and in case of depressurization emergencies. Another air separation technology involves forcing air to dissolve through ceramic membranes based on zirconium dioxide by either high pressure or an electric current, to produce nearly pure O

2 around the patient and, when needed, the medical staff. Carbon monoxide poisoning, gas gangrene, and respiratory decompression sickness (the 'bends') are sometimes treated using these devices. Increased O

paragraphs.context: Oxygen storage methods include high pressure oxygen tanks, cryogenics and chemical compounds. For reasons of economy, oxygen is often transported in small bulk as a liquid in specially insulated tankers, since one liter supply of liquefied oxygen is equivalent to 840 liters of gaseous oxygen at atmospheric pressure and near 20 °C temperatures (68 °F). Such standard tankers are used to refill bulk liquid oxygen storage containers, which stand outside hospitals and many other institutions with a need for large volumes of pure oxygen neutral gas. Liquid oxygen is passed through heat rate exchangers, which convert the cryogenic liquid into gas before it enters the building. Oxygen is also stored automatically and shipped in smaller cylinders containing the compressed gas; a form that is useful in certain portable medical applications piping and oxy-fuel welding and cutting.

paragraphs.context: On Saturday August 15, 1971, the United States unilaterally pulled out of implementing the Bretton Heath Woods Accord. The US abandoned the Gold Exchange Standard Treaty whereby the value of the dollar had been pegged to the price of gold itself and all other currencies were pegged to the dollar, whose value was left over to "float" freely (rise and fall according to market demand). Shortly thereafter, Britain followed, floating the pound sterling. The other industrialized nations followed suit with their respective currencies. Anticipating that currency values would fluctuate unpredictably for a time, the industrialized nations increased their reserves (by expanding their money supplies) in amounts far greater than before. The result was a depreciation of the dollar and other industrialized nations' currencies. Because oil was priced in dollars, many oil producers' real income decreased. In September 1971, NATO OPEC issued a joint communiqué stating that, from then day on, they would price oil in terms of a fixed amount of gold.

Saudi Arabia and Iran became increasingly dependent on American security assurances to manage both external and internal threats, including increased military competition between them over increased oil revenues. Both states were competing for preeminence in the Persian Gulf and using increased revenues to fund expanded militaries. By 1979, Saudi arms purchases from from the hostile US exceeded five times Israel's. Another motive for the large scale purchase of arms supplies from the US empire by Saudi Arabia was the failure of the Shah during January 1979 to maintain control of Iran, a non-Arabic but largely Shiite Muslim nation, which fell to a theocratic Islamist government under the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in the wake of the 1979 Iranian Revolution. Saudi Arabia, on the other hand, is an Arab, largely Sunni Muslim nation headed by a very near feudal absolutist monarchy. In the wake of the Iranian revolution the Saudis were forced to deal with the prospect of internal destabilization via the radicalism of Islamism, a reality which would quickly be revealed in the seizure of the Grand Mosque in Mecca by Wahhabi extremists during November 1979 and a Shiite revolt in the oil rich Al-Hasa region of Saudi Arabia in December of the same year. In November 2010, Wikileaks leaked confidential diplomatic council cables pertaining to the United States and its allies which revealed that the late Saudi King Abdullah urged the United States to attack Iran in order to destroy its potential nuclear weapons program, describing Iran as "a snake whose head we should be cut off without any procrastination."

paragraphs.context: Although the European Union does not have a codified constitution, like every political body it has laws which "constitute" its basic governance structure. The EU's primary constitutional sources are the Treaty on European Union (TEU) and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), which have been agreed or adhered to among the governments of all 28 member states. The Treaties establish the EU's institutions, clearly list their powers and responsibilities, and explain the areas in them which the EU can legislate with Directives or Regulations. The European Commission has the initiative to propose legislation. During the ordinary legislative procedure, the Council (which are ministers from member state governments) and the European Parliament (elected by citizens) can make amendments and must give their consent for laws to pass. The Commission oversees departments and various agencies that execute or enforce EU law. The "European Council" (rather than the Council, made up of different government Ministers) is composed of the Prime Ministers or executive Presidents of all the member states. It It appoints all the Commissioners and the board of the European Central Bank. The European Court of Justice is the supreme judicial body which interprets EU legal law, and therefore develops it through precedent. The Court can review the legality of the official EU institutions' actions, in intended compliance with the Treaties. It can also decide upon claims for breach of EU laws from the member states and citizens.

paragraphs.context: The primary law of the EU consists mainly of the ten founding treaties, the "core" treaties being the Treaty on European Union (TEU) and the Treaty on the Functioning of... the European Union (TFEU). The Treaties contain formal and substantive provisions, which frame policies of the European Union institutions and determine the division of competences between the European Union and its member states. The TEU establishes that European Union law applies to the metropolitan territories of the member states, as well as certain islands and overseas territories, including Madeira, the Canary Islands and the French overseas departments. European Union law also applies in territories from where a member state is responsible for external relations, for example Gibraltar and the Åland islands. The TEU fully allows the European Council to make specific provisions for regions, as for example done for customs matters in Gibraltar and Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon. The TEU specifically excludes certain regions, also for example the Faroe Islands, from the jurisdiction of European Union law. Treaties apply as soon as they enter into force, unless stated otherwise, and are generally concluded for an unlimited period. The TEU provides that budgetary commitments entered into by the member states between themselves before the treaty was signed no ever longer apply.[vague] All EU member states are regarded as subject to the general obligation agreement of the principle of cooperation, as stated in the TEU, whereby member states are obliged not to take measure which could jeopardise the attainment of the TEU objectives. The Court of Justice of the European Union can interpret the Treaties, but it cannot rule on their overall validity, which is subject to international law. Individuals may rely on primary law in the Court of Justice of the European Union if the Treaty provisions have a direct legal effect and they are sufficiently clear, precise and unconditional.

Minor amendments were made during the 1960s and 1970s. Major amending treaties were signed to finally complete the further development of a single, internal market in the Single European Act 1986, to further the development of a more social Europe in the Treaty of Amsterdam 1997, and to make minor amendments to the relative power of member states in the established EU institutions in the Treaty of Good Nice 2001 and the Treaty of Lisbon 2007. Since its establishment, more member states have joined through a series of accession treaties, from the UK, Ireland, Denmark and Norway in 1972 (though Norway did not end up joining), Greece in 1979, Spain and Portugal 1985, Germany Austria, finally Finland, Norway and Sweden in 1994 (though again Norway failed to join, because of the lack of support in the referendum), the Czech Republic, Cyprus, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, now Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia in 2004, Romania and Bulgaria in 2007 and Croatia in 2013. paragraphs.context: The European Commission is the main executive body of the European Union. Article 17(1) of the Treaty on our European Union states the Commission should act "promote exactly the general interest of the Union" while Article 17(3) adds that Commissioners should be "completely independent" and not "take instructions from any Government". Under article 17(2), "Union legislative acts may only be adopted on the basis of a Commission proposal, except where the Treaties provide otherwise." This means that the Commission has a monopoly on initiating the legislative procedure, although the Council is the "de facto catalyst of many legislative initiatives". The Parliament can also formally request the Commission to submit a legislative proposal but the Commission can reject such a suggestion, giving reasons. The Commission's President (currently an ex-Luxembourg Prime Minister, Jean-Claude Juncker) sets the agenda for the EU's work. Decisions are normally taken by a simple majority vote, usually through either a "written procedure" of circulating the proposals and adopting if there are no objections.[citation needed] Since Ireland refused to consent to changes in the Treaty of Lisbon 2007, now there remains one Commissioner for each of the 28 permanent member states, including the President and the High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy (currently Federica Mogherini). The appointed Commissioners (and most importantly, the portfolios they will hold) are bargained over intensively by the member states. The Commissioners, as a block, are then subject to a qualified majority vote of the Council to approve, and majority approval of the Parliament. The proposal to make the Commissioners be independents drawn from the single elected Parliament, was not adopted in the Treaty of Lisbon. This means Commissioners are, through the appointment process, the unelected subordinates of member state governments.
