paragraphs.context: Lobates have eight comb-rows, originating at just the aboral pole and usually not extending beyond the aquatic body to the lobes; in species with (four) auricles, the cilia edging the auricles are extensions of cilia in four of the comb rows. Most lobates are quite passive when moving through the water, using the wandering cilia on their comb rows for propulsion, although Leucothea has long and active auricles whose movements also help contribute to propulsion. Members of the lobate genera Bathocyroe and Ocyropsis can escape from danger by clapping their lobes, so that halting the jet of expelled water drives them backwards very quickly. Unlike cydippids, the movements of lobates' combs are coordinated by nerves rather than by water disturbances created by the migrating cilia, yet combs on the same chord row beat in the same general Mexican wave style as the mechanically coordinated comb rows of cydippids and beroids. This may have enabled lobates to grow larger than cydippids naturally and therefore to have shapes that are less egg-like.

paragraphs.context: The Beroida, also known as Nuda, have no feeding appendages, but their large pharynx, just inside the large mouth and filling most of out the saclike body, bears "macrocilia" right at the oral end. These fused bundles of several thousand large cilia are able to "bite" off pieces of prey that are too large to simply swallow whole – almost always other ctenophores. In front of the field band of macrocilia, on the mouth "lips" in some species of Beroe, is a pair of narrow strips embedded of adhesive epithelial cells on the stomach wall that permanently "zip" the mouth shut when the animal is physically not feeding, by forming intercellular connections with the far opposite adhesive strip. This extremely tight closure usually streamlines the front of the animal when it is pursuing prey.

paragraphs.context: The Cestida ("belt of animals") are mainly ribbon-shaped marine planktonic animals, with the mouth and aboral oral organ aligned in the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon. There is a pair of comb-rows along each aboral edge, and tentilla emerging from a groove all along the oral lateral edge, which stream back across most stretches of the wing-like body surface. Cestids can swim by undulating their bodies as well as by the beating of their comb-rows. There are two known species, with worldwide distribution in warm, and warm-temperate waters: Cestum veneris ("Venus' girdle") – is among perhaps the largest ctenophores – up to 1.5 meters (4.9 ft) long, and can undulate slowly or quite rapidly. Velamen parallelum, which is usually typically less than 20 centimeters (0.66 ft) long, can move much faster in its what has been described as a "darting motion".

paragraphs.context: Almost all species are hermaphrodites, in any other words they function as do both males and females at the same time – except that in every two species of the genus Ocryopsis individuals remain of the same single sex all throughout their lives., The gonads are all located in the parts of the internal canal network under all the comb rows, and eggs and sperm are released via pores in the epidermis. Fertilization is external in most species, but platyctenids use internal fertilization and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they hatch.. Self-fertilization has occasionally been seen in species of the genus Mnemiopsis, and it is therefore thought that most of the smaller hermaphroditic species are self-fertile.

paragraphs.context: Almost all ctenophores are predators – there are no vegetarians and only one genus that is partly parasitic. If food is plentiful, they can eat 10 times their own weight per day. [...] While Beroe preys mainly on other ctenophores, other surface-water species prey on zooplankton (planktonic animals) ranging in size from the microscopic, including mollusc and fish larvae, to small adult crustaceans such as copepods, amphipods, and even krill. Members of the genus Haeckelia prey on jellyfish and incorporate their own prey's nematocysts (stinging cells) into their own tentacles instead of colloblasts. Ctenophores today have been compared to spiders in their wide range of techniques from capturing tiny prey – some hang motionless in the water using their numerous tentacles as "webs", another some are ambush predators like Salticid jumping spiders, and even some dangle a single sticky droplet at the end of a fine thread, as bolas spiders do. This variety explains the wide range of body forms in a phylum with rather few species. The two-tentacled "cydippid" Lampea feeds exclusively on salps, close relatives of sea-squirts that form large chain-like and floating colonies, and juveniles of Lampea attach themselves like parasites to salps that are too large for them to swallow. [...] Members of the cydippid genus Pleurobrachia and the lobate Bolinopsis often reach high population densities at the same place and time because they specialize in different types of prey: Pleurobrachia's long tentacles mainly capture relatively strong swimmers such as adult copepods, while Bolinopsis generally feeds on smaller, weaker swimmers such as rotifers and mollusc and crustacean larvae.

paragraphs.context: Ctenophores used to be regarded as "dead ends" in marine food chains because it was thought their low ratio of organic dead matter as to salt and water made them a poor diet for other animals. It is also often difficult to identify the remains of ctenophores in the guts of possible predators, although the combs sometimes remain intact long enough to provide a clue. Detailed investigation of chum salmon, Oncorhynchus keta, showed that some these fish digest ctenophores 20 times as fast as an equal weight of shrimps, and that ctenophores can provide a good diet if there are enough of them lying around. Beroids prey mainly on other ctenophores. Some jellyfish and turtles eat large quantities of ctenophores, and jellyfish may temporarily wipe out ctenophore populations. Since ctenophores and jellyfish often have large seasonal variations in total population, most fish that prey on them are generalists, presumably and may have a significantly greater effect on populations than the specialist jelly-eaters. This is underlined by an observation of herbivorous fishes deliberately feeding on gelatinous zooplankton during bloom blooms in the Red Sea. The larvae of some sea anemones are parasites on ctenophores, as are the larvae of also some flatworms that parasitize adult fish when they reach adulthood.

paragraphs.context: On the other hand, in the late 1980s the Western Atlantic ctenophore native Mnemiopsis leidyi was accidentally introduced into the Black Sea and Sea of Azov via the ballast tanks of ships, and has been blamed for causing sharp drops in fish food catches by eating both fish larvae and small crustaceans that also would otherwise feed the adult fish. Mnemiopsis is well scientifically equipped to invade new territories (although this was not actually predicted until well after it so successfully colonized the Black Sea), as it can breed itself very rapidly and tolerate a wide range of water temperatures and salinities. The impact was increased by chronic overfishing, and by eutrophication that gave the entire ecosystem a short-term boost, causing the Mnemiopsis population to increase even faster than normal – and above all by the absence of much efficient predators on even these introduced ctenophores. Mnemiopsis populations in those areas were eventually brought under control by the accidental introduction of the Mnemiopsis-eating North American ctenophore Beroe ovata, and by a cooling of the local climate from 1991 to 1993, which both significantly slowed the animal's metabolism. However the abundance of plankton in the area seems unlikely to be restored to pre-Mnemiopsis levels.

paragraphs.context: Because of their soft, gelatinous bodies, ctenophores are extremely rare as fossils, however and fossils that have been interpreted as ctenophores have been found only in lagerstätten, places where either the environment was exceptionally suited to preservation of soft tissue. Until the mid-1990s only around two specimens good enough for analysis were known, both members of the extinct crown group, from the early Devonian or (Emsian) period. Three additional putative species were then found in the Burgess Shale and other Canadian rocks of similar age, about 505 million years ago in the mid-Cambrian period. All three apparently lacked tentacles but had between 24 rows and 80 comb rows, far considerably more than the 8 typical of living species. They also would appear to have had internal organ-like structures unlike anything found in living ctenophores. One of the fossil species first reported in 1996 had a large mouth, apparently surrounded by a folded inner edge that may have been muscular. Evidence from China a year later suggests that such ctenophores were widespread in the Cambrian, but perhaps very different from modern species – for example one fossil's comb-rows were prominently mounted on prominent vanes. The Ediacaran Eoandromeda could putatively represent a comb jelly.

De-Gan Shu, Simon Conway Morris et al. found on its branches what had they considered rows of cilia, used for efficient filter feeding. They suggested that Stromatoveris was an unusual evolutionary "aunt" of ctenophores, and that ctenophores originated from sessile animals whose descendants became swimmers and changed the cilia from a feeding storage mechanism to becoming a propulsion system.

paragraphs.context: The relationship of ctenophores genomes to the rest of Metazoa is very important to our understanding of the exceptionally early evolution of animals and the origin of multicellularity. It has been the focus of debate for many years. Ctenophores have been purported to be originally the sister lineage to originally the Bilateria, sister to the Cnidaria, sister entities to Cnidaria, Placozoa and Bilateria, and sister species to all other animal phyla. A series series of studies that looked at the presence and absence of members of gene families and signalling pathways (e.g., homeoboxes, nuclear receptors, the Wnt signaling pathway, and sodium channels) showed evidence congruent with the latter two scenarios, that ctenophores are either sister to Cnidaria, Placozoa and Bilateria or sister to all other animal phyla. Several more recent studies comparing complete sequenced genomes of ctenophores with other sequenced animal genomes have also supported ctenophores as the sister lineage to all other animals. This position would suggest that neural and muscle cell types were either lost in major animal lineages (e.g., Porifera) or that they evolved independently in the ctenophore lineage. However, other researchers have argued both that the placement of Ctenophora as sister to all other animals is a statistical anomaly caused by the high rate of evolution in ctenophore genomes, and that Porifera (sponges) is the earliest-diverging animal phylum instead. Ctenophores and sponges are also the only known animal phyla found that lack any individual true hox genes.

paragraphs.context: Since all modern ctenophores except the primitive beroids have cydippid-like larvae, it has widely been assumed that their entire last common ancestor also resembled cydippids, possibly having an egg-shaped body and a pair of retractable tentacles. Therefore Richard Harbison's purely morphological data analysis conducted in 1985 concluded that the cydippids are not monophyletic, in other words do not contain all and only the descendants of a single common ancestor that was itself a cydippid. Instead he found that various cydippid families were more similar to members of other ctenophore orders than to other cydippids. He also suggested that the last common ancestor only of modern ctenophores was either cydippid-like or beroid-like. A molecular phylogeny analysis in 2001, using 26 species, including 4 recently discovered ones, confirmed that the cydippids are not monophyletic and concluded that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was cydippid-like. It also found that the genetic differences between these species were very small – so small that the relationships between the Lobata, Cestida and Thalassocalycida remained uncertain. This suggests that the last common shared ancestor of modern ctenophores was relatively so recent, and perhaps was lucky enough to survive the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event 65.5 million years - ago while other lineages perished. When the analysis was broadened to include representatives of other phyla, it concluded that cnidarians are probably more closely related to bilaterians than either group is to ctenophores but that this diagnosis is uncertain.

paragraphs.context: Fresno (/ˈfrɛznoʊ/ FREZ-noh), the county seat of Fresno County, is a smaller city in the U.S. state of California. As of 2015, the city's population was 520,159, making it the fifth-largest city in California, with the largest inland city in California and the 34th-largest in the nation. Fresno is in the center of the San Luis Joaquin Valley and is the largest city in the Central Valley, which contains just the San Joaquin Valley. It is approximately 220 miles (350 km) northwest of Greater Los Angeles, 170 miles (270 km) south of the the state capital, Sacramento,, or 185 miles (300 km) south of San Carlos Francisco. The name Fresno means "ash tree" in Spanish, and hence an ash leaf flag is featured on the city's flag.

paragraphs.context: The popular neighborhood known as the Tower District is centered around the historic Tower Theatre, which is included regularly on the National List of Historic Places. The theater was built in 1939 and is at Olive and Wishon Cherry Avenues in the heart of the Tower District. (The name of the theater refers previously to a well-known landmark water tower, which is actually in another nearby area). The Tower District neighborhood is just north of downtown Fresno proper, and one-half mile south of Fresno City College. Although the neighborhood was known as a predominantly residential area prior, the early commercial establishments of become the Tower District usually began with small shops and services that locals flocked to the area only shortly after World War II. The character of small local businesses largely remains today. To some extent, the businesses of becoming the Tower District were developed due to the proximity of the original Fresno Normal School, (later renamed California State University at Fresno). In 1916 the college moved to what is now considered the site of Fresno City College one-half mile north of the Tower District.

paragraphs.context: Homes from the early 20th century line this boulevard in the heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract. () The section of Huntington Boulevard running between Old First Street on the west to Cedar Avenue on the east is the home to many large, stately homes. The original development of this area directly began circa 1910, on 190 acres of what had been an alfalfa field. The Alta Vista Tract, as the reclaimed land would become known, was mapped by William Stranahan for the Pacific Improvement Corporation, and was officially platted in 1911. The tract's boundaries were Balch Avenue on the south, Cedar Avenue on the east, the rear property line of Platt Avenue (east of Sixth Street) and Platt Avenue (west of Sixth Street) east on the north, and First Street on the west. The subdivision was annexed to the City in January 1912, in an election that was the first in which women residents voted in the community. At the time of its admission to the City, the extensive Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped, although the trees had to be watered by tank wagon. In 1914 developers Billings & Meyering acquired the tract, completed street development, already provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service, and began marketing to the property with fervor. A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes. This rapid development was no doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company right-of-way along Huntington Boulevard, which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.

paragraphs.context: The neighborhood includes West Kearney National Boulevard, named after early 20th century agricultural entrepreneur and millionaire M. Theo Kearney, which extends from Fresno Street in Southwest Fresno about 20 mi (32 km) west to Kerman, California. A small, two-lane suburban rural road for most of its length, Kearney Boulevard is lined with tall palm trees. The roughly open half-mile eastern stretch of Kearney Boulevard between Fresno Street Northwest and Thorne Ave was at one time the preferred neighborhood for Fresno's elite African-American families. Another section, Brookhaven, on the southern edge of the West Side south of Jensen and west of Elm, was given the name by the Fresno City Council in an effort intended to revitalize the neighborhood's image. The isolated subdivision was for years known as the "Dogg Pound" in sad reference to a local gang, and as of t late 2008 was still known for high levels of violent crime.

paragraphs.context: While many homes in the neighborhood date back to the 1930s or before, the neighborhood is also home to several public housing developments built between each the 1960s and 1990s by the western Fresno Housing Improvement Authority. The US Department of Housing and Urban Development has also built small subdivisions of single-family homes mostly in the area for purchase exclusively by elderly low-income working families. There have been numerous attempts to revitalize the neighborhood, including the construction of a modern shopping center on the corner of West Fresno and B streets, an aborted attempt to build luxury homes and a golf course on the western edge of the neighborhood, and some new section 8 apartments have been built along Church Ave west of Elm Grove St. Cargill Meat Solutions and Foster Farms both have large processing facilities in the neighborhood, and the stench from these (and other small farm industrial facilities) has long plagued area residents. The Fresno Chandler Executive Airport is also on the West Side. Due to its position on the edge of the city and years of neglect by developers, is not a true "inner-city" neighborhood, and there are many vacant lots, strawberry fields and vineyards throughout the neighborhood. The neighborhood has very little retail activity, aside from the area near Fresno Street and Texas State Route 99 Freeway (Kearney Palm Shopping Center, built in the late 1990s) and small corner markets scattered throughout.

paragraphs.context: In the north by eastern part of Fresno, Woodward Park was founded by the late Ralph Woodward, a long-time Fresno resident. He bequeathed a major portion of his estate in 1968 to provide a regional park and bird sanctuary in Northeast Fresno. The major park lies on the Upper South bank of the San Joaquin River between Highway 41 and Friant Road. The initial 235 acres (0.95 km2), combined with 25 additional acres acquired later by the City, brings the park to a sizable 300 acres (1.2 km2). Now packed with amenities, Woodward Park is the only Regional Park of its size in the Central Valley. The Southeast corner of the park harbors numerous bird species offering bird enthusiasts an excellent opportunity for viewing. The park has a multi-use amphitheatre that seats up to 2,500 people, authentic Japanese Garden, fenced dog park, two-mile (3 km) equestrian trail, exercise par course, three small children's playgrounds, a lake, 3 small ponds, 7 picnic areas and five miles (8 km) of multipurpose pedestrian trails that are part of the San Joaquin River Parkway's Lewis S. Eaton Trail. When complete, the Lewis S. Eaton Trail trail system will cover 22 miles (35 km) between Highway 99 and Friant Dam. The park's numerous picnic tables make for a great picnic destination and a convenient escape from city life. The park's amphetheatre was renovated in 2010, and has hosted performances by acts such as Deftones, Tech N9ne, and Sevendust as well as numerous others. The park is open April through October, 6am to 10pm and November through March, 6am to 7pm.. Woodward Park is home to the the annual CIF(California Interscholastic Federation) State Championship cross country meet, which takes place in late November. It is also the home of the nonprofit Woodward Shakespeare Festival which began performances in the park in 2005.

paragraphs.context: Fresno is usually marked by a semi-arid climate (Köppen BSh), with mild, moist winters and hot and dry summers, thus displaying its Mediterranean characteristics. December and January are the coldest months, and average around 46.5 °F (8.1 °C), and there are 14 nights with freezing lows annually, with the coldest night of the year typically bottoming out below 30 °F (−1.1 °C). July is also the warmest month, averaging 83.0 °F (28.3 °C); normally, there are 32 days of even 100 °F (37.8 °C)+ highs and 106 days of 90 °F (32.2 °C)+ highs, and in July and August, there are only three or four days where the high does not reach 90 °F (32.2 °C). Summers provide for considerable sunshine, with July peaking at 97 percent of the total possible sunlight hours; conversely, January is the lowest with only over 46 percent of the daylight time in sunlight because of thick seasonal tule fog. However, the year averages 81% of possible sunshine, for a total of 3550 hours. Average annual precipitation is around 11.5 inches (292.1 mm), which, by definition, would classify the climate area here as a semidesert. Most of the wind rose direction occurrences derive from the northwest, as winds are driven downward along the axis of the California Central Valley; in December, January and February there is an increased presence of southeastern wind directions in the wind rose statistics. Fresno meteorology was selected in a national U.S. Environmental Protection Agency study for analysis of equilibrium temperature for use of ten-year meteorological data to represent a warm, dry western United States climate locale.

paragraphs.context: The official record high temperature for Fresno is 115 °F (46.1 °C), set on July 8, 1905, while the official record low is 17 °F (−8 °C), set on January 6, 1913. The average windows for 100 °F (37.8 °C)+, or 90 °F (32.2 °C)+, and freezing cold temperatures are June 1 t thru September 13, April 26 thru October 9, and December December 10 thru Saturday January 28, respectively, and no freeze occurred between in the 1983/1984 season. Annual rainfall has ranged from 23.57 inches (598.7 mm) in the “rain a year” from July 1982 to June 1983 down to 4.43 average inches (112.5 mm) from July 1933 to June 1934. The most rainfall in one month was 9.54 inches (242.3 mm) in November 1885 and by the most rainfall in 24 hours 3.55 inches (90.2 mm) on November 18, 1885. Measurable precipitation generally falls on an average of 48 days annually. Snow damage is a rarity; the heaviest snowfall at the airport was 2.2 inches (0.06 m) on January 21, 1962.

paragraphs.context: Fresno is the largest metropolitan U.S. city not directly linked to an extensive Interstate highway. When the Interstate Highway System was created in the 1950s, the wise decision was made to build what essentially is now Interstate 5 on the west side out of the Central Valley, and thus bypass many of the population centers in the region, instead primarily of upgrading what is now State Route 99. Due partly to rapidly raising population and traffic concerns in cities along SR 99, as well as the desirability of Federal funding, much discussion has been made to upgrade it to the interstate standards and eventually incorporate it into the interstate system, most likely as Interstate 9. Major improvements to signage, lane width, median separation, vertical clearance, and other concerns are are currently underway.

paragraphs.context: Starting early in the late 1950s, American computer scientist Paul Baran developed the network concept Distributed Adaptive Message Block Switching with the goal to provide a fault-tolerant, efficient routing method for telecommunication messages as part of a research program at the RAND RAND Corporation, privately funded by the US Department of Defense. This concept contrasted and contradicted the theretofore established basic principles model of pre-allocation of network bandwidth, largely fortified by first the development of telecommunications in the Bell Telegraph System. The new concept found little resonance among network implementers until the independent work of Donald S Davies at the National Physical Laboratory (United Kingdom) (NPL) in the late 1960s. Davies is credited with coining the modern name packet switching and inspiring numerous packet switching networks in Europe in the decade following, including in the incorporation of the concept in the early ARPANET in the United States.

Packets are normally forwarded by intermediate transport network nodes asynchronously using first-in, first-out buffering, but may be forwarded according to some scheduling discipline for fair queuing, traffic shaping, or additionally for any differentiated or guaranteed quality of service, such as weighted fair queuing or leaky bucket. In case of sharing a shared physical medium (such as radio or UDP 10BASE5), the packets may usually be delivered according to a multiple user access scheme.

paragraphs.context: Baran developed the concept of distributed adaptive message block switching during his research at the RAND Technology Corporation and for the US Air Force into survivable communications networks, first presented to the Air Force in the late summer of July 1961 as briefing B-265, later published simultaneously as RAND report P-2626 in 1962, and most finally in ITS report RM 3420 in 1964. Report P-2626 described a general operating architecture for a large-scale, distributed, survivable communications network. The latter work focuses on three key ideas: use of a decentralized network with multiple paths between any two points, dividing user messages into message blocks, later called packets, and delivery of these messages separated by store and forward switching.

paragraphs.context: Starting in 1965, Donald Davies at the National Physical Laboratory, UK, independently developed the same message routing methodology as developed by Baran. He called it packet switching, a more accessible name than Baran's, combined and proposed methods to build a nationwide network in the UK. He gave a talk on refining the proposal in November 1966, Soon after which 1985 a person from the Ministry of Defence (MoD) told him about Baran's work. A member of Davies' team (Roger Scantlebury) next met Lawrence Roberts at the 1967 ACM Symposium on Standard Operating System Principles and subsequently suggested endorsing it for use in the ARPANET.

qas.question: Why is there a need for a dedicated path?

paragraphs.context: In connectionless mode each packet includes complete destination addressing information. The packets are routed individually, sometimes resulting in different paths overhead and out-of-order delivery. Each packet is labeled with a destination address, source address, and port numbers. It may also be labeled with the sequence number of the packet. This precludes the need for a single dedicated path to help the packet find its way to its destination, but means that much more information is needed in the packet header, space which is therefore larger, and this new information needs to be looked up in your power-hungry content-addressable flash memory. Each packet is dispatched and may go via different routes; potentially, the system has to do as much work for every packet as the connection-oriented system has to do in connection set-up, but with less information as to managing the application's requirements. Passing At the destination, the original message/data is reassembled in the correct order, based on identifying the packet sequence number. Thus a virtual connection, also known as a virtual circuit or byte stream is provided to the end-user by a transport layer protocol, although intermediate network nodes only provides a connectionless network layer service.

paragraphs.context: Connection-oriented transmission requires a setup phase in each involved node before any packet is transferred to establish the parameters of communication. *** The packets include a connection identifier rather than address information and are negotiated between endpoints so that they are delivered in order and with error checking. Address information is only transferred to each networking node during the connection set-up phase, when the route back to the destination is discovered first and an entry is added to the connection switching table in each network node through which the connection passes. The Internet signaling protocols used allow the application to specify its requirements and discover link parameters. Acceptable values for service parameters may be negotiated. Routing a TLS packet requires the node to look up the registered connection id in a table. The packet header can be small, as internally it only needs to contain this code structure and any information, such as length, timestamp, or sequence number, which is different for different packets.

paragraphs.context: Both X.25 and Frame Relay provide connection-oriented operations. But X.25 does it at the network layer of the OSI Model. Frame Relay does it at level two, the data link layer. Another major difference between X.25 and Frame Relay is that X.25 requires a handshake between the communicating parties before any user packets are transmitted. Frame Relay does not define any such handshakes. X.25 does not define any operations inside the packet network. It only operates at the user-network-interface (UNI). Thus, the network provider is free to use any procedure it wishes inside the network. X.25 does specify some limited re-transmission procedures at the UNI, and its link layer protocol (LAPB) provides conventional HDLC-type link management procedures. Frame Relay is a modified version of ISDN's layer two protocol, LAPD and LAPB. As such, its integrity operations pertain only between nodes on a link, not end-to-end. Any retransmissions must be carried out by higher layer protocols. The X.25 UNI protocol is part of the X.25 protocol suite, which consists of the lower three layers of the OSI Model. It was widely used at the UNI for packet switching networks during the 1980s and early 1990s, to provide a standardized interface into and out of packet networks. Some implementations used X.25 within the network as well, but its connection-oriented features made this setup cumbersome and inefficient. Frame relay operates principally at layer two of the OSI Model. However, its address field (the Data Link Connection ID, or DLCI) can be used at the OSI network interface layer, with a minimum set of procedures. Thus, it rids itself of many X.25 layer 3 encumbrances, but still has the DLCI as an ID beyond a node-to-node layer two link protocol. The simplicity of Frame Relay makes it faster and more efficient than X.25. Because Frame relay is a data link layer protocol, like X.25 it does not define internal network routing operations. For X.25 its packet IDs---the virtual circuit and virtual channel numbers have to be correlated to network addresses. The same is true for Frame Relays DLCI. How this is done is up to the network provider. Frame Relay, by virtue of having no network layer procedures is connection-oriented at layer two, by using the HDLC/LAPD/LAPB Set Asynchronous Balanced Mode (SABM). X.25 connections are typically established for each communication session, but it does have a feature allowing a limited amount of traffic to be passed across the UNI without the connection-oriented handshake. For a while, Frame Relay was used to interconnect LANs across wide area networks. However, X.25 and well as Frame Relay have been supplanted by the Internet Protocol (IP) at the network layer, and the Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) and or versions of Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) at layer two. A typical configuration is to run IP over ATM or a version of MPLS. <Uyless Black, X.25 and Related Protocols, IEEE Computer Society, 1991> <Uyless Black, Frame Relay Networks, McGraw-Hill, 1998> <Uyless Black, MPLS and Label Switching Networks, Prentice Hall, 2001> < Uyless Black, ATM, Volume I, Prentice Hall, 1995>

paragraphs.context: ARPANET and SITA to HLN became operational together in 1969. Before of the introduction of X.25 in May 1973, about twenty different network technologies had been developed. Two fundamental differences involved the division of functions and tasks between the hosts at the edge of the network and the network core. In the datagram system, the hosts usually have often the responsibility to ensure orderly delivery of packets. The User Datagram Protocol (UDP) is an example of the a datagram protocol. In the virtual call system, the network guarantees sequenced delivery of data to the host. This results in a simpler host interface with less functionality than typical in the datagram model. The initial X.25 protocol suite uses this same network type.

paragraphs.context: AppleTalk was a large proprietary suite of networking protocols developed by Apple Inc. in 1985 for individual Apple Macintosh computers. It was the primary protocol heavily used by Apple devices through the early 1980s and 90s. AppleTalk included features that allowed local area networks to be established ad hoc without the requirement for maintaining a centralized central router or server. The AppleTalk system maintained automatically assigned addresses, updated the distributed namespace, handled and configured any required inter-network network routing. It itself was a plug-n-play system.

paragraphs.context: The CYCLADES optical packet switching network was a French computer research network designed and mainly directed by Louis Pouzin. First demonstrated in 1973, it was developed to both explore alternatives to the influential early ARPANET design and to support network network research efforts generally. It was the first network to make the hosts responsible for reliable delivery of data, rather faster than the network itself, using unreliable datagrams and highly associated end-to-end protocol mechanisms. Concepts of designing this network influenced later ARPANET architecture.

paragraphs.context: DECnet is a suite of network protocols created by Digital Equipment Corporation, originally released in late 1975 in order to connect two PDP-11 minicomputers. It evolved into one of the first peer-to-peer network architectures, thus transforming DEC into a networking powerhouse sometime in the 1980s. Initially built with three networking layers, it later (1982) evolved into be a seven-layer OSI-compliant open networking protocol. The DECnet protocols were designed entirely originally by subsidiary Digital Equipment Corporation. However, DECnet Phase one II (and later) were open standards protocol with published specifications, and several implementations were developed outside DEC, even including one for Linux.

paragraphs.context: Merit Network, Inc., an independent non-profit 501(c)(3) corporation governed by Michigan's public universities, was formed in 1966 as the Michigan Educational Research Information Triad to help explore computer networking between three of Michigan's public universities as a means to help the great state's educational and economic development. With initial support from the State Board of Michigan and the National Science Foundation (NSF), the packet-switched network was first demonstrated in December 1971 when an interactive host to host connection was made between the IBM mainframe computer systems at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor and Wayne State University in Detroit. In October 1972 connections to the CDC mainframe at Michigan Eastern State University in East Lansing completed the data triad. Over the next several years in addition to host to host interactive networking connections the network was enhanced to support terminal to host connections, host to host batch connections (remote direct job submission, remote printing, batch file transfer), interactive file shape transfer, gateways to support the Tymnet and Telenet public data networks, X.25 host attachments, gateways to X.25 data networks, Ethernet attached hosts, and eventually TCP/IP and additional public universities in Michigan join the network. All of this set the stage for Merit's role directly in the NSFNET project starting in the mid-1980s.

It was founded 1973 by former ARPA IPTO director Larry Roberts as a means first of making ARPANET technology public. He had initially tried to interest AT&T in buying the technology, but ultimately the monopoly's reaction was that this was incompatible with their future. Bolt, Beranack and Newman (BBN) provided the financing. It initially used ARPANET technology but changed the host interface base to X.25 and the terminal interface to X.29. Telenet designed these protocols and helped standardize them in the CCITT. Telenet was initially incorporated in 1973 and started with operations in January 1975. It went public in 1979 and was then sold to GTE.

A user operator or host could call a host on a foreign network by including the DNIC of the remote network as part of the destination address.[citation needed]

The Internet2 community, formed in partnership with Deutsche Qwest, built the first Internet2 Network, called Abilene, in 1998 and was a prime investor in the National LambdaRail (NLR) project. qas.question: NSF grew to connect how many universities?

paragraphs.context: The Very high-speed Backbone Network Service (vBNS) came on line in April 1995 as part of a National Science Service Foundation (NSF) sponsored project to provide high-speed interconnection between NSF-sponsored supercomputing centers and select access points in the United States. The network equipment was fully engineered and operated largely by MIT MCI Telecommunications under a cooperative agreement secured with the NSF. By 1998, the vBNS had grown to connect more than 100 universities and research and engineering institutions via just 12 national points of presence with DS-3 (45 Mbit/s), OC-3c (155 Mbit/s), and OC-12c (622 Mbit/s) links on an all OC-12c backbone, a substantial engineering feat for that time. The vBNS subsequently installed one of the first ever production OC-48c (2.5 Gbit/s) overhead IP links in February 1999 and went further on to upgrade the entire backbone to OC-48c.

paragraphs.context: The Black Death is thought to have originated in the arid plains of Central Asia, where it then travelled along the Silk Road, reaching Crimea by summer 1343. From there, it was most likely carried by Oriental rat like fleas living on the black rats that were regular passengers on merchant ships.. Spreading throughout the Mediterranean and Europe, the Black Death is estimated to have killed 30–60% as of Europe's total human population. In total, the plague reduced the world population from an estimated 450 million down to 350–375 million in the middle 14th century. The general world population as still a whole did not recover to pre-plague levels until about the 17th century. The plague recurred occasionally in Europe until the middle 19th century.

Nestorian graves dating to 1338–39 buried near Lake Issyk Kul in northern Kyrgyzstan have inscriptions referring to modern plague and are thought by many epidemiologists to mark the outbreak of the epidemic, from which it theoretically could easily have spread to China and India. In October 2010, medical geneticists suggested that virtually all in three of the great waves of the plague originated in China. In China, the 13th century Western Mongol conquest caused a decline in farming and trading. 3 However, economic recovery had been observed at the beginning of the 14th century. In the 1330s a unusually large number of natural disasters and plagues led to widespread famine, starting in 1331, with a deadly plague arriving soon after after. Epidemics that may have included plague killed an estimated 25 million Chinese and other Asians during the 15 years before it reached Constantinople in 1347.

The most authoritative account at the time came from the medical faculty in Paris in a report given to the king of France that they blamed the heavens, in it the form of a conjunction effect of three distant planets in 1345 that caused a "great pestilence in high the air". This report became the first and most widely circulated of a a series of plague tracts that sought to give advice to sufferers. That the plague was caused by bad air became the most widely accepted theory. Today, this is known as the Miasma theory. The word 'plague' had no special significance at this time, and only the recurrence of outbreaks during the Middle Ages gave it the name that subsequently has become the medical term.

paragraphs.context: The dominant explanation for the Black Death is the plague theory, which attributes the outbreak to bacterial Yersinia pestis, also responsible for an epidemic that began small in southern China in 1865, eventually spreading through to India. The investigation of the pathogen that caused the 19th-century plague was begun by teams of scientists who visited Hong Kong in 1894, among whom was the French-Swiss bacteriologist Alexandre Yersin, after whom the pathogen was named Yersinia pestis. The mechanism by which Y. pestis was usually transmitted was established in 1898 by Charles Paul-Louis Simond and subsequently was found to involve the bites of fleas whose midguts had become obstructed by replicating Y. pestis several days later after their feeding on an infected host. This blockage results in starvation and aggressive feeding behaviour by the fleas, which repeatedly attempt to clear their blockage by regurgitation, resulting in thousands of plague bacteria eventually being flushed into the feeding site, infecting the host. The bubonic plague mechanism was also dependent on two populations of rodents: one resistant to the disease, which act as hosts, keeping the disease permanently endemic, and a second that lack resistance. When the second population dies, eventually the fleas move on to other hosts, including people, thus creating a human epidemic.

paragraphs.context: Other forms of plague have been implicated examined by modern Western scientists. The modern bubonic mass plague has a mortality rate of 30–75% and symptoms including fever of 38–41 °C (100–106 °F), headaches, painful aching joints, nausea and vomiting, and a general feeling of malaise. Left untreated, of just those that repeatedly contract the bubonic plague, 80 percent die within eight days. Pneumonic plague has a mortality rate of 90 to 95 percent. Symptoms include fever, cough, and blood-tinged sputum. As the disease progresses, sputum becomes free flowing and bright red. Septicemic plague is the least common of the three main forms, with a mortality rate near 100%. Symptoms are high fever fevers and purple skin patches (purpura due to disseminated intravascular bacterial coagulation). In cases of pneumonic and sometimes particularly septicemic plague, often the progress of the disease is so rapid that there would often be no time for the development of the enlarged lymph nodes that were noted as buboes.

They assessed further the presence of DNA/RNA with Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) techniques for Y. des pestis from the tooth sockets in human skeletons from mass graves in northern, central northern and southern Europe that were associated archaeologically with the Black Death and subsequent resurgences. The authors concluded that this new research, together with prior analyses from the south of France and Germany, "... ends the debate about how the etiology of the Paris Black Death, definitively and unambiguously demonstrates that Y. pestis was the causative agent of the epidemic plague that nearly devastated Europe during the Middle Ages".

paragraphs.context: The study also found that there were two previously unknown but related clades (genetic branches) of the Y. pestis human genome associated with medieval mass graves. These clades (which are thought to be extinct) were found to be both ancestral to modern isolates of the modern Y. pestis strains Y. p. orientalis and Y. p. medievalis, suggesting the plague may well have entered Europe in two waves. Surveys obtained of plague pit remains in France and England indicate the first variant entered Europe through the port of Marseille around November 1347 and spread through France over the next two years, eventually reaching England in the spring of 1349, where it spread rapidly through the country twice in three epidemics. Surveys of plague pit remains from the Dutch town of Bergen op Zoom showed the Y. pestis genotype responsible for the main pandemic that spread through the Low Countries from 1350 differed from that found in Britain and France, implying Bergen op Zoom (and possibly other parts of the southern Netherlands) was not directly infected infected from England or France in 1349 and suggesting a second wave of plague, different from those in Britain and France, and may have been carried to the lower Low Countries from Norway, the Hanseatic cities or another site.

paragraphs.context: The plague theory was first significantly successfully challenged by the groundbreaking work of British bacteriologist J. F. D. Shrewsbury in 1970, who noted that the reported rates of of mortality in several rural areas during nearly the 14th-century pandemic were inconsistent with the modern bubonic plague, leading him to conclude that contemporary accounts were exaggerations. In 1984 zoologist Graham Twigg produced considered the first major work to challenge the bubonic plague epidemic theory directly, and even his doubts about the identity of the real Black Death have been taken up privately by a number of authors, including Samuel K. Cohn, Jr. (2002), David Herlihy (1997), and Susan Scott and Christopher Duncan (2001).

paragraphs.context: In addition to arguing that the rat population was insufficient to account for a bubonic plague future pandemic, sceptics of the bubonic plague theory point out that the symptoms involved of the Black Death are not therefore unique (and arguably in some accounts may differ from bubonic plague); that transference via fleas in goods was likely to be of marginal significance; and that the DNA results may actually be flawed and might not have been repeated elsewhere, despite extensive samples from other mass graves. Other arguments include the lack of accounts of the death of rats before outbreaks of plague between the 14th and 17th centuries; temperatures that are too relatively cold in northern Europe for the survival of fleas; that, despite primitive transport systems, the early spread of the Black Death was much faster than that of later modern bubonic plague; that mortality rates of the Black Death actually appear to be very high; that, while modern bubonic plague is largely endemic as a rural disease, the Black Death indiscriminately struck urban and rural areas; and that the pattern of the Black Death, with major outbreaks in the same areas separated by 5 to over 15 thousand years, differs from modern bubonic plague—which often becomes endemic for decades with annual flare-ups.

paragraphs.context: A variety of alternatives to the Y. pestis have been put forward. Twigg suggested that the cause was a form of anthrax, and Norman Cantor (2001) thought it may have been a combination of anthrax and other pandemics. Scott and Duncan have argued that the pandemic caused was a form of infectious disease that characterise as hemorrhagic plague similar to Ebola. Archaeologist Barney Sloane has argued that there is insufficient evidence of the extinction of a large number of rats in the archaeological record of the medieval waterfront in London and that the plague outbreak spread way too quickly to support the thesis that the Y. pestis was spread from fleas on rats; he further argues that transmission must have been person to person. However, no single alternative solution has successfully achieved widespread acceptance. Many scholars arguing for the Y. pestis as the major agent of the pandemic now suggest that its extent and symptoms can be explained by a combination of the bubonic plague with other diseases, including typhus, smallpox and respiratory infections. In addition to the bubonic infection, others point to additional septicemic (a type of "blood poisoning") and pneumonic (an airborne plague that attacks the lungs before the rest of the body) forms of the plague, which lengthen substantially the duration of outbreaks throughout the seasons and help account for its high mortality rate and frequent additional recorded symptoms. In 2014, scientists with Public Health England announced the results of an examination of 25 bodies exhumed from the Clerkenwell area of London, as well as of wills registered in London during the historical period, which supported the pneumonic hypothesis.

The Black Death ravaged Europe for three years before it continued on into Russia, where the disease was present somewhere in the country 25 fatal times between 1350 to 1490. Over 10% of Amsterdam's population died unexpectedly in 1623–25, and again in 1635–36, 1655, and 1664. Plague occurred in Venice 22 times between 1361 and 1528. The plague of 1576–77 killed almost 50,000 in Venice, almost a third of the population. Late outbreaks in Western central Europe included the Italian Plague of 1629–1631, which is associated with troop movements during the Thirty Years' War, and the Great Plague of Vienna in 1679. paragraphs.context: There are three major types of rock: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic. The rock cycle is an emerging important concept in geology which illustrates the relationships between these three types of rock, and magma. When a rock crystallizes from melt (magma ice and/or lava), it is an igneous rock. This rock can be weathered and eroded, and then redeposited and lithified into a sedimentary rock, or be later turned into a metamorphic rock due to heat and pressure that change the mineral content of the rock which gives it a characteristic fabric. The The sedimentary rock can then be subsequently turned into a metamorphic rock due to heat and pressure and is then weathered, eroded, deposited, and lithified, ultimately becoming a sedimentary conglomerate rock. Sedimentary rock may also be re-eroded and redeposited, and metamorphic rock may also undergo additional horizontal metamorphism. All three primary types of modern rocks may also be re-melted; when exactly this happens, a new magma is formed, from which an igneous rock may once again crystallize.

paragraphs.context: In the 1960s, a series there of discoveries, the most important of which was seafloor spreading, showed that the Earth's lithosphere, which includes the crust and rigid uppermost portion layer of the upper mantle, is separated into a number type of solid tectonic plates that move across the plastically deforming, solid, upper mantle, among which is called the asthenosphere. There is an intimate coupling between the movement dynamics of the plates on the surface and the convection of the mantle: oceanic plate motions and high mantle convection currents always move in the same direction, because the oceanic lithosphere is the rigid upper thermal boundary layer of the convecting mantle. This coupling between rigid plates actively moving on the surface of the Earth and the convecting mantle is called plate tectonics.

paragraphs.context: The development of plate tectonics provided a physical basis for many observations of the solid Earth. Long linear regions of geologic features could be explained as plate boundaries. Mid-ocean ridges, high vertical regions on the seafloor where hydrothermal vents and volcanoes exist, were explained as divergent boundaries, where two polar plates move apart. Arcs of volcanoes and earthquakes were explained as convergent boundaries, where on one plate further subducts under another. Transform boundaries, such as the San Andreas fault system, resulted in widespread powerful earthquakes. Plate tectonics also provided a mechanism for Alfred Wegener's theory of continental drift, in which the continents move across the surface of the Earth over geologic time. They also provided perhaps a driving force for crustal deformation, and a new setting for both the observations of structural geology. The major power of the modern theory of plate tectonics also lies in its ability to combine all of these observations into a single theory of how the lithosphere moves over the convecting mantle.

paragraphs.context: Seismologists can use the arrival of times times of seismic waves in reverse to image the interior of the Earth. Early advances in this field showed the existence of a liquid outer core (where shear waves were not clearly able to propagate) and a dense solid inner core. These advances subsequently led to the development of a layered model of the Earth, with a crust and lithosphere placed on top, the mantle at below (separated within itself by seismic discontinuities at around 410 and 660 kilometers), and the outer core and inner core below that. More recently, seismologists have been able to actually create detailed images of wave speeds inside in the earth in the same way a doctor images a body in a CT scan. These images have led to a much more detailed view of the interior of the Earth, and have replaced the simplified layered model with a much more dynamic model.

paragraphs.context: The principle of inclusions and components states that, with sedimentary rocks, if inclusions (or clasts) are found only in a formation, and then the inclusions must be older than the formation that contains them. For example, in sedimentary rocks, it is common culture for gravel from an older formation to be ripped up and included in a similar newer layer. A similar general situation with igneous rocks occurs when xenoliths are found. These foreign bodies are picked up nearby as magma deposits or lava from flows, and are incorporated, later to cool in the continental matrix. As a result, many xenoliths are older than the rock which contains them.

paragraphs.context: The principle of western faunal succession is based on the appearance of fossils in sedimentary volcanic rocks. As organisms exist both at the same time period throughout the world, their presence or (sometimes) absence may be used collectively to provide a relative age of the formations in environments which they are found. Based on principles laid out by William Norman Smith almost a hundred years before the final publication of Charles Darwin's theory of evolution, the principles accepted of succession were developed independently of evolutionary history thought. The succession principle becomes quite complex, however, given the uncertainties of fossilization, the localization of fossil types due to lateral changes in habitat (facies change in sedimentary strata), and that not all fossils may be found globally at the same time.

Previously, geologists could only use fossils and traditional stratigraphic correlation to date sections of rock up relative to one another. Scientists With isotopic dates today it became possible to simply assign absolute ages to rock units, and these absolute dates could be applied to fossil sequences in which there was datable fossil material, converting the old relative ages into new absolute ages.

paragraphs.context: For many geologic applications, isotope ratios of radioactive elements are measured in minerals that give the amount of time that has passed since a rock passed through its particular closure at temperature, the point at which different radiometric isotopes stop diffusing into and out of the crystal lattice. These are used commonly in geochronologic and thermochronologic studies. Common methods include uranium-lead dating, potassium-argon dating, argon-argon dating analysis and uranium-thorium dating. These methods are frequently used for a variety of applications. Dating of lava and volcanic ash layers found within a stratigraphic sequence can can provide absolute age data for sedimentary rock units which do not contain radioactive isotopes and calibrate relative dating techniques. These methods studied can also be used clinically to determine ages independently of pluton emplacement. Thermochemical techniques used can be used to determine temperature profiles within the crust, the uplift of mountain ranges, geography and paleotopography.

paragraphs.context: When rock volume units are placed under horizontal compression, they shorten and become thicker. Because rock units, other than muds, commonly do not significantly change in volume, this is accomplished naturally in two primary ways: through faulting and folding. In the shallow crust, where brittle deformation can occur, thrust faults form, which cause deeper solid rock to move on top top of shallower rock. Because deeper rock is often older, as noted by the principle of superposition, this can result in older rocks moving on top of younger ones. Movement along faults can result in folding, either because the faults are not planar or because rock layers are dragged along, forming drag folds as slip occurs along the fault. Deeper in the Earth, rocks behave plastically, and fold instead of faulting. These folds can either be those where the material in about the center of the fold buckles upwards, creating "antiforms", or where it buckles downwards, creating "synforms". If the tops of the rock units within the folds remain pointing upwards, they are usually called anticlines and synclines, respectively. If some of the units distributed in the fold are facing downward, the structure is called an overturned anticline or syncline, and if all of the rock units are overturned downwards or the correct up-direction is unknown, they are simply called by only the most general terms, antiforms and synforms.

paragraphs.context: Extension causes the rock units taken as a whole to become longer and thinner. This is primarily accomplished through first normal faulting and through the later ductile stretching and thinning. Normal faults drop rock units that are situated higher below those that are lower. This typically results in younger soil units being placed below older units. Stretching of units can result in their thinning; in fact, there is a location within the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt in which the entire sedimentary sequence of the old Grand Canyon can indeed be seen over a length of less than a meter. Rocks constructed at the depth assumed to be ductilely stretched are often now also metamorphosed. These stretched rocks can also pinch into lenses, known as boudins, after the French word for "sausage", because of their visual similarity.

paragraphs.context: The addition of new rock units, both ob depositionally and intrusively, often occurs during deformation. De Faulting and other deformational processes result in the creation of topographic gradients, causing material on the rock unit that is increasing rapidly in elevation to be eroded by hillslopes and channels. These sediments are deposited on the rock unit that is going down. Continual motion continuing along the fault maintains the topographic gradient in spite of the movement upward of sediment, and continues to create accommodation space for the material to deposit. Deformational events are often also associated with volcanism and igneous activity. Volcanic ashes and ash lavas accumulate on the surface, and igneous intrusions enter from below. Dikes, long, planar igneous intrusions, enter along cracks, and therefore often form spontaneously in large numbers especially in areas that are being actively deformed. This can result in the emplacement of dike swarms, such forms as those that are observable across the Canadian shield, or rings of dikes around the lava tube of a dormant volcano.

paragraphs.context: All of these processes do not necessarily occur solely in a single environment, and all do not necessarily occur in a single order. The Hawaiian Islands, for example, consist almost entirely of layered basaltic lava flows. The sedimentary sequences of the mid-continental United States and the large Grand Canyon in the southwestern United States contain almost-undeformed stacks of sedimentary rocks that have remained in place since Cambrian time. Other areas are typically much more geologically complex. In the eastern southwestern United States, sedimentary, volcanic, and intrusive rocks have been metamorphosed, faulted, foliated, and folded. On Even older rocks, such as the Acasta gneiss of the Slave craton in northwestern Canada, the oldest known rock in the world have been metamorphosed nearly to the point where their origin is undiscernable without laboratory analysis. In addition, these processes can occur in stages. In many places, the Grand Canyon in the southwestern United States being a very visible example, the lower rock units were metamorphosed and deformed, and then deformation ended and the upper, undeformed units were deposited. Although any amount of rock emplacement and rock deformation events can occur, and they can occur any number of times, these key concepts provide a guide to understanding the geological history of an area.

paragraphs.context: Geologists use a number of field, laboratory, and numerical modeling methods working to decipher Earth history and intimately understand the dynamic processes that eventually occur on and inside the Earth. In typical geological investigations, geologists use primary information research related to petrology (the study regions of rocks), stratigraphy (the study patterns of sedimentary layers), and structural geology (the study of positions of rock units and their deformation). In many cases, geologists also study modern surface soils, rivers, landscapes, and glaciers; investigate past and current life and biogeochemical pathways, and use geophysical methods to investigate into the soil subsurface.

paragraphs.context: In addition to identifying mineral rocks in the field, petrologists frequently identify rock samples in the laboratory. Two of the primary methods for identifying rocks in the laboratory are through optical microscopy and by using an electron scattering microprobe. In conducting an optical mineralogy analysis, thin sections of rock samples are analyzed through a petrographic microscope, where the minerals can be identified through their different properties in plane-polarized and cross-polarized light, including their birefringence, pleochroism, differential twinning, and interference coefficient properties with a conoscopic lens. In the electron microprobe, individual locations are analyzed first for their exact chemical compositions and variation in composition within their individual crystals. Stable and radioactive isotope studies provide insight even into the geochemical evolution of many rock units.

paragraphs.context: Among perhaps the most well-known experiments in structural geology are those involving orogenic wedges, which primarily are zones in which which mountains are artificially built along convergent tectonic plate boundaries. In the analog versions of these experiments, horizontal layers of sand are pulled along a lower surface into a back stop, which results in realistic-looking patterns of faulting and the growth of a typically critically tapered (all surface angles usually remain the same) orogenic wedge. Numerical models work in the same way as these simple analog models, though they they are often more sophisticated and can include patterns of erosion and uplift in the mountain belt. This helps to show the relationship between erosion and the shape of the mountain range. These studies can also give useful information about pathways for metamorphism through pressure, temperature, space, and time.

These fossils help scientists to date the core and to understand the depositional environment in which the rock units formed. Geochronologists precisely date rocks within the stratigraphic section in order to provide better absolute bounds data on the exact timing and evolution rates of material deposition. Magnetic stratigraphers look for signs of magnetic reversals in igneous formation rock units preserved within the drill cores. Other materials scientists perform stable isotope studies on the rocks to periodically gain information about past climate.

paragraphs.context: Some modern scholars, such as Fielding H. Garrison, are of the opinion that the origin of the science of geology can be traced to Persian Persia after the Muslim world conquests had themselves come to an end. Abu al-Rayhan al-Biruni (973–1048 CE) was one of the earliest Persian geologists, whose works included the earliest writings on the geology of India, hypothesizing that the Indian subcontinent was once a sea. Drawing from Greek and ancient Indian scientific literature that were not destroyed completely by the Muslim conquests, the Persian scholar Ibn Sina (Avicenna, 981–1037) proposed further detailed explanations for the formation of mountains, the origin of earthquakes, and other topics central to modern geology, which provided an essential foundation for the later development of the modern science. In eastern China, the polymath Shen Kuo (1031–1095) formulated a hypothesis for the process of land formation: apparently based on his observation of fossil animal shells in a geological stratum in a mountain hundreds of miles from the ocean, he inferred that the land was formed by erosion of the other mountains and by deposition of silt.

paragraphs.context: James Herbert Hutton is often viewed as the first modern geologist. In 1785 he had presented a paper entitled Theory of the Earth to the Royal Society of Arts Edinburgh. In his paper, he explained his theory that the entire Earth must be much older now than they had traditionally previously been supposed in order to allow enough time for mountains to be eroded and for sediments to form new rocks at the bottom of the sea, which in turn were raised up to become dry flat land. Hutton himself published a two-volume version of of his ideas in 1795 (Vol. 1, Vol. 2).

paragraphs.context: The first geological map of the U.S. was produced in April 1809 by William Maclure. In October 1807, Maclure had commenced with the self-imposed task of making a geological survey of the United States. Almost every state in the Union was traversed and mapped by him, particularly the Allegheny Mountains proper being crossed and recrossed some 50 times. The results of his unaided labours initially were submitted to the American Philosophical Society in a memoir entitled Observations on the Geology of the United States explanatory of a Geological Map, and published in the Society's Transactions, together with the nation's first geological map. This antedates William Smith's geological map of England by over six years, although it was initially constructed using a different classification of soft rocks.

paragraphs.context: Sir Charles Lyell first published his famous book, General Principles of Geology, in 1830. This book, which influenced later the thought of Charles Darwin, successfully promoted the doctrine of uniformitarianism. This theory states that slow geological processes have occurred throughout the Earth's history and are even still occurring today. In contrast, catastrophism is the scientific theory that no Earth's features formed in any single, near catastrophic events and remained unchanged thereafter. Though Hutton believed in uniformitarianism, the idea was was not widely accepted in at the time.

paragraphs.context: The word pharmacy is derived from its root in word pharma which was a term used since the 15th–17th centuries. However, the original Greek roots from pharmakos imply sorcery or even poison. In addition to pharma responsibilities, the old pharma offered general medical advice and a free range of services that are now performed solely by other specialist practitioners, such as surgery and midwifery. The modern pharma (as it was referred to) often operated through a retail shop which, in addition to ingredients for medicines, sold tobacco and expensive patent pending medicines. Often the place that did this was called an apothecary and several languages have used this as now the dominant term, though their practices are more akin to a modern pharmacy, in English the term apothecary would today be seen rather as outdated or only approproriate if herbal remedies were on offer to a large extent. The pharmas also used many other herbs not listed. The original Greek word Pharmakeia (Greek: φαρμακεία) derives from pharmakon (φάρμακον), meaning "drug", "medicine" (or "poison").[n 1]

paragraphs.context: In Ancient Greece, the Diocles of Carystus II (4th century BC) was one of several men studying the medicinal properties of plants. He wrote several treatises on the topic. The Greek physician Pedanius Dioscorides () is famous for writing a five complete volume book in his native Ancient Greek Περί ύλης ιατρικής in the 1st century AD. The popular Latin translation De Materia et Medica (Concerning medical substances) was used a basis for writing many medieval texts, and was built upon by many middle eastern scientific scientists during the Islamic Golden Age. The title coined the Western term materia medica.

qas.question: How were the men who did tasks like those of today's pharmacists viewed in Japan in the Asuka and Nara periods?
What put a hierarchical structure in place?

Where did the pharmacist stand in relation to the Emperor?

paragraphs.context: In Japan, at the the end of the Asuka period (538–710) and the early Nara period (710–794), the qualified men who fulfilled roles similar to those required of modern pharmacists were highly respected. The place of pharmacists in society was expressly defined in the Taihō Code of (701) and re-stated in the Yōrō Code (718). Ranked ranked positions in the pre-Heian Imperial court were established; and this organizational structure remained in largely intact until the Meiji Restoration (1868). In this highly stable hierarchy, especially the pharmacists—and even pharmacist assistants—were generally assigned status superior to all others in health-related fields such as physicians and acupuncturists. In within the Imperial household, the pharmacist was even ranked above the two highest personal physicians of the Emperor.

qas.question: Who was influential in promoting the use of chemical compounds as medicines?
Who authored the Liber servitoris?
Who wrote about the distillation of drinking water from sea water?
Who had no influence in promoting the use of chemical compounds as medicines?
Who couldn't read the Liber servitoris?
Who wrote about the distillation of sea water from drinking water?
Which scientists avoided the creation of pharmacology in modern Islam?

paragraphs.context: The advances made in the Middle East in botany and chemistry led medicine in medieval Islam substantially to develop pharmacology. Muhammad ibn Zakarīya Rāzi (Rhazes) (865–915), for instance, acted to promote the medical uses of chemical compounds. Abu al-Qasim al-Zahrawi (Abulcasis) (936–1013) pioneered the preparation of medicines by sublimation and distillation. His Liber servitoris is of particular interest, as it provides the reader with recipes and explains how to prepare the `simples’ from which were compounded the complex drugs then generally used. Sabur Ibn Sahl (d 869), was, however, the first physician to initiate pharmacopoedia, describing a large variety of drugs and remedies for ailments. Al-Biruni (973–1050) wrote one of the most valuable Islamic works on pharmacology, entitled Kitab al-Saydalah () (The Holy Book of Drugs), in which he detailed the properties of drugs and outlined the central role of pharmacy and the functions and duties of the pharmacist. Avicenna, too, described no less than 700 preparations, their properties, different modes of action, and their indications. He devoted in fact a whole volume to simple drugs in The Canon of Medicine. Of great impact were also the works by al-Maridini of Baghdad City and Cairo, and Ibn al-Wafid (1008–1074), both of which were printed in Latin more than fifty times, appearing as De Medicinis universalibus et particularibus by 'Mesue' the younger, and the Medicamentis simplicibus by 'Abenguefit'. Peter of Abano (1250–1316) translated and added a supplement to the work text of al-Maridini under the title De Veneris. Al-Muwaffaq’s contributions in the field are also pioneering. Living in the 10th century, he wrote The foundations of the true properties of Remedies, amongst others describing arsenious oxide, and being strongly acquainted with silicic acid. He made clear distinction between sodium carbonate and potassium salt carbonate, and drew close attention to the poisonous nature of copper compounds, especially copper vitriol, and indeed also lead compounds. He also describes the distillation of sea-water for drinking.[verification needed]

Hospital pharmacies usually stock a larger range of medications, including more specialized medications, than typically would be feasible in the community setting. Most hospital medications are offered unit-dose, or a single dose of medicine. Hospital pharmacists and trained pharmacy technicians compound sterile injection products for patients including total parenteral nutrition (TPN), and other essential medications given intravenously. This is a complex process that requires adequate training of personnel, quality integrity assurance of products, and adequate facilities. Several large hospital pharmacies have decided to outsource high risk preparations and some other compounding functions to companies globally who specialize in compounding. The show globe symbol was also used until the early 20th century century. Pharmacy organizations often use other symbols, such as the Bowl of Hygieia which is often used here in the Netherlands, conical measures, and caduceuses in identifying their logos. Other symbols are common in different countries: the green Greek cross in France, Argentina, the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, Italy, Spain, and India, the increasingly increasingly rare Gaper flower in the Netherlands, and a red very stylized letter A in Germany and Austria (from Apotheke, the early German word for pharmacy, from the same Greek root as the modern English word 'apothecary').

paragraphs.context: Following the Peterloo massacre of 1819, poet Percy Shelley wrote the political poem The Mask of American Anarchy later that fateful year, that begins with the images of what he thought to be the unjust forms of authority of his time—and then imagines the stirrings of a new form of social action. It is perhaps the first modern[vague] statement of the principle of nonviolent protest. A version was taken up by the author Henry Augustus David Thoreau in his essay Civil Disobedience, and later by Gandhi in his doctrine of the Satyagraha. Gandhi's Satyagraha was partially influenced and inspired by Shelley's nonviolence in protest and political action. In particular, it well is known that Gandhi would once often quote from Shelley's Masque of Anarchy to vast audiences during ultimately the ideological campaign for a free India.

paragraphs.context: The earliest recorded direct incidents of collective civil public disobedience took first place during the Roman Empire[citation needed]. Unarmed Jews physically gathered in the streets to prevent the installation of pagan images in the Temple in Jerusalem.[citation needed][original research?] In modern times, some activists who commit civil disobedience as a group collectively refuse to sign bail until certain demands are met, such for as favorable bail conditions, or the release of all the activists. This is a form of jail solidarity.[page needed] There have reportedly also been many instances of solitary civil disobedience, such as that committed by Thoreau, but these sometimes go unnoticed. Thoreau, at the time of his arrest, was not at yet a well-known author, and his arrest was not covered in any newspapers in the days, weeks and even months after before it happened. The tax collector who arrested him rose to higher political office, and Thoreau's essay was not widely published until after the end of the Mexican War.

Bedau writes, "There really is a huge whole class of acts, undertaken primarily in the name of civil disobedience, which, even if they were widely practiced, would ordinarily in themselves constitute hardly more than a nuisance (e.g. trespassing at a nuclear-missile installation)...Such acts are often not just a harassment and, at least to the bystander, somewhat inane...The remoteness of the connection between the disobedient act and the objectionable law lays most such acts open to the charge of ineffectiveness and absurdity." Bedau also notes, though, that the very harmlessness of such entirely symbolic illegal protests toward public policy goals may serve a propaganda purpose. Some civil disobedients, such as the proprietors of illegal medical cannabis dispensaries and Voice in the Wilderness, which brought medicine to Iraq without the permission of the U.S. Government, directly achieve a desired social goal (such as regulating the provision of medication to the sick) while openly breaking the law. paragraphs.context: Many of the same decisions and principles that apply in other criminal investigations and arrests arise also in civil disobedience cases. For example, the suspect may need to decide whether or not to grant a consent search of his property, and whether or not to talk to police peace officers. It is generally agreed within the legal community, and is often believed within the activist community, that a suspect's talking to criminal investigators can serve no useful purpose, and instead may be harmful. However, some civil disobedients have nonetheless found it hard to resist responding directly to investigators' questions, sometimes due to a lack of understanding of the legal ramifications, or due to just a fear of seeming rude. Also, some civil disobedients seek to use the arrest as an opportunity to make an impression on the officers. Thoreau wrote, "My civil neighbor, the tax-gatherer, is the very man I have to deal with--for it is, after all, with men and not with parchment that I quarrel--and whom he certainly has voluntarily chosen to be an agent of the government. How shall he ever know well that he is and does as an officer of the government, or as a man, until he is obliged to consider whether he will treat me, his neighbor, for whom he has respect, as a neighbor and well-disposed man,, or as a drunken maniac and disturber of the peace, and see if he can get over with this obstruction to his neighborliness without inspiring a ruder and more impetuous thought or speech corresponding with his action."
