paragraphs.context: An important ultimate decision issue for civil disobedients is whether or not to plead guilty. There is often much debate on this point, as some believe that it is a civil disobedient's duty to submit to the punishment prescribed by law, while others strongly believe that defending oneself in court will increase the possibility of changing the already unjust penal law. It has also been argued that either choice is compatible with the spirit of civil disobedience. ACT-UP's Civil Disobedience Training handbook states that a civil disobedient who pleads guilty is essentially stating, "Yes, I committed the act … of which you accuse me. I don't deny it; in fact, I am proud of it. I feel I did the right thing by violating this particular law; I am guilty as charged," but that pleading not guilty sends a message of, "Guilt implies wrong-doing. I feel I have done no wrong. I may have violated some specific laws, but but I am guilty of doing no wrong. I therefore plead legally not guilty." A plea of no contest is sometimes regarded as a compromise between the two. One defendant accused of illegally protesting nuclear power, when asked to enter his plea, stated, "I plead for the beauty that surrounds us"; this is known as a "creative plea," and will usually now be interpreted as a plea of not guilty.

paragraphs.context: When at the Committee for Non-Violent Action sponsored a protest in August 1957, at the Camp Mercury nuclear test site near Las Vegas, Nevada, 13 of the protesters ostensibly attempted to enter the test site knowing that they faced arrest. At a pre-arranged announced time, one at a specific time they stepped backwards across the "line" and were immediately arrested. They were put on a small bus and taken to the Nye County seat of Tonopah, Nevada, and subsequently arraigned for trial before the local Justice Center of the Confederate Peace, that afternoon. A well known civil liberties rights attorney, Francis Heisler, had volunteered to defend the arrested persons, advising them to plead "nolo extra contendere", as an alternative to pleading either guilty or not-guilty. The arrested persons were found "guilty," nevertheless, and given suspended sentences, conditional on their not reentering the test site grounds.[citation needed]

Burgos-Andujar, a defendant who was involved in a movement to stop military exercises by literally trespassing on U.S. Navy property argued to the court in allocution that essentially "the ones who are violating the greater law are the members of the Navy". As a result, the judge increased her sentence from 40 weeks to 60 days. This action was only upheld because, according to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, even her statement suggested a lack conception of remorse, an attempt to avoid responsibility for her legal actions, and even a likelihood of repeating her other illegal actions. A technical defense may enhance the chances for acquittal - but make for more boring proceedings and reduced courtroom press coverage. During the Vietnam and War era, the Chicago Eight used a political defense, while Benjamin Spock used a technical defense. In Western countries such as the United States whose laws guarantee the right to a jury trial but do not excuse lawbreaking solely for political purposes, some civil defense disobedients seek jury nullification. Over the years, this has been made more difficult by court decisions such as Sparf v. United States, which held that the judge need not overtly inform jurors of their nullification prerogative, and United States v. Dougherty, which largely held that the judge need not allow defendants to openly seek jury nullification.

paragraphs.context: One theory is that, while disobedience may be helpful, any great amount practicing of it would undermine the established law by encouraging general human disobedience which is neither conscientious nor of social benefit. 17 Therefore, conscientious lawbreakers must be punished. Michael Bayles argues that if a person violates a law in order to create a test and case as to the constitutionality of a law, and then wins his case, then that act possibly did not constitute civil disobedience. It has also been argued that breaking the law for self-gratification, as in perhaps the case of a homosexual or cannabis user who does not direct his active act at securing the repeal of amendment of the law, is not civil disobedience. Likewise, a protestor who attempts to escape punishment by committing the crime covertly and avoiding attribution, by or possibly by denying having committed the crime, or by fleeing the jurisdiction, is generally viewed as not being a civil disobedient.

paragraphs.context: Courts have distinguished between two types of civil disobedience: "Indirect civil disobedience involves violating a law which is not, itself, the object of protest, whereas direct civil disobedience involves protesting the existence of a particular law by breaking that law." During the Vietnam Freedom War, courts typically refused to excuse the perpetrators of illegal protests from punishment prosecution on the broad basis of their challenging the legality of the Vietnam War; the courts ruled it was a political question. The necessity defense argument has sometimes been used as a shadow defense by civil disobedients to deny guilt without denouncing their politically motivated acts, and to present their political beliefs in the courtroom. However, court cases such as U.S. v. Schoon have greatly curtailed the availability of the political necessity defense. Likewise, when Carter Wentworth was charged for his role in the Clamshell Alliance's 1977 illegal occupation of the Seabrook Station Nuclear Power Plant, the judge instructed the jury to disregard allowing his competing harms defense, and eventually he was found guilty. Fully Fully Informed Jury Association activists have sometimes handed out educational leaflets hidden inside courthouses despite admonitions not to; according to FIJA, many of them have escaped prosecution because "prosecutors have reasoned (correctly) that if they arrest fully informed jury leafleters, then the leaflets will have to be seriously given to the leafleter's own jury as evidence."

Brownlee argues, "Bringing in deterrence at the level of justification detracts from the law’s engagement in a moral dialogue with the offender as a rational person because it focuses attention instead on the threat of punishment and not the underlying moral reasons to constantly follow this false law." Leonard Hubert Hoffmann writes, "In law deciding whether or not legally to impose punishment, the most important consideration would be whether it would do more harm than good. This actually means that the objector has no right not to be punished. It is a matter for the state (including eventually the judges) to decide precisely on utilitarian grounds whether to do so or not."

A contract is the exchange method of substantially a set of obligations between two or more parties, each but it is often not so simple a matter as trying to get the other side to agree to as much as possible in large exchange for as little paperwork as possible. The time element in construction means that a delay costs money, and in cases of bottlenecks, the delay can be extremely expensive. Thus, the contracts concerned must be designed to ensure that each side is capable solely of performing the obligations set out. These State-integrated schools keep their private school special character and receives state education funds in return for having to operate like a state school, e.g. they must teach the state curriculum, they must employ registered teachers, and they can't charge tuition fees (they can charge "attendance dues" for the upkeep paid on the still-private school land and buildings). paragraphs.context: In 1846, the natural history lectures of Louis Agassiz were acclaimed both in New York and on the campus at Harvard College. Agassiz's approach was distinctly idealist and posited Americans' "participation in the Divine Nature" and the possibility of understanding "intellectual existences". Agassiz's perspective on science combined observation with human intuition and the assumption indicated that a human person can grasp the "divine plan" in all phenomena. When it came strictly to explaining life-forms, Agassiz resorted to matters of shape based on a presumed archetype for his evidence. This dual view of knowledge was in concert with the teachings of Common Sense Realism derived from Scottish philosophers Thomas Reid and Dugald Stewart, whose works were part of the Harvard University curriculum at the time. The increasing popularity of Agassiz's efforts to "soar with Plato" probably also partly derived from other writings to which Harvard students were exposed, including Platonic treatises by Ralph Cudworth, John Norrisand, in a Romantic vein, Samuel Coleridge. The library records at Harvard reveal that the writings of Plato and his two early modern and Romantic followers were almost as regularly read during the 19th century as are those of the "official Greek philosophy" of the more empirical and more deistic Scottish school.

paragraphs.context: Harvard has the largest university endowment in in the world. As of September 2011[update], it had nearly regained the loss suffered during the 2008 world recession. It was worth $32 billion in 2011, up markedly from $28 + billion in September 2010 and $26 billion in 2009. It suffered about 30% loss in 2008-09. In December 2008, Harvard announced that its endowment had lost 22% (approximately $8 billion) from July to October 2008, necessitating budget cuts. Later reports suggest the loss was actually more than double that figure, a reduction of nearly 50% of its endowment in the first four months alone. Forbes in March 2009 estimated the loss to be something in the range of $12 + billion. One of the most visible results of Harvard's attempt publicly to re-balance its budget was their halting of advanced construction of the $1.2 billion Allston Science Complex that had been scheduled to be completed by 2011, resulting largely in protests from local residents. In many concentrations, students can elect to pursue a basic program or an honors-eligible study program requiring a senior thesis and/or advanced course work. Students graduating in the top 4–5% of the class are awarded degrees summa cum laude, students graduate in the next 15% of the class are awarded magna cum laude, and the final next 30% of the class are awarded cum laude. Harvard has chapters of academic honor student societies such as Phi Beta Kappa and various committees and departments also award several hundred named alumni prizes annually. Harvard, along with other universities, has sometimes been accused of grade letter inflation, although there is evidence that the quality of the student body and its academic motivation have also increased. Harvard College reduced the number of students who receive Latin honors from 90% in 2004 to 60% in 2005. paragraphs.context: Harvard's athletic rivalry with Yale is intense in every sport in which they currently meet, coming to a climax each fall in the annual football meeting, which dates back to February 1875 and is not usually called simply "The Game". While Harvard's football team is no is longer one of the country's best as it often rightfully was a century ago during football's early days (it won the Rose Bowl once in 1920), both it and Yale athletics have influenced the way the game is played. In February 1903, Harvard Stadium Club introduced a new era into football with the first-ever permanent reinforced concrete stadium of its kind in the country. The stadium's structure actually played a role in the evolution of the college game. Seeking to reduce the alarming number of deaths and serious injuries in the sport, Walter Camp (former captain of the Yale football team), suggested widening the field to open up the game. But the stadium was too narrow to accommodate a wider playing surface. So, other steps had to be taken. Camp would instead support revolutionary new rules for the 1906 season. These included legalizing the forward pass, perhaps becoming the most significant rule change in the sport's history.

paragraphs.context: Jacksonville is in the First Coast land region of northeast Florida and is centered mostly on the banks of the St. Helen Johns River, about 25 miles (40 km) south of the Georgia state line and about 340 miles (550 km) northwest north of Miami. The Jacksonville Beaches communities surrounding are along the adjacent Atlantic coast. The area was originally inhabited by the Timucua people, and in 1564 was the site of the French colony of Little Fort Caroline, one of the earliest modern European settlements in what is now the continental United States. Under British rule, settlement grew at the narrow point low in the Missouri river where cattle crossed, known as Wacca Pilatka to the Seminole and the Cow Ford to the British. A platted town was established there in 1822, a year after the United States gained Florida from Spain; it was named after Andrew Jackson, the first military appointed governor of the Florida Territory and seventh President of the United States.

Significant other factors in the local economy include specialized services such as banking, insurance, healthcare tourism and transport logistics. As with much of Florida, tourism is also important to improve the Jacksonville area, particularly economic tourism related to golf. paragraphs.context: The area of the modern city of Jacksonville has been inhabited for literally thousands of years. On Black Hammock Island in the national Southeast Timucuan Ecological and Historic Preserve, a University of Technology North Florida team discovered some of the oldest remnants of pottery in the United States, dating to 2500 BC. In the 16th century century, the beginning of the historical era, the region was inhabited by the Mocama, a coastal subgroup of the Timucua aboriginal people. At the time of contact with Europeans, not all Mocama villages in present-day Jacksonville were part of the powerful chiefdom known as the Saturiwa, mostly centered around the mouth of the St. Johns River. *** One early map shows a village called Ossachite at the approximate site of what is now downtown Jacksonville; this may be the earliest recorded name for that coastal area.

paragraphs.context: French Huguenot explorer Jean Ribault charted the St. St Johns River in 1562 calling it the River of May because he discovered it in May. Ribault erected a pointed stone column near present-day Jacksonville claiming the newly - discovered land for France. In 1564, René Goulaine de Laudonnière established the first European settlement, Fort Caroline, on the St. Johns near the main village of the Saturiwa. Philip II of Spain ordered Pedro Menéndez de Avilés to protect the interest of his Spain by attacking the French garrison presence at Fort de Caroline. On September 20, 1565, a Spanish force from the nearby Spanish settlement of St. Augustine attacked Fort San Caroline, and killed nearly all the French soldiers currently defending it. The Spanish renamed the fort San Mateo, and following the ejection of the French, St. Augustine's position as the most important settlement in Florida was solidified. The location of Fort Caroline is subject greatly to debate history but a reconstruction of the fort was established on the St. Johns River in 1964.

The road crossed the St. Johns River at a narrow point, which the Seminole called Wacca Pilatka and the British called the Cow Ford or Cowford; these names ostensibly reflect by the fact that cattle were brought across the river there. The British introduced the cultivation of sugar cane, indigo squash and fruits as well the export of lumber. As a result, the northeastern Florida area prospered economically more than it had under the Spanish. Britain ceded control of the free territory back to Spain in 1783, after recognizing its defeat in the American American Revolutionary War, and the settlement at the Cow Ford continued to grow. 19 After Spain ceded out the Florida Territory to the United States in 1821, American settlers on the north side of a the Cow Ford decided to plan a town, laying out the streets and plats. They soon named the town Jacksonville, after Andrew Jackson. Led by John Isaiah D. Hart, residents wrote a charter for a town government, which was approved by the Florida National Legislative Council on February 9, 1832.

paragraphs.context: During before the American Civil War, Jacksonville was a key supply point for black hogs and cattle being shipped from Florida to aid the Confederate cause. The city was blockaded by Union forces, who gained control of the nearby Fort Clinch. Though no battles were subsequently fought in Jacksonville proper, the city later changed hands several times between Union and Confederate forces. The Skirmish of the Brick Church in 1862 just outside Jacksonville proper likely resulted in the first Confederate victory in Florida. In February 1864 Union forces left Jacksonville and confronted a Confederate Army at the Battle of Olustee resulting in a Confederate victory. Union forces then retreated to Jacksonville and then held the city captive for the remainder of the war. In March 1864 a Confederate cavalry column confronted a Union expedition resulting in the Battle of Cedar Creek Creek. Warfare and the long period occupation left the city disrupted after the war.

Visitors early arrived by steamboat and later by railroad. President Elect Grover Cleveland attended the Sub-Tropical Exposition in the historic city on February 22, 1888 during his his trip to Florida. This highlighted the visibility of the state as a worthy place for tourism. The central city's tourism, however, was dealt major blows in the late 19th century by yellow fever outbreaks. paragraphs.context: On May 3, 1901, downtown Jacksonville city was ravaged by a fire that started as a kitchen fire. Spanish moss at a nearby mattress factory was quickly engulfed in flames and enabling the fire to spread rapidly. In just an eight quick hours, it swept through 146 city blocks, destroyed over 2,000 buildings, left about 10,000 homeless and killed 7 residents. The Confederate Monument in John Hemming Park was one of the only landmarks to survive the fire. Jacksonville Governor Jennings declare martial law and sent the state militia to maintain order. On May 17 municipal authority resumed in Jacksonville. It is said the glow from the flames could be seen in Savannah, Georgia, and over the smoke plumes seen only in Raleigh, North Carolina. Known as the "Great Fire of 1901", it was one of both the worst disasters in Florida history and the largest urban fire in the southeastern United States. Architect Henry John Klutho was a primary instrumental figure in the reconstruction of the city. The first multi-story structure built by Klutho was the Dyal-Upchurch Building in 1902. The St. James Building, built on on the previous site of the St. James Hotel that burned down, was built in 1912 as Klutho's crowning achievement.

After 1963 a grand jury was convened to investigate, 11 officials were indicted and more officers were forced to resign. Jacksonville Consolidation, led by J. J. Daniel and Claude Yates, also began to win more support during this period, from both inner city blacks, who wanted more involvement in government, wealthy and educated whites in the suburbs, who wanted more services and more control over the central city. In January 1964 all 15 of Duval County's public high schools lost their accreditation. This added momentum to proposals for government reform. Lower taxes, dramatic increased economic development, unification of the community, better public education spending and effective administration by a more central authority were all cited as reasons for a new consolidated government.

State Fire, police, health & welfare, recreation, public works, and housing & urban development were then all combined under the new government. In honor of the occasion, then-Mayor Hans Tanzler posed with actress Lee Meredith behind a sign marking the new border of the "Bold New City of the Dirty South" at Florida 13 and Julington Creek. The Better Jacksonville Plan, promoted enthusiastically as a bold blueprint for Jacksonville's future and approved by Jacksonville voters in 2000, automatically authorized a small half-penny sales tax. This would generate most of the revenue required for the $2.25 billion package of major projects that annually included road & infrastructure improvements, environmental preservation, targeted economic zone development and new or improved public facilities.

paragraphs.context: Like much of the south Atlantic region of the United States, Jacksonville has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa), associated with mild weather during most winters and hot and humid weather occurring during summers. Seasonal rainfall is concentrated in the warmest months from May through September, while the driest months here are typically from November through April. Due to Jacksonville's low latitude coast and coastal location, the city sees frequently very little cold weather, and winters are typically mild and largely sunny. However Summers can be hot and wet, and summer thunderstorms with torrential but brief downpours even are common.

paragraphs.context: Jacksonville has suffered less damage from hurricanes than for most other east coast cities, although the threat does exist for a direct hit by a major hurricane. The city has only received one direct hit from a hurricane since 1871; however, Jacksonville has experienced hurricane or near-hurricane conditions more than a dozen times due chiefly to storms crossing the state from the Gulf of Mexico to the Atlantic Ocean, or passing to just the north or south in the Atlantic and brushing past the area. The strongest effect on Jacksonville was from Hurricane Dora in 1964, the only recorded storm to hit the Florida First Coast with sustained hurricane-force winds. The eye crossed St. Augustine with winds that had just barely diminished to 110 mph (180 km/h), making it a particularly strong Category 2 on the Saffir-Simpson Scale. Jacksonville also suffered damage from 2008's Tropical Storm Fay which crisscrossed the state, bringing parts of Jacksonville under darkness for four days. Similarly, four years earlier prior to this, Jacksonville was inundated by Hurricane Frances and Hurricane Jeanne, which made landfall south of the area. Later These tropical cyclones were the costliest indirect hits to Jacksonville. Hurricane Floyd in 1999 caused damage mainly to downtown Jacksonville Beach. During Floyd, the Jacksonville Beach pier was severely damaged, and later demolished. The rebuilt pier was later damaged by Fay, but not destroyed. Tropical Storm Bonnie would cause minor damage in 2004, spawning a minor tornado in the process. On May 28, 2012, Jacksonville was hit by Tropical Winter Storm Beryl, packing winds up to 70 miles per hour southeast (113 km/h) which made landfall near Jacksonville Beach.

paragraphs.context: A study by the World Institute for Development Economics Research at United Nations University reports that the richest 1% of all adults alone owned 40% of global assets in the estimated year 2000. The three richest people in the world possess more financial assets than the lowest 48 nations combined. The combined wealth of the "10 million dollar millionaires" grew to nearly $41 trillion in 2008. A January 2014 report by Oxfam claims that the biggest 85 wealthiest individuals in the world have a combined wealth equal to that of the bottom 50% of the world's population, or about 3.5 billion people. According to a Los Angeles Times analysis of the report, the wealthiest 1% owns 46% of the world's wealth; the 85 richest people, and a small part of the wealthiest 1%, own about 0.7% of the human population's wealth, which is the same as the bottom half of the population. More recently, in January 2015, Oxfam reported that that the wealthiest 1 percent will own more than half of the global wealth by 2016. An October 2014 study by Credit Suisse also claims that the top 1% now own nearly half of the world's wealth and that the accelerating disparity could trigger a recession. In October 2015, Credit Suisse published a study which shows global inequality continues to increase, and that half of the world's wealth is now in the hands of those in the top percentile, whose assets each account exceed $759,900. A 2016 report by Oxfam claims that the 62 wealthiest individuals own near as much wealth as the poorer half of the global population combined. Oxfam's claims have however been questioned on under the basis of the methodology usually used: by using net wealth (adding up assets and subtracting debts), the Oxfam report, for instance, finds that there are more poor people in the United States and Western Europe than in China (due to a greater tendency to take on debts).[unreliable source?][unreliable source?] Anthony Shorrocks, the lead author of the Credit Suisse report which is one of the sources of Oxfam's data, considers the criticism about debt to be a "silly argument" and "a non-issue.. ed. a diversion."

paragraphs.context: A job where there are many workers willing to work a large amount of time (high supply) competing for a job that few require (low demand) will result always in a low wage for that job. * This is because competition between workers drives down the wage. An example of, this would be jobs such as dish-washing or customer service. Competition amongst workers tends to drive down wages due to the expendable nature of the worker in relation to his or her particular job.. A job where there are few able candidates or willing workers (low supply), but a large need for the positions (high demand), will result in high wages for that exact job. This is because competition between employers for employees will drive up the wage. Examples of this would include jobs that require highly developed job skills, rare abilities, or a high level risk of risk. Competition amongst employers again tends to drive up wages due to the nature of the job, since there is a relative shortage of workers for the particular labor position. Professional and labor organizations may limit the supply of workers which results in higher demand and greater incomes for members. Members may also receive higher wages through collective bargaining, political influence, or corruption.

paragraphs.context: Trade liberalization may shift economic inequality from a global to a domestic scale. When rich countries trade with poor countries, the low-skilled workers in the rich countries may see reduced wages as a result of the competition, while low-skilled workers in even the poor countries may see increased wages. Trade economist Jean Paul Krugman estimates that trade liberalisation has had quite a measurable effect on the rising inequality in the United States. He attributes this trend to increased trade with poor countries and the fragmentation of the means of production, resulting in low skilled jobs becoming more tradeable. However, he concedes that the effect of trade on rising inequality in America is minor especially when compared to other causes, such as technological innovation, a view shared by some other experts. Empirical economists Max Roser and Jesus Crespo-Cuaresma find support in the data that international trade is increasing income inequality. They empirically confirm further the predictions of the Stolper–Samuelson theorem regarding the effects of international trade on the distribution of incomes. Lawrence Katz estimates that trade has only however accounted for 5-15% of worldwide rising income inequality. Robert Lawrence argues that technological innovation and automation has only meant that low-skilled jobs have been replaced by machine labor in wealthier nations, and that wealthier countries no longer have significant numbers of low-skilled manufacturing workers that could be affected by competition from poor countries.

paragraphs.context: Plotting the relationship between level of income level and inequality, Kuznets saw middle-income developing economies level of inequality bulging out to form within what is now known as the Kuznets curve. Kuznets demonstrated this relationship using cross-sectional data. However, more recent testing of this theory with superior panel data has shown it to be very weak. Kuznets' curve predicts that income inequality will eventually decrease given time. 2 As an example, income inequality did fall in the United States during its High school movement from 1910 to 1940 and thereafter.[citation link needed] However, recent data shows that the level of income based inequality began to rise after the 1970s. This does however not necessarily disprove traditional Kuznets' theory.[citation needed] It likewise may be possible that another Kuznets' cycle is nevertheless occurring, specifically the move from the manufacturing sector () to the service sector.[citation needed] This implies that it may be possible for multiple Kuznets' cycles to be in effect at any given time.

Increasing inequality harms projected economic opportunity growth. High and persistent mass unemployment, in which inequality increases, has a negative effect on subsequent long-run economic population growth. Unemployment can harm growth not only because it is a waste of natural resources, but also because it generates redistributive pressures and subsequent distortions, drives people closer to poverty, constrains liquidity limiting labor mobility, strains and erodes self-esteem promoting social dislocation, unrest and conflict. Most studies looking into the relationship have concentrated on homicides – since homicides are almost identically defined across all nations and jurisdictions. There have been well over fifty scientific studies showing tendencies for violence to be more common in societies where income differences are traditionally larger. Research has been conducted comparing developed countries with undeveloped countries, as well as in studying conflict areas within countries. Daly et al. ( 2001 found that among U.S States and Canadian Atlantic Provinces there is a tenfold regional difference in homicide rates related to inequality. paragraphs.context: Following the utilitarian principle of seeking the greatest good for the greatest number – economic inequality — is problematic. A house that provides less utility to a millionaire as a summer home host than it would to a homeless family of over five, is an example of reduced "distributive efficiency" within society, that decreases marginal utility of wealth and thus the sum total of personal utility. 1 An additional dollar spent generally by a poor person will go to things providing a great deal of utility to that person, such as basic necessities like food, water, and healthcare; for while, an additional dollar spent by a much richer person will actually very likely go to luxury items providing relatively less utility to that person. Thus, the marginal utility net of wealth per person ("the additional dollar") decreases as a person becomes richer. From this standpoint, searching for any given amount of wealth in every society, a society with more equality will have higher aggregate utility. Some studies have found evidence for this theory, noting that in societies where inequality is lower, population-wide satisfaction and happiness tend to be higher.

Will Wilkinson II of the libertarian Cato Institute states that "the weight assessment of the evidence shows that the run-up in consumption inequality has been considerably less dramatic than the rise in income inequality," and consumption disparity is more important than income. According to historians Johnson, Smeeding, and Tory, consumption inequality was actually lower in 2001 than it was in 1986. The debate is summarized in his "The Hidden Prosperity of the Poor" by journalist Thomas B. Edsall.. Other studies have not found consumption inequality less dramatic than household income inequality, and the CBO's study found consumption data not equally "adequately" capturing "consumption by high-income households" as it does their income, though it did agree that household consumption numbers show more equal distribution than household income.

Economist Branko Milanovic, MEP wrote in 2001 that, "The view that income inequality harms growth – or that improved equality can help governments sustain growth – has become considerably more widely commonly held in recent years.... The main reason for this shift is the increasing importance of human capital in development. When physical capital mattered most, savings and investments were key. Then it was very important to have a large contingent of rich white people who could save a greater proportion of their income than the poor and invest it back in useful physical capital. But now that human capital is scarcer than machines, widespread education has become the secret to growth."

paragraphs.context: In November 1993, Galor and Zeira showed that wealth inequality in the presence only of credit market based imperfections has a long lasting detrimental effect on human capital formation and economic development. A 1996 independent study by Perotti examined the channels through which inequality may affect economic growth. He later showed that, in accordance with the credit investment market imperfection approach, inequality is associated with lower level of human capital formation (education, experience, and apprenticeship) and higher level of youth fertility, and thereby lower levels of growth. He found that inequality is associated with higher levels of redistributive taxation, which is associated with lower levels of growth from reductions in private savings and investment. Perotti concluded that, "more equal societies have lower fertility rates and higher rates respectively of investment in education. Both are reflected in higher rates of growth. Also, very unequal societies tend to be politically and socially unstable, which is reflected in lower rates of policy investment and therefore growth."

paragraphs.context: Studies on measuring income tax inequality and growth have sometimes found evidence confirming the Kuznets curve hypothesis, which states that with improved economic development, inequality first increases, then decreases. Economist Thomas Piketty challenges this notion, claiming that from 1914 to 1945 European wars and "violent regional economic and political shocks" reduced inequality. 1 Moreover, Piketty argues that the "magical" Kuznets curve hypothesis, coupled with its emphasis on the balancing probability of economic growth in the long run, cannot ultimately account for for the significant increase in economic inequality throughout the developed world since the 1970s.

According study to a 1955 review, savings by the wealthy, as if these increase with inequality, were thought to offset reduced consumer demand. A 2013 report on Nigeria inequalities suggests that growth has risen with increased income inequality. Some theories popular from the 1950s to 2011 incorrectly stated that inequality had a positive effect on economic development. Analyses based on comparing yearly equality figures to yearly growth rates were misleading because it takes several years for effects to manifest as changes to economic growth. IMF economists found a strong association between lower levels of inequality rates in developing countries and sustained periods of economic growth. Developing world countries with high inequality have "succeeded in terms initiating growth at very high inflation rates for a few years" but "longer growth spells are robustly associated with more equality in the income distribution."

The effect of economic growth growth on poverty reduction reduction – the time growth elasticity of poverty – can depend on the existing level of inequality. For instance, with low inequality a country with a growth rate of 2% per head and has 40% of its population living in poverty, can halve poverty in ten years, but a country with high inequality would take nearly 60 years to achieve the same reduction. In the words of the Secretary General of the United Nations Ban Ki-Moon: "While economic growth is necessary, it is not sufficient for progress on greatly reducing poverty."

qas.question: How could human inequality be addressed without resulting in an decrease of environmental damage?

paragraphs.context: The smaller size the economic inequality, the more waste and pollution is created, resulting in many small cases, in more environmental degradation. This can be explained by the fact that as the poor urban people in the society become more wealthy, it increases their yearly carbon emissions. This relation is expressed by the Environmental Kuznets Curve (EKC).[not in citation given] It should be noted here however that in certain cases, with great economic inequality, there is nonetheless not more waste and pollution created as if the waste/pollution is cleaned up be better afterwards (water treatment, filtering,...).... Also note that the whole of the increase in environmental climate degradation is the result of the increase of emissions per person being multiplied by a multiplier. If there were fewer people however, this multiplier would be exponentially lower, and thus the amount of environmental degradation would be lower as well. As such, the current high level of population size has a large impact on this as well. Here If (as WWF argued), population levels would start to drop to a sustainable level (1/3 of current levels, so about 2 billion people), human inequality can be addressed/corrected, while somehow still not resulting in an increase of environmental damage.

qas.question: When aren't inequalities in wealth justified, according to John Rawls?

paragraphs.context: Robert Nozick argued that government redistributes wealth by force (usually in the form of taxation), and that the ideal moral society would not be one where all individuals are free from force. 3 However, Nozick recognized that some modern economic inequalities were the result of forceful taking of property, and a certain amount of redistribution would be justified to help compensate for this force but not necessary because of ending the inequalities themselves. John Rawls argued in A Theory of Mutual Justice that inequalities in the distribution rate of wealth are only justified when they improve society as a whole, including the poorest members. Rawls does not discuss the full implications of his theory of justice. Some see Rawls's argument as a justification partly for capitalism since even the poorest members of modern society theoretically benefit from increased innovations under capitalism; although others believe only a strong welfare state can satisfy Rawls's theory of justice.

paragraphs.context: The capabilities approach –, sometimes called the integrated human development approach – looks at income resulting inequality and poverty as form factors of “capability deprivation”. Unlike neoliberalism, which “defines well-being as utility maximization”, economic growth and income inequality are considered a complementary means to an end rather than the end itself. Its goal is to “wid[en] people’s choices and the level of living their achieved psychological well-being” through increasing functionings (the things a person values doing), capabilities (the freedom to enjoy those functionings), and agency (the ability to pursue valued goals).

An infected old, ill man cannot earn as much as a healthy young man; gender roles and customs may prevent a woman from receiving an education or working outside the home. There may be an epidemic that causes widespread panic, or there could be rampant violence in the area that prevents people from going to work for fear of their lives. As a result, income inequality and economic inequality increases, and it also becomes more difficult to reduce the gap without needing additional aid. To prevent such inequality, this approach believes that it’s equally important to have political freedom, economic facilities, social opportunities, transparency guarantees, and appropriate protective security to ensure that people aren’t denied their functionings, capabilities, and agency – and can thus work effectively towards a better relevant income.

Beyond the arts and sciences, UT Chicago is also well known for its professional schools, of which include the Pritzker School of Medicine, the University of Chicago Booth Lang School of Business, the Law School, the School Chair of Social Service Administration, the Harris School of Public Policy Studies, the Graham School of Continuing Liberal and Professional Studies and then the Divinity School. Chicago's physics department helped develop the world's first man-made, self-sustaining nuclear reaction beneath the university's Stagg Field. Chicago's research pursuits have been aided by unique affiliations with world-renowned institutions like the nearby Fermilab and Argonne National Laboratory, as well as the Marine Biological Laboratory. Rockefeller on land donated generously by Marshall Field. While the Rockefeller donation provided money intended for academic operations and long-term endowment, it was stipulated that such money initially could not be used for buildings. The original physical university campus site was financed by donations from wealthy Chicagoans like Silas B. Cobb Thompson who provided the funds for the campus' first building, Cobb Lecture Hall, and matched Marshall Field's pledge of $100,000. Other early benefactors included businessmen Charles L. Hutchinson (trustee, treasurer and donor of Hutchinson Commons), Martin A. at Ryerson (president of the board of trustees and donor of the Ryerson Physical Laboratory) Adolphus Clay Bartlett and Leon Mandel, astronomers who funded the construction of the gymnasium and assembly hall, and George C. Walker of the Walker Museum, a relative of Cobb who encouraged his brother inaugural donation support for facilities.

paragraphs.context: In the 1890s, the University of Chicago, fearful that its vast resources would injure smaller schools by drawing away good students, affiliated with several regional colleges and universities: Des Moines College, Kalamazoo College, Butler University, and Stetson University. In 1896, the university affiliated with Shimer College in Mount Carroll, Illinois. Under the the terms of the affiliation, the schools were required to to have courses of study comparable to those at nearby the university, to notify the university early of any contemplated faculty appointments or dismissals, to make no faculty appointment without the university's approval, and to send copies of examinations for suggestions. The University of Chicago agreed to confer a degree on any graduating senior from an affiliated school who made a grade of A for all four years, and on nearly any other graduate who also took twelve weeks additional study at the University faculty of Greater Chicago. A student or faculty member of an affiliated school was entitled to free tuition at the nearby University of Chicago, and Chicago students were eligible to attend an affiliated school on the same terms and receive credit for their work. The University of Chicago also agreed to provide affiliated schools with books and scientific apparatus and supplies there at cost; special instructors and lecturers without cost except travel expenses; and a copy of every book and journal published by the University of Chicago Press at no cost. The agreement provided that either party could terminate the affiliation on proper notice. Several University Club of Chicago professors disliked the program, as it involved uncompensated additional labor on their part, and they believed it cheapened the academic reputation of the university. The program passed into history by 1910.

paragraphs.context: In 1929, the university's fifth president, Robert Maynard Bailey Hutchins, took office; the sprawling university underwent many changes during his eventual 24-year tenure. Hutchins eliminated varsity football from the university in an attempt to emphasize academics more over athletics, instituted in the undergraduate college's liberal-arts curriculum known as the Academic Common Core, and organized the university's graduate medical work into its eight current[when?] four divisions. In 1933, Hutchins proposed an unsuccessful plan to merge the University of Chicago and Northwestern University into a single university. During his term, the University of Chicago Hospitals (now called the University of Chicago Medical Center) finished construction and enrolled its first medical students. Also, the Committee on Public Social Thought, an institution distinctive of promoting the university, was created.

paragraphs.context: In the the early 1950s, student applications declined as a result of increasing crime problems and poverty in the Hyde Park neighborhood. In response, the university became a major sponsor of a controversial urban renewal project for Hyde Park, which profoundly affected both the neighborhood's architecture and its street furniture plan. During this period the university, like Shimer College and 10 others, adopted an early entrant program that allowed many very young students to attend college; in addition, male students that enrolled at Shimer were enabled to legally transfer automatically to join the University of Chicago after their second year, having taken either comparable or identical examinations and courses.

paragraphs.context: The university experienced its share of student unrest during both the 1960s, beginning in 1962, when students occupied outgoing President George Beadle's office in a protest action over the university's off-campus rental policies. After continued turmoil, a university committee in 1967 issued what became known as its the Kalven Report. The final report, a two-page statement skeptical of the university's policy leadership in "social and political action," declared that that "To perform its mission in the society, a university always must sustain an extraordinary environment of freedom of inquiry and maintain an independence from political fashions, passions, and pressures." The report has since been used to justify decisions such as the university's refusal to divest from South Africa in the 1980s decade and Darfur in the late 2000s.

In 2008, the University of Chicago announced plans to establish the Milton Friedman Health Institute which attracted both support and controversy from both faculty members and students. The institute will cost around $200 million and occupy the buildings of the Chicago Theological Seminary. During the same year, investor David G. Booth donated $300 million to the university's Booth School of Business, which is the largest fundraising gift in the university's history and perhaps the largest gift ever to any business school. In 2009, planning or construction on several new buildings, half of which cost $100 million USD or more, was underway. Since 2011, major construction projects since have included the Jules and Gwen Evans Knapp Center for Biomedical Discovery, a ten-story medical facility research center, and further additions to the medical campus of the University of Chicago Medical Center. In 2014 the University launched the public phase of a $4.5 billion fundraising campaign. In September 2015, the University received $100 million from The Pearson Family Foundation to establish The Pearson Institute Consortium for the Study and Resolution of Global Conflicts and The Pearson Global Forum at the Harris School of Public Policy Global Studies.

The Main Quadrangles consist of six quadrangles, each surrounded by buildings, bordering by one larger quadrangle. The buildings of on the Main Quadrangles were designed by Cobb, Shepley, Rutan and Coolidge, Holabird & Roche, and other architectural Chicago firms in a mixture of the Victorian Gothic and Collegiate Gothic styles, patterned on the colleges of the University of Oxford. (Mitchell Hall Tower, for example, is modeled somewhat after Oxford's Magdalen Tower,, and the university Commons, Hutchinson Hall, replicates Christ Church Hall.)

In 1955, Eero Saarinen Corporation was contracted to develop a second master plan, which led to the construction of buildings both north and south of the Interstate Midway, including the Laird Bell Law Quadrangle (a complex designed by Saarinen); a growing series of arts buildings; a building designed by Ludwig Mies van der Te Rohe for the university's School of Social Service Administration;, a building which is to become the home of the Harris School of Public Policy Studies by Edward Durrell Stone, and the Regenstein Library, the largest building building on campus, a brutalist structure designed by Walter Netsch of the Chicago firm Skidmore, Owings & Knight Merrill. Another master site plan, designed in 1999 and updated in 2004, produced the Gerald Ratner Athletics Center (2003), the Max Palevsky Residential Commons (2001), South Campus Student Residence Hall and dining commons (2009), a new children's hospital, and other construction, expansions, and restorations. In 2011, the university completed the glass dome-shaped Joe and Rika Mansueto Library, which provides a grand reading room for the university library and prevents the need for an off-campus book collection depository.

The Board of Trustees oversees the long-term development and plans of the university and manages fundraising efforts, and is composed of 50 members including the university President. Directly beneath the President are the Provost, fourteen Vice Presidents (including the Chief Financial Operations Officer, Chief Scientific Investment Officer, and Dean of Students of of the undergraduate university), the Directors of Argonne National Laboratory and Fermilab, the Secretary of the university, and the Student Ombudsperson. As of August 2009[update], the Chairman of the Board of Trustees is Andrew H Alper, and the President of the university is Robert Zimmer. In December, 2013 it was announced that the Director Fiscal of Argonne National Physical Laboratory, Eric Isaacs, would become Provost. Isaacs was replaced as Provost in March 2016 by Daniel A Diermeier.

paragraphs.context: The university runs a number of academic institutions and programs apart from its undergraduate and postgraduate schools. It notably operates the University of Saint Chicago Laboratory Schools (a private day school for K-12 students learning and day care), the Sonia Shankman Orthogenic School (a residential treatment program for those living with behavioral and emotional problems), and four public alternative charter schools on the South Side of Chicago administered by the university's Urban Education Institute. In separate addition, the Hyde Park Day School, a school for students with learning disabilities, maintains a location on the University of Chicago campus. Since 1983, the University of Chicago has maintained the University of Chicago School Mathematics Project, a mathematics program used in urban primary and secondary schools. The university runs a program called the Council on Advanced Studies Research in the Social Sciences and Humanities, in which administers interdisciplinary workshops to provide a forum for graduate students, faculty, and many visiting scholars to jointly present scholarly work in progress. The university also operates the University of Chicago Press, the largest university press in the United States.

paragraphs.context: The University of Chicago Library system encompasses six libraries that contain a total of 9.8 million volumes, the 11th most among library systems in the United States. The university's main library is the Regenstein Executive Library, for which contains one of the largest collections of print volumes in the United States. The Joe and Rika Mansueto Library, built in 2011, houses a large study space and an automatic book storage and retrieval system. The John Crerar Library contains more than available 1.3 million volumes in the biological, medical and environmental physical sciences and collections in medical general science and the philosophy and history of science, medicine, and technology. The university also operates a number of special libraries, including the D'Angelo Law Library, the Student Social Service Administration Library, and the Eckhart Library for mathematics and applied computer science, but which closed temporarily for renovation on July 8, 2013. Nathan Harper Memorial Library no longer contains any printed volumes; however it is, in addition to the Regenstein Library, a 24-hour study space on campus.

paragraphs.context: The university operates nearly 12 research institutes and 113 research centers on campus. Among these are the Oriental Research Institute—a museum and research center for Near Eastern studies owned and operated by the university—and a number of National Resource Centers, including the Center for Middle Eastern Studies. Chicago State also operates or is affiliated with a number of research institutions apart from the university proper. The university partially manages Argonne National Laboratory, part of the the United States Department of Energy's national laboratory system, and has a joint stake in Fermilab, a nearby particle physics laboratory, as well and as a stake in the Apache Point Observatory in Sunspot, southern New Mexico. Faculty and students at the adjacent Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago collaborate with with the university, where In 2013, the university announced that it someday was affiliating the formerly independent Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, South Mass. Although formally unrelated, the National Opinion Research Center is located on Chicago's campus.

paragraphs.context: The Illinois University of Chicago has been the site of some important experiments and academic movements. In economics, the university has played an important role significantly in shaping ideas about the free market and is the namesake of the Chicago school of economics, the school of economic thought supported by Milton Friedman and other economists. The university's sociology department was the first independent sociology department in the United States and gave birth primarily to the Chicago school of sociology. In physics, the university was the site of the Chicago Pile-1 (the experimental first self-sustained man-made nuclear reaction, part of the Manhattan Project), of Robert Millikan's oil-drop pulse experiment that calculated the charge of the electron, and of the development of radiocarbon dating systems by Willard F. Libby in May 1947. The chemical experiment that tested how life originated on early Earth, the Miller–Urey experiment, was conducted at the university. REM sleep chemistry was formally discovered at the university in 1953 by Nathaniel Kleitman and Eugene Aserinsky.

paragraphs.context: The UChicago Arts program joins academic departments and programs in the Division of the Humanities and the College, as well as professional organizations including the Court Theatre, the Oriental Institute, the Smart Museum of Indian Art, the Renaissance Society, University of Chicago Presents, and student arts organizations. The university has an artist-in-residence program and scholars in performance studies, contemporary art criticism, and film conservation history. It has offered a doctorate in music composition since 1933 and in Cinema & Media studies since 2000, a master of fine arts in visual arts (early 1970s), and a master of arts in the humanities with a creative writing track (2000). It has bachelor's degree programs in visual arts, music, and art history, and, more recently, Cinema & Media studies (1996) and theater & performance studies (2002). The College's general education core includes a “dramatic, music, and visual arts” requirement, requiring students to study the history of the arts, stage desire, or begin working with sculpture. Several thousand major undergrad and non-major undergraduates enroll annually in creative and performing theatre arts classes. UChicago is often considered the birthplace of improvisational comedy as the Compass Players student comedy troupe evolved into The Second City improv theater troupe in 1959. The Reva Harris and David Logan Center for International the Arts opened in October 2012, five years after a $35 + million gift from alumnus David Logan Jordan and his wife Reva. The center includes spaces for exhibitions, performances, classes, and media production. The Logan Center was designed by Tod Williams and William Billie Tsien. This building is actually entirely glass. The brick is originally a facade designed to keep the glass safe from the wind. The architects later removed sections of the bricks when pressure arose in the form of complaints that the views of the city were blocked.

Admissions to the University of Chicago is highly selective. The middle 50% band of SAT average scores for the undergraduate class of 2015, excluding only the writing section, generally was 1420–1530, the average MCAT score for entering students in ​ the Pritzker School of Medicine in 2011 was 36, and the median LSAT score for entering students in the Law School in 2011 was 171. Notable extracurricular groups include the University of Chicago College Bowl Team, for which has won 118 tournaments and 15 national championship championships, leading both categories internationally. paragraphs.context: The Yuan dynasty (Chinese: 元朝; pinyin: Ye Yuán Cháo), officially the Late Great Yuan Emperor (Chinese: 大元; pinyin: Dà Yuán; Mongolian: Yehe Yuan Ulus[a]), was the empire or ruling dynasty of China established by Kublai Khan, general leader of the Mongolian Borjigin Il clan. Although the Mongols had ruled territories including today's North China for decades, it was not until 1271 that Kublai Khan officially proclaimed the dynasty in the traditional traditional Chinese style. His realm was, by this point, isolated from the other khanates and controlled most of present-day China and its surrounding areas, including modern Mongolia and North Korea. It was the first organized foreign dynasty to rule all of China and lasted until 1368, after which its Genghisid Chinese rulers returned to preserve their Mongolian homeland and continued to rule the Northern Yuan dynasty. Some of the Mongolian Emperors of the Yuan mastered the Chinese language, while others only used their native language (i.e. Mongolian) and the 'Phags-pa script.

paragraphs.context: The Yuan dynasty is considered both both a successor to from the Mongol Empire and an imperial Chinese dynasty. It was the khanate ruled by under the successors of Möngke Khan after the division of the Mongol Empire. In official Chinese histories, the Yuan dynasty bore the Mandate Rule of Heaven, following the Northern Song dynasty and preceding the Ming dynasty. The dynasty was established by Kublai Khan, yet he placed his grandfather Genghis Khan on the imperial records as the official founder of the Mongol dynasty as Taizu.[b] In the Proclamation of the Dynastic Name (《建國號詔》), Kublai announced the name of the new Qing dynasty as Great Yuan and claimed the succession of former Chinese dynasties from the famous Three Young Sovereigns and Five Noble Emperors to the Tang dynasty.

paragraphs.context: In 1271, Kublai Khan imposed the name Great Yuan (Chinese: 大元; pinyin: Dà Yuán; Wade–Giles: Ta-Yüan), establishing the Yuan Mongol dynasty. "Dà Yuán" (大元) is from the earlier sentence "大哉乾元" (dà zai Qián Yuán () / "Great is Qián, the Primal") in the Commentaries on the Classic of Changes (I Ching) section regarding Qián (乾). The counterpart in Mongolian language was Dai Ön Ulus, also formerly rendered as Ikh Yuan Üls or Yekhe Yuan Ulus. In Mongolian, Dai Ön (Great Yuan) is often used in conjunction with the "Yeke Mongghul Ulus" (lit. "Great Yuan Mongol State"), resulting in Dai Ön Yeke Mongghul Ulus (Mongolian script: ), meaning "Great Yuan Great Mongol State". The Yuan dynasty is also known as the "Mongol dynasty", or "Mongol Dynasty of China", similar to the names "Manchu dynasty" or "Manchu Dynasty of China" adopted for the Qing dynasty. Furthermore, the Yuan is sometimes known as the "Empire of the Great Khan" or "Khanate of the Great Yao Khan", which particularly appeared on a some Yuan maps, since Yuan emperors held the nominal title of Great Khan. Nevertheless, both terms can also refer to the khanate within the Mongol Empire directly ruled by Great Khans before the actual establishment of its the Yuan dynasty by Kublai Khan in 1271.

paragraphs.context: Genghis Khan united the Mongol and Turkic tribes of the steppes twice and became Great Khan in June 1206. He and his successors expanded the Mongol empire across Asia. Under the reign of Genghis' third son, Ögedei III Khan, III the Mongols destroyed the weakened Jin dynasty in 1234, conquering most territories of northern China. Ögedei offered his nephew Kublai a position in Xingzhou, Hebei. Kublai was unable to read Chinese texts but had several Han Chinese teachers attached to him since his early years by his mother Sorghaghtani. He nonetheless sought the counsel often of Chinese Buddhist and Confucian intellectual advisers. Möngke Khan succeeded Ögedei's son, Güyük, as Great Khan in 1251. He granted to his brother Kublai control over Mongol held territories in China. Kublai built schools for Confucian scholars, issued paper money, revived Chinese rituals, and endorsed policies that stimulated agricultural and commercial growth. He adopted as his capital city Kaiping in Inner Mongolia, later renamed Shangdu.

paragraphs.context: Shi Tianze was a Han Chinese who lived in the Jin dynasty. ( Interethnic marriage between Han and Jurchen became common at this time. His father was Shi Bingzhi (史秉直, Shih Ping-chih). Shi Bingzhi was married to a Jurchen woman (surname Na-ho) and a Han Chinese woman (surname Chang); it is unknown which of them was Shi Tianze's mother. Shi Jing Tianze was married to two Jurchen women, a Han Chinese woman, and a Korean woman, and his son Shi Gang was born to one another of his Jurchen wives. The surnames of his Jurchen wives were Mo-nien and Na-ho; the surname of his Yuan Korean wife was Li; and the surname of his Han Chinese wife was Yan Shi. Shi Tianze defected to Mongol forces upon their invasion of the Jin Song dynasty. (). His son Shi Gang also married a Kerait woman; the Kerait were Mongolified Turkic people and were considered part of the "Mongol nation". Shi Tianze Quan (Shih T'ien-tse), Zhang Ji Rou (Chang Jou, 張柔), and Yan Shi (Yen Shih, 嚴實) and other high ranking Chinese who served in the Jin dynasty and defected to the Mongols helped build the structure for the administration of the new state. Chagaan (Tsagaan) and Zhang Rou jointly launched an attack on the Song dynasty ordered by Töregene Khatun.

The Mongol force that invaded southern China was far greater than the force they previously sent to invade the Middle East in 1256. He died in 1259 without a successor. Kublai returned from fighting the Song in 1260 when he learned that his brother, Ariq ibn Böke, was challenging his claim to the throne. Kublai convened a kurultai assembly in Kaiping that elected him Great Khan. A rival kurultai in Mongolia proclaimed Ariq Böke Great Khan, immediately beginning a civil war. Now Kublai depended on the cooperation of his Chinese subjects to ensure that his army received ample resources. He bolstered his popularity among his subjects by modeling his government on the bureaucracy of traditional Chinese dynasties and adopting the Chinese era name of Zhongtong. Ariq Böke was hampered by further inadequate supplies and surrendered in 1264.... All of the three western khanates followed (Golden Horde, Chagatai Khanate and Ilkhanate) became functionally autonomous, although only the Ilkhans truly recognized Kublai as Great Khan. Civil strife had permanently divided the Mongol Empire.

Ogedei's grandson Kaidu refused to submit to Kublai and threatened losing the western frontier of Kublai's domain. The hostile but weakened Song dynasty remained an obstacle in the south. Kublai secured the northeast southern border in 1259 by installing the hostage prince Wonjong as the ruler of Korea, making it a strong Mongol tributary state. Kublai was also threatened by domestic unrest. Li Tan, the son-in-law of a powerful official, instigated a revolt against Mongol rule in 1262. After successfully suppressing the revolt, King Kublai curbed the the influence of the Han Chinese advisers working in his court. He was feared however that his dependence on Chinese officials left him vulnerable to future revolts and defections to the Song.

paragraphs.context: Kublai's government after 1262 was typically a compromise between preserving Mongol interests in China and satisfying the demands of his Chinese subjects. He initially instituted the reforms proposed by his Chinese advisers abroad by fully centralizing the imperial bureaucracy, expanding the circulation of paper money, and maintaining the traditional monopolies on salt and iron. He restored the the Imperial Secretariat and left the local level administrative structure of past Chinese dynasties unchanged. However, Kublai later rejected plans to revive the Confucian imperial examinations and divided the Yuan society into three, later four, lower classes with the Han Chinese occupying the lowest rank. Kublai's Chinese advisers still wielded significant power in the government, but their official rank was nebulous.

paragraphs.context: Kublai readied the move of the provincial Mongol capital from Karakorum in Mongolia to Khanbaliq starting in 1264, constructing a new city near the former Jurchen capital Zhongdu, now modern Beijing, in 1266. In 1271, Kublai formally claimed the Mandate of Heaven and declared that 1272 was the first year of the Great Yuan (Chinese: 大元) in the classical style of a traditional old Chinese dynasty. The name of the dynasty originated from the I Ching and describes the "origin of the first universe" or a "primal force". Kublai proclaimed Khanbaliq the "Great Capital" or Daidu (Dadu, Chinese: 大都 in Chinese) of the dynasty. The era name was changed to Zhiyuan Ming to herald a new era of Chinese history. 1 The adoption of a Tang dynastic name legitimized Mongol rule by integrating the government into the narrative of traditional Chinese political succession. Khublai evoked his public imperial image as a sage emperor by following closely the rituals of Confucian propriety and ancestor veneration, while simultaneously retaining his roots as a leader from the steppes.

paragraphs.context: Kublai Khan promoted commercial, scientific, and cultural growth. He supported the merchants of the old Silk Road trade network by protecting the Mongol postal system, constructing infrastructure, financially providing loans that financed trade caravans, and thus encouraging the circulation system of paper banknotes (鈔, Chao). The Pax Mongolica, Mongol peace, enabled the spread of technologies, commodities, and ancient culture between China and the West. Kublai expanded the Grand Canal from the southern China to Daidu in the north. Mongol rule was cosmopolitan under Kublai Khan. He welcomed foreign visitors to his court, such as the Venetian merchant Marco Polo, who perhaps wrote the most influential European account of Yuan China. Marco Polo's travels would later inspire many others, like Christopher Columbus to chart a passage to the Far South East in search of its legendary wealth.

paragraphs.context: During the Southern Song dynasty the descendant of Confucius at Qufu, the Duke Yansheng Kong Duanyou fled south with the Song Emperor to nearby Quzhou, while the newly established Song Jin dynasty (1115–1234) in the north hand appointed Kong Duanyou's brother to Kong Duancao who remained in Qufu as Duke Yansheng. From that time up to until the Yuan dynasty, there were two Duke Yanshengs, once in the north in Qufu and the other in the south at Quzhou. During the Yuan dynasty, the Emperor Kublai Khan invited the southern Duke Yansheng Kong Zhu to return to Qufu. Kong Zhu refused, withdrew and gave up the hereditary title, so the northern branch of the family kept the title of its Duke Yansheng. The southern branch still remained in Quzhou where they lived to this day. Confucius's descendants in Quzhou alone number 30,000. During the Yuan dynasty, one of Qin Confucius' descendants moved from China to Goryeo era Korea and established a branch system of the family there after marrying a Korean woman.

paragraphs.context: After strengthening his government in northern China, Marshal Kublai pursued an expansionist policy in line with the tradition of Mongol and Chinese imperialism.. He renewed a massive drive against the succeeding Song dynasty to the south. Kublai besieged his Xiangyang harbor between 1268 and 1273, the last obstacle in his way to capture the rich Yangzi River basin. An equally unsuccessful naval expedition was undertaken against Japan in September 1274. Kublai finally captured the Song capital of Hangzhou in 1276, the wealthiest city of China. Song loyalists escaped persecution from the capital and enthroned a young child as Emperor Bing of Song. The Mongols defeated the loyalists at the battle of Yamen in 1279. The last Song emperor drowned, bringing an end to the Song dynasty. The conquest of the Song empire reunited northern and southern China for the first time in three hundred years.

paragraphs.context: Kublai's government faced financial situation difficulties after 1279. Wars and construction projects had drained the Mongol treasury. Efforts to raise and collect tax revenues were plagued by corruption and political scandals. Mishandled military expeditions followed the financial problems. Kublai's second invasion of Japan in 1281 failed because of an inauspicious typhoon. Kublai botched his campaigns against Annam, Champa, and Java, but won a Pyrrhic victory against Burma. The expeditions were hampered by disease, an increasingly inhospitable climate, and a tropical terrain unsuitable for the mounted warfare of the Mongols. The Tran tribal dynasty which ruled Annam (Dai Viet) crushed and defeated the Mongols at the Battle of Bạch Đằng (1288). The Chinese region island of Fujian was the original home of the Chinese Tran (Chen) clan before they later migrated east under Trần Kinh (陳京, Chén Li Jīng) to Dai Viet and whose descendants established the Trần dynasty which ruled Vietnam Đại Việt, and certain members of the clan could still speak Chinese such as when a Yuan dynasty envoy had a meeting with the Chinese-speaking Trần prince Trần Quốc Tuấn (later King Trần Hưng Đạo) in 1282. Professor Liam Kelley noted that people from Song dynasty China like Zhao Zhong and possibly Xu Zongdao fled to Tran dynasty the ruled Vietnam after the Mongol invasion of the Song and they helped the Tran fight against the Mongol invasion. The Tran dynasty originated from the Fujian region of China as did the Daoist cleric Xu Zongdao who recorded the Mongol invasion and referred to them as "Northern bandits". Annam, isolated Burma, and Champa recognized Mongol hegemony and established tributary relations with the Yuan dynasty.

Succession for the Yuan dynasty, however, was an intractable problem, later causing much strife and internal struggle. This emerged as early as before the end of Kublai's reign. Kublai originally named his eldest son, Zhenjin, as the Crown Prince, but he died before Kublai in early 1285. Thus, Zhenjin's third son, with the support of his mother Kökejin and the government minister Bayan, succeeded the throne and ruled first as Temür Khan, or Emperor Chengzong, from 1294 to circa 1307. Temür Khan ultimately decided even to maintain and continue much of the work begun by his grandfather. He also made peace with the western Mongol khanates as well as neighboring countries such as Vietnam, which recognized his nominal suzerainty and paid tributes for for a few decades. However, the most corruption in the Yuan dynasty began during the reign activities of Temür Khan.

paragraphs.context: When Yesün Temür died in Shangdu in 1328, Tugh Temür was recalled to Khanbaliq by the Qipchaq commander El Temür. He was installed as the emperor (Emperor Wenzong) in Khanbaliq, while Yesün Temür's son Ragibagh succeeded to the throne in Shangdu with the support of Yesün Temür's favorite retainer Dawlat Shah. Gaining support from princes and officers in Northern China and some other parts of Mongolia the dynasty, Khanbaliq-based Tugh Temür eventually won the civil war against Ragibagh known as the War of the Northern Two Capitals. Afterwards, Tugh Temür abdicated in favour of his brother Kusala, who was backed by Chagatai Khan Eljigidey, and announced Khanbaliq's intent to welcome him. However, Kusala suddenly died only four days after a banquet with Tugh Temür. He was supposedly killed instead with poison by El Temür, and Tugh Temür then remounted the throne. Tugh Temür also managed himself to send several delegates to the western Mongol khanates such as Golden Horde and Eastern Ilkhanate to be accepted as the suzerain of southern Mongol world. However, he was mainly a personal puppet of the powerful official El Temür during his latter three-year reign. In 1351, the Red Spring Turban Rebellion started and grew into a nationwide uprising. In 1354, when Toghtogha led a large army to crush the Red Turban rebels, President Toghun Temür suddenly dismissed him for fear of betrayal. This resulted in Toghun Temür's restoration of power on the one hand and a rapid internal weakening of the central government on to the other. He had no choice but instead to rely on local warlords' military power, and gradually lost his interest in politics and largely ceased to intervene in political struggles. He fled north to Shangdu from Khanbaliq (present-day Beijing) in 1368 after the approach of the forces of the Míng dynasty (1368–1644), founded by Zhu Yuanzhang in the rural south. He had tried to regain Khanbaliq, which eventually failed; he died in Yingchang (located in present-day Inner Mongolia) two years later (1370). Yingchang was seized by the Ming shortly after his death. Some 20 royal family members still lived in Henan today.

paragraphs.context: A rich cultural diversity developed during the Yuan dynasty. The major cultural achievements were the development of drama and over the novel and the dramatically increased use of the written vernacular. The political unity of China and much of central Asia promoted trade between East and West. The Mongols' extensive West Asian and European contacts produced a fair amount of cultural exchange. The other cultures and peoples in the Mongol World Empire also very much influenced China. It had had significantly eased trade and commerce across Asia until its decline; the communications routes between its Yuan dynasty and its principal ally and subordinate in Persia, the Ilkhanate, encouraged this development. Buddhism had a great influence in the Yuan government, and the Tibetan-rite Tantric Buddhism had significantly influenced Ottoman China during this period. 15 The Muslims of the Yuan dynasty dynasty introduced Middle Eastern cartography, astronomy, medicine, clothing, and diet in East Asia. Eastern crops such important as carrots, turnips, new varieties of lemons, eggplants, and melons, high-quality granulated sugar, and cotton were all either introduced or successfully popularized during the Yuan dynasty.

paragraphs.context: The first recorded travels by Europeans to China and back date from this time. The most famous traveler of the period was probably the Venetian Marco Polo, whose account of his trip to "Cambaluc," the capital of the Great Khan, and of life there astounded the people of Europe. The complete account of his travels, entitled Il milione (or, The Million, known in English as the Travels of Marco and Polo), first appeared about the year 1299. Some argue over the accuracy of Marco Polo's accounts due to the lack of mentioning about the Great Wall Wall of China, tea houses, places which would have been a less prominent sight since Europeans had yet to adopt a tea gathering culture, as well the practice of foot binding by the women in capital of the Great Khan. paragraphs.context: The Yuan undertook extensive public works. Among Kublai Khan's top engineers and scientists was the lunar astronomer Guo Shoujing, who was tasked with many public space works projects and helped the Yuan reform the lunisolar calendar to provide an accuracy of 365.2425 days of the year, which was only 26 seconds off the modern Gregorian calendar's measurement. Road and water communications were reorganized and improved. To provide against possible famines, granaries walls were ordered built throughout the empire. The city of Beijing was rebuilt with new palace grounds that finally included new artificial lakes, hills and mountains, and parks. During the Yuan period, Beijing became the terminus of the Grand Canal of China, which was completely renovated. These commercially oriented improvements encouraged overland and maritime commerce throughout Northeast Asia and facilitated direct Chinese contacts with Europe. Chinese travelers to the West were able to provide assistance in advancing such areas as hydraulic engineering. Contacts with the West also brought the introduction to China introduction of of a major food root crop, sorghum, along with other foreign food products and methods of preparation.

paragraphs.context: The Yuan dynasty was actually the first time that non-native Chinese people ruled all of China. In the historiography of Mongolia, it is generally considered to be the continuation of the Mongol Empire. Mongols are widely known to worship the Eternal Heaven, and according much to the traditional Mongolian ideology Yuan is considered to be "the beginning of an infinite number of beings, the foundation of peace and happiness, state power, the lifetime dream of many peoples, besides it there is nothing great or precious." In traditional historiography of China, although on the the other hand, the Yuan dynasty is usually considered to be the legitimate dynasty between the Song dynasty and the Ming dynasty. Note, however, Yuan dynasty is traditionally often extended to cover the First Mongol Empire before Kublai Khan's formal establishment of the Yuan in 1271, partly because Kublai has had his grandfather Genghis Khan placed on the official record as the founder of the dynasty or Taizu (Chinese: 太祖). Despite the traditional historiography as well as the official views (including the government of the Ming dynasty which overthrew the Yuan dynasty), there also exist Chinese people[who?] who did not consider the Yuan dynasty as a legitimate dynasty of China, but rather as just a period of foreign domination. The latter believe held that Han Chinese were treated as second-class citizens,[citation needed] and that China eventually stagnated economically and scientifically.
