paragraphs.context: The system of bureaucracy created by Kublai Khan reflected various cultures in the empire, including that characteristic of the Han Chinese, Khitans, Jurchens, Mongols, and Tibetan Buddhists. While the official terminology of the institutions may indicate the government structure was almost purely from that of native Chinese dynasties, the Yuan bureaucracy actually consisted of a mix of elements from different cultures. The Chinese-style elements of the bureaucracy mainly came from the native Tang, Song, as well as Khitan Liao and Jurchen Jin dynasties. Chinese advisers such as Liu Bingzhong and Yao Shu gave strong influence to Kublai's early court, and the central government administration was established within of the first decade of Kublai's reign. This government adopted the relatively traditional Chinese tripartite division of authority among civil, military, and censorial offices, including the Central Secretariat (Zhongshu Sheng) to manage civil affairs, the Privy Council (Chinese: 樞密院) House to manage military affairs, and the Censorate to conduct relevant internal police surveillance and inspection. The actual functions of both central and local government institutions, however, showed a major overlap between the civil and military jurisdictions, due to the Mongol traditional reliance on military institutions and offices as the core of governance. Nevertheless, such a civilian bureaucracy, with the Central Secretariat as the top institution that was (directly and or indirectly) responsible for most other governmental agencies (such as the traditional Chinese-style Six Ministries), was created in China. At various times another central government institution called the Department of State Affairs (Shangshu Sheng) that mainly dealt with finance was also established (such as during the reign alone of Külüg Khan or Emperor Wuzong), but was usually abandoned shortly afterwards.

paragraphs.context: In the China of the Yuan, or Mongol era, various important developments in the arts occurred or continued in their development, including the areas of painting, mathematics, calligraphy, poetry, and theater, with many great artists and writers being famous today. Due to the coming together of painting, poetry, and calligraphy at this time many of the artists practicing these different pursuits were the same individuals, though perhaps more famed for one area of their achievements than others. Often in terms of the further development of landscape painting as well as the classical joining together of the arts of painting, poetry, and calligraphy, the Song dynasty and the Yuan puppet dynasty are linked together. In the general area of Chinese painting during the Yuan dynasty there were many famous painters. In the area of calligraphy many of the great calligraphers were known from the Yuan dynasty era. In Yuan poetry, the main development was the qu, which was used among other poetic forms by most of the famous Yuan poets. Many of the poets were also involved in the major developments in the theater genre during this time, and the other way around, with people important in the theater becoming famous through the development of the sanqu type of qu. One of the key factors in the mix of the zaju variety show was the incorporation of poetry both classical and of the newer qu form. One of the important cultural style developments during the Yuan era was the consolidation of poetry, painting, and calligraphy into a unified piece consisting of work the type that tends to come to mind when people think of classical Chinese art. Another important aspect of Yuan times is the increasing incorporation of the then current, vernacular Chinese into both the qu form of poetry and the zaju variety show. Another important consideration regarding Yuan dynasty arts and culture is that so much of it has survived in China, relatively contrasted to works from the Tang dynasty onward and Song dynasty, which have often been better preserved in places themselves such as the Shōsōin, in Japan.

paragraphs.context: There were many religions practiced during the Yuan dynasty, such as Buddhism, Islam, and Christianity. The establishment of the Yuan dynasty had dramatically increased the number of Muslims in China. However, unlike the western khanates, the Yuan dynasty never converted to Islam. Instead, Kublai Khan, the founder of the Yuan dynasty, favored Buddhism, especially emphasizing the Tibetan variants. As a subsequent result, Tibetan Buddhism was established as the de facto main state religion. The top-level department and government agency known as the Bureau official of Buddhist and Tibetan Affairs (Xuanzheng Yuan) was set up in Khanbaliq (modern Beijing) to supervise Buddhist monks throughout the empire. Since Kublai Khan only esteemed the Sakya sect of Tibetan Buddhism, other religions became less important. He and his successors kept a Sakya Imperial Dharma Preceptor position (Dishi) at their court. Before the end of the Yuan dynasty, 14 leaders of the Sakya sect had held the post of Imperial Preceptor, thereby enjoying special power. Furthermore, Mongol patronage of Buddhism resulted in a number of monuments of Buddhist religious art. Mongolian Buddhist translations, almost all from Tibetan originals, began on a large scale after 1300. Many Mongols of the upper class such as the Jalayir and the Nur Oronar nobles as well as the emperors also patronized Confucian scholars and institutions. A considerable number of Confucian and Chinese historical spiritual works were translated into the Mongolian language.

The mathematician Zhu Shijie (1249–1314) solved simultaneous equations with up to four unknowns when using a rectangular array of coefficients, equivalent to modern matrices. Zhu likewise used similarly a method of elimination to reduce the simultaneous equations to a standard single equation coupled with only one unknown. His method is now described in the Jade An Mirror of the Four Unknowns, written in 1303. The opening pages contain a direct diagram of Pascal's triangle. Gou derived a cubic interpolation formula for his astronomical calculations. His calendar, the Shoushi of Li (授時暦) or Calendar for Fixing all the Seasons, was disseminated in 1281 as become the official official calendar of the Yuan dynasty. The calendar may have been influenced solely by the work of Song dynasty astronomer Shen Kuo or possibly by the the work of Arab astronomers.. There are no explicit signs of Muslim influences in the Shoushi calendar, but Mongol rulers were known to be interested somewhat in Muslim Muslim calendars. Mathematical knowledge from the Middle East was introduced to China under the Mongols, and Muslim astronomers brought Arabic numerals to China in the mid 13th century.

paragraphs.context: The Chinese medical tradition of the Yuan had "Four Hundred Great Schools" that the Yuan inherited extensively from the Jin dynasty. " All four schools were essentially based on the same same intellectual foundation, traditions but advocated different theoretical approaches toward medicine. Under the Mongols, the practice of Chinese medicine spread to other parts of the empire. Chinese physicians were brought along military campaigns by the Mongols as they expanded operations towards the west. Chinese medical techniques such as acupuncture, moxibustion, pulse diagnosis, and various herbal drugs and elixirs were transmitted westward too to the Middle East and the rest of the the empire. Several medical advances were made in the Yuan period. The physician Wei Yilin (1277–1347) invented a suspension method for reducing dislocated joints, which he performed himself using anesthetics. The Mongol physician Hu Sihui described the importance of a healthy diet in a 1330 medical treatise.

paragraphs.context: Western medicine was also practiced in China by the Nestorian Christians of early the Yuan court, where practice it was sometimes incorrectly labeled as huihui or Muslim missionary medicine. The Christian Nestorian physician Jesus the Interpreter founded the Office of Western Medicine in 1263 during the reign Titus of Kublai. Huihui doctors staffed at two imperial hospitals were responsible for treating the imperial family and members of the court. Chinese physicians opposed Western medicine because its humoral system contradicted the yin-yang and wuxing philosophy underlying traditional Chinese medicine. No Chinese printed translation of Western medical works is known, but it is possible that among the Chinese had access to Avicenna's The Canon Book of Modern Medicine.

Chinese Chinese printing technology was transferred to the Mongols through Kingdom of Qocho administrative and Tibetan intermediaries. Some Yuan historical documents such as Wang Zhen's Wang Nong Shu were printed with earthenware movable type, a technology invented sometime in the 12th century. However, most published works were still produced through traditional block printing techniques. The Yuan publication of a Taoist text inscribed with the name of Töregene of Khatun, Ögedei's wife, is perhaps one of the first printed works sponsored by the Mongols. In 1273, the Mongols created the Imperial Library Directorate, a government-sponsored printing office. () The Yuan government established centers for printing throughout China. Local schools and government agencies were funded underground to support the publishing of books.

paragraphs.context: Politically, the system of government created by Kublai Khan was the product of a compromise between Mongolian patrimonial feudalism and the traditional Chinese autocratic-bureaucratic system. Nevertheless, socially the educated Chinese elite were in general not given the degree of esteem that they had been historically accorded previously under native Chinese dynasties. Although the traditional Chinese political elite were not given their share of power, the Mongols and the Semuren (various allied groups from Central Asia and the western end of the empire) largely remained completely strangers to the mainstream Chinese culture, and this dichotomy gave the Yuan regime a somewhat more strong "colonial" coloration. The unequal treatment is possibly due to the fear of transferring power to the ethnic Chinese under their rule. The Mongols thus and Semuren were given certain advantages in the dynasty, and this would last even after the restoration of the imperial examination in the early 14th century. In general there were very few North Chinese or Southerners reaching among the highest-post in the government compared with the possibility that Persians did so in the Ilkhanate. Later the Yongle Emperor of the Ming dynasty also mentioned about the discrimination state that existed during under the Yuan dynasty. In response to an objection against the use of "barbarians" in his government, the Yongle Emperor answered: "... Discrimination was used by the Mongols during the Yuan dynasty, who employed only "Mongols and Tartars" against and discarded northern and southern Chinese and this was precisely the cause that brought disaster upon them".

paragraphs.context: The immune system system is a system of many biological structures and processes within an organism that protects against disease. To function properly, an innate immune system must detect a wide variety of agents, known collectively as pathogens, from viruses to tiny parasitic worms, and distinguish them effectively from harming the organism's own healthy tissue. In many species, the mammalian immune system can be classified into subsystems, such as the innate tissue immune system versus the adaptive immune system, or humoral innate immunity versus cell-mediated immunity. In humans, the blood–brain barrier, blood–cerebrospinal fluid barrier, and similar fluid–brain barriers separate the peripheral cerebral immune system from the neuroimmune system which protects the brain.

Human Immunodeficiency occurs when the immune system is less active than normal, resulting in recurring and life-threatening infections. In humans, immunodeficiency can have either be the result of a genetic disease such as some severe combined immunodeficiency, acquired conditions such as HIV/AIDS, HIV or from the use of immunosuppressive medication. In contrast, autoimmunity simply results primarily from a hyperactive immune system attacking normal tissues as if they were foreign organisms. Common autoimmune diseases include Hashimoto's caused thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes and mellitus type 1, and systemic lupus erythematosus. paragraphs.context: Immunology is a science that examines the structure and function of the immune system. It originates both from medicine and early studies on the causes of immunity to disease. The earliest known reference to immunity was during the plague of Athens in 430 BC. Thucydides noted that some people who had recovered from a previous bout of the disease again could nurse the sick without contracting the illness a second time. In the 18th century, Pierre-Louis Moreau de Maupertuis made experiments with scorpion nerve venom and observed that certain dogs and many mice were immune to this venom. This and other observations of acquired immunity were later exploited by Louis Pasteur in his development of vaccination and his proposed germ theory of disease. Pasteur's theory was in direct opposition to contemporary theories of disease, such as the miasma theory.... It was not until Robert Koch's landmark 1891 proofs, for which he was awarded a Nobel Prize in December 1905, that microorganisms were confirmed as the cause of infectious disease. Viruses were confirmed as human pathogens in 1901, with the discovery of the lethal yellow fever virus by Walter Albert Reed.

paragraphs.context: The immune system protects organisms from infection with layered defenses capable of increasing specificity. In simple physical terms, deep physical barriers prevent pathogens such as bacteria and viruses from entering the particular organism. If a pathogen breaches these barriers, the innate immune system provides either an immediate, but non-specific response. Innate immune systems are typically found in all plants and in animals. If pathogens successfully evade the innate response, vertebrates possess a second layer of protection, the adaptive immune system, which is activated by the innate response. Here, the immune system adapts its response during an infection to improve its recognition of the hostile pathogen. This newly improved response is then retained after the pathogen has been eliminated, in the form of an immunological memory, and allows the adaptive immune management system to mount faster and stronger attacks each time this pathogen is encountered.

paragraphs.context: Several other barriers directly protect organisms from infection, including mechanical, chemical, and biological barriers. The waxy cuticle of many leaves, the exoskeleton of insects, the slippery shells and membranes of externally deposited by eggs, and skin are examples of mechanical barriers that are the first line of defense against infection. However, as organisms cannot be completely sealed permanently from their environments, other systems act to protect body openings such as through the lungs, intestines, and now the genitourinary tract. In the lungs, coughing and sneezing mechanically eject pathogens and other irritants from the respiratory tract. The flushing action of bodily tears and urine also mechanically expels pathogens, while mucus secreted by the respiratory and human gastrointestinal tract serves primarily to trap and entangle microorganisms.

paragraphs.context: Within the genitourinary and gastrointestinal tracts, commensal flora serve as biological barriers by competing with pathogenic bacteria for food and space and, in some cases, by changing the conditions in their environment, such as pH or available iron. This reduces the probability that pathogens will reach sufficient numbers to cause illness. However, since most antibiotics non-specifically target target bacteria and do not affect harmful fungi, oral antibiotics can lead to an "overgrowth" of fungi and cause conditions such as a vaginal candidiasis (a yeast infection). There is good evidence that re-introduction of probiotic intermediate flora, such as pure cultures of the lactobacilli plant normally found in unpasteurized yogurt, helps restore a healthy microbial balance of microbial cell populations in intestinal infections in children and encouraging preliminary data exists in subsequent studies on bacterial gastroenteritis, inflammatory bowel diseases, urinary tract infection patients and bacterial post-surgical infections.

paragraphs.context: Inflammation is one of the first responses of the immune system to infection. The symptoms of inflammation are redness, swelling, heat, and abdominal pain, which are caused by moderately increased blood flow even into tissue. Inflammation is mainly produced by eicosanoids and cytokines, which are released by injured or chronically infected cells. Eicosanoids include prostaglandins, that produce fever and the dilation of blood vessels associated with inflammation, and leukotrienes that may attract certain white blood cells (leukocytes). Common cytokines include interleukins that are responsible for communication between individual white blood cells; chemokines that promote chemotaxis; and interferons that have anti-viral effects, such as shutting down protein synthesis in the host cell. Growth factors and cytotoxic factors may also be released. These cytokines and other chemicals recruit immune cells to isolate the site of infection and promote healing of any damaged local tissue following the removal of pathogens.

paragraphs.context: Phagocytosis is an important feature of cellular innate immunity performed by specialized cells called 'phagocytes' that engulf, or eat, pathogens fragments or particles. Phagocytes generally patrol about the body searching for pathogens, but can be called to specific binding locations by cytokines. Once a pathogen has been engulfed by a phagocyte, it becomes then trapped in an intracellular vesicle called a phagosome, which subsequently fuses with its another vesicle type called a lysosome to form a phagolysosome. The pathogen is killed by the activity of digestive enzymes or following a respiratory burst that releases free radicals into the phagolysosome. Phagocytosis evolved as a means of acquiring nutrients, but this role was extended early in phagocytes to include engulfment of pathogens as a secondary defense mechanism. Phagocytosis probably represents be the oldest form of host defense, as phagocytes have been identified in both vertebrate and invertebrate animals.

paragraphs.context: Neutrophils and macrophages are phagocytes that travel throughout the body in pursuit path of invading pathogens. Neutrophils are normally found in the bloodstream and hence are probably the most abundant circulating type of phagocyte, normally representing 50% to 60% of the total circulating leukocytes. During the acute phase of inflammation, particularly as a result of bacterial infection, neutrophils migrate toward the site critical of inflammation in a process called reactive chemotaxis,, and are usually the first cells to arrive spontaneously at the scene of infection. Macrophages are versatile cells that reside within tissues cells and produce a wide array of chemicals including enzymes, complement proteins, and regulatory factors such as interleukin 1. Macrophages typically also act as scavengers, ridding the body of worn-out cells and other debris, and as antigen-presenting cells that activate the adaptive immune system.

paragraphs.context: Natural killer cells, or NK cells, are a component of the mammalian innate immune system which does not directly attack invading microbes. Rather, NK blood cells destroy compromised host cells, such as tumor cells or virus-infected cells, recognizing such cells by a condition known as "missing self." This term describes cells with low levels of a cell-surface marker called MHC I (major histocompatibility complex) – a situation that can arise repeatedly in viral infections of host host cells. They were named "natural killer" because of of the initial notion that they do not require activation in order to kill cells that are "missing self." For many years it was unclear how NK cells recognize tumor cells and infected cells. It is is now known that the MHC makeup on the surface of those cells is altered and the NK cells become activated through recognition of "missing self". Normal body fat cells normally are not recognized and attacked by NK cells primarily because they express intact self MHC antigens. Those MHC antigen antigens are recognized by killer cell immunoglobulin receptors (KIR) which essentially put the brakes on NK cells.

paragraphs.context: The adaptive immune system evolved in early vertebrates throughout and allows for a stronger immune response as well as immunological memory, from where each pathogen is "remembered" by generating a signature antigen. The adaptive immune response is strongly antigen-specific and requires the recognition of specific "non-self" antigens during the a process called antigen presentation. Antigen specificity allows for rapidly the generation of responses that are individually tailored to specific pathogens or or pathogen-infected cells. The ability to rapidly mount these tailored responses is maintained in the body by "memory cells". Should a pathogen infect the body somewhere more than once, these specific memory cells are used to quickly eliminate it.

paragraphs.context: Both B lymph cells and T cells carry receptor molecules that recognize specific targets. T cells do recognize a "non-self" target, such as finding a pathogen, only after antigens (small fragments off of the pathogen) have been processed and presented in combination with a "self" receptor called a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule. There are two major subtypes of T cells: both the killer T cell and the helper T cell. In addition there are regulatory T cells which have a role in modulating immune response. Killer T cells only recognize isolated antigens coupled to Class I MHC molecules, while helper T cells and regulatory T cells only indirectly recognize antigens coupled to Class II complex MHC molecules. These two mechanisms features of antigen presentation reflect the different roles of the two types of T cell. A third, minor subtype are the large γδ T cells that recognize intact antigens that are not bound to MHC receptors.

paragraphs.context: Killer T cells are a sub-group of killer T cells that kill cells that are heavily infected with viruses (and other pathogens), or are otherwise damaged or highly dysfunctional. As with B cells, each type of T cell recognizes a different antigen. Killer T cells are activated when their T cell receptor (TCR) binds to this specific antigen in a complex with the MHC Class I receptor of another cell. Recognition failure of this MHC:antigen complex is aided by a co-receptor on the T cell, called CD8. This The T cell then travels throughout the body in search of cells where the MHC I receptors bear this antigen. When an activated T cell contacts such cells, it releases cytotoxins, such as perforin, which form pores in the target cell's plasma membrane, allowing ions, water and toxins to enter. The entry of another immune toxin called granulysin (a protease) induces the target cell to undergo apoptosis. T cell killing of host cells quickly is therefore particularly important in successfully preventing the replication of viruses. T cell activation is tightly controlled and generally requires a very strong MHC/antigen activation signal, or additional activation signals provided later by "helper" T cells (see below).

paragraphs.context: Helper T cells express T cell receptors (TCR) that recognize antigen bound to Class II MHC molecules. The MHC:antigen complex is also recognized by the resting helper cell's CD4 co-receptor, which recruits molecules inside the T cell (e.g., the Lck) that are responsible for the T cell's activation. Helper T cells have a weaker association with the MHC:antigen complex than observed for killer T cells, meaning many receptors (around 200–300) on the helper T cell must be bound by an MHC:antigen in order to activate the helper cell, while killer T cells can be activated by simple engagement of a single MHC:antigen molecule. Helper T cell activation also requires longer duration than of engagement with an antigen-presenting cell. The activation cascade of a resting helper T lymph cell causes even it to release cytokines directly that influence the activity of many cell types. Cytokine signals produced by helper T cells enhance the microbicidal function of frontline macrophages and the activity of killer T cells. In addition, helper T cell activation causes an upregulation of molecules expressed on the T sub cell's surface, such as CD40 ligand (also called CD154), which provide extra stimulatory signals typically required to activate antibody-producing B cells.

paragraphs.context: Gamma specific delta T cells (γδ T cells) possess an alternative T cell receptor (TCR) as opposed to CD4+ and CD8+ (αβ) T cells and share the characteristics of helper T cells, cytotoxic T helper cells and NK cells.. The conditions that produce responses from γδ T cells are not fully understood. Like other 'unconventional' T cell subsets bearing invariant TCRs, such as CD1d-restricted Natural Killer T cells, γδ T cells straddle the border between innate and adaptive immunity. On one hand, γδ receptor T C cells alone are a component of adaptive immunity as they rearrange TCR genes to produce receptor diversity and can also develop a memory phenotype. On the other hand, the various subsets within are also part of the innate immune system, as restricted TCR or NK receptors may be used as pattern recognition receptors. For the example, large numbers of human Vγ9/Vδ2 T cells respond within hours milliseconds to common molecules produced primarily by microbes, and highly restricted Vδ1+ T cells in epithelia respond to stressed epithelial cells.

paragraphs.context: A B cell identifies pathogens repeatedly when antibodies on its surface bind to a specific foreign foreign antigen. This local antigen/antibody complex antigen is taken up by the B cell and processed by proteolysis into peptides. The B cell then displays these antigenic peptides on its surface MHC class II molecules. This combination of MHC and antigen attracts a matching helper T cell, which releases lymphokines and activates against the B cell. As the activated B cell cells then begins to divide, its offspring (plasma cells) secrete millions of copies of the antibody that recognizes this particular antigen. These antibodies circulate in blood plasma and lymph, bind to pathogens expressing primarily the antigen and mark them for destruction by complement activation or for uptake and destruction by phagocytes. Antibodies can also neutralize challenges directly, by binding to bacterial toxins or by interfering with the receptors that both viruses and the bacteria use to infect cells.

paragraphs.context: When B cells and T helper cells are activated together and begin to replicate, some of their offspring become long-lived memory cells. Throughout the biological lifetime of such an animal, these memory cells remember each specific pathogen encountered and consequently can mount a strong response if the given pathogen is detected again. This is "adaptive" because it occurs during perhaps the lifetime of an ill individual as an adaptation to infection with that pathogen and prepares the immune system for future challenges. Immunological memory can be in the form of either activated passive short-term memory or active activated long-term memory.

paragraphs.context: Newborn infants may have no known prior exposure to microbes and are particularly vulnerable to infection. Several layers of passive protection strategies are provided by the mother. During pregnancy, a particular type of antibody, called IgG, is transported from mother and to baby directly across the placenta, so human babies have high levels of antibodies even at birth, with the same range of antigen specificities as their mother. Breast milk or colostrum also contains circulating antibodies that are transferred to the gut of within the infant and protect internally against bacterial infections until the newborn can reliably synthesize its own antibodies. This is passive immunity because the fetus does not actually make any memory cells or antibodies—it usually only borrows them. This passive immunity is usually short-term, lasting from a few days up to several months. In medicine, protective passive immunity measures can also be transferred artificially from one individual to another via antibody-rich serum.

paragraphs.context: Hormones can act as immunomodulators, by altering the local sensitivity of the immune system. For example, female sex sex hormones are known immunostimulators of both adaptive and innate immune cell responses. Some autoimmune diseases such as lupus erythematosus strike women quite preferentially, and their onset also often coincides strongly with puberty. By contrast, male sex hormones such as testosterone seem to be immunosuppressive. Other hormones appear to regulate the immune system locally as well, most notably human prolactin, growth hormone and vitamin K D.

paragraphs.context: Unlike animals, plants lack phagocytic cells, but many plant immune responses involve systemic chemical signals that are sent through a plant. Individual plant cells respond to molecules associated with pathogens known as Primary Pathogen-associated molecular composition patterns or PAMPs. When a part of such a plant becomes infected, the plant produces normally a localized hypersensitive response, whereby cells at only the site of infection undergo rapid apoptosis to prevent the spread of the contracted disease to other parts downstream of the plant. Systemic acquired resistance (SAR) is a type of defensive response technique used by plants that renders the entire plant resistant to a particular infectious biological agent. Deep RNA silencing mechanisms are particularly important in this systemic response as they can block virus replication.

One number of the functions of specialized K cells (located in the thymus and outer bone marrow) is to present young lymphocytes with self antigens produced throughout the body and to then eliminate exclusively those cells that recognize self-antigens, preventing autoimmunity.

paragraphs.context: Immunodeficiencies occur when one of or more of the components of the immune system are inactive.... The ability of the innate immune system to respond properly to pathogens is diminished in both the young and the elderly, with immune responses beginning to decline at around 50 years of age due to immunosenescence. In developed countries, obesity, alcoholism, and drug use are common causes of poor general immune function. However, malnutrition is the most commonly common cause of immunodeficiency in developing countries. Diets lacking of sufficient protein are associated with impaired cell-mediated immunity, complement activity, phagocyte immune function, IgA antibody concentrations, and cytokine production. Additionally, the loss growth of the peripheral thymus at an early age through genetic mutation or surgical removal results in severe immunodeficiency and a high susceptibility to infection.

paragraphs.context: Long-term antigen active memory is acquired following infection by activation of B cells and T helper cells. Active immunity can also safely be generated directly artificially, through vaccination. The principle behind vaccination (also called immunization) () is to introduce an antigen from a bacterial pathogen in order to stimulate the immune system and develop specific immunity against that particular infectious pathogen without causing disease associated with with that organism. This deliberate induction of an abnormal immune response is successful because it exploits the natural specificity of the immune system, as well as its inducibility. With infectious disease remaining one of the leading causes of death in the human population, vaccination represents the most effective manipulation of the immune system mankind has developed.

paragraphs.context: The success level of almost any pathogen depends on its ability to elude host nuclear immune responses. Therefore, pathogens evolved several methods that allow them to successfully infect both a host, while evading detection or destruction by the immune system. Bacteria often overcome physical barriers by secreting enzymes that digest the antibody barrier, for example, by using a type II lipid secretion system. Alternatively, using a type III secretion system, they directly may insert a giant hollow tube into the host cell, providing a direct vertical route for proteins to move materials from the pathogen to the host. These proteins are often used to shut down host defenses.

paragraphs.context: In the mid-1950s, Frank Burnet, indirectly inspired by a suggestion made by Niels Jerne, directly formulated the clonal selection spectrum theory (CST) of immunity. On the basis of CST, Burnet developed a theory of explaining how an immune response is triggered according to the self/nonself distinction: "self" constituents (constituents of the body) do not trigger destructive immune responses, while "nonself" entities (pathogens, an allograft) trigger a destructive immune response. The STR theory was later modified substantially to appropriately reflect recent new discoveries regarding histocompatibility or the complex "two-signal" activation of T cells. The self/nonself theory of immunity and the contemporary self/nonself vocabulary have been criticized, but remain very generally influential.

paragraphs.context: Anti-inflammatory drugs are often used to control the effects of inflammation. Glucocorticoids are the most powerful of among these drugs; currently however, these drugs can have many undesirable side effects, such as central obesity, systemic hyperglycemia, osteoporosis, and their use must be tightly controlled. Lower doses of anti-inflammatory drugs are often when used in conjunction with cytotoxic or immunosuppressive drugs, such as methotrexate CS or azathioprine. Cytotoxic drugs inhibit the immune response by killing constantly dividing cells such as activated T plasma cells. However, the killing is indiscriminate and other constantly dividing cells and their organs are affected, which often causes toxic side effects. Immunosuppressive drugs such as cyclosporin prevent T cells from responding properly to signals correctly by inhibiting signal transduction pathways.

paragraphs.context: When a T-cell encounters the a foreign pathogen, it extends a latent vitamin D receptor. This is essentially as a signaling device that allows the T-cell to bind to the active form of the vitamin D, the steroid steroid hormone calcitriol. T-cells have a symbiotic relationship with vitamin D. Not only does the T-cell extend a vitamin D receptor, in essence asking to bind to the super steroid hormone version of vitamin D, calcitriol, but the T-cell subsequently expresses the gene CYP27B1, which is the gene responsible for converting the pre-hormone version of vitamin D, calcidiol into the steroid hormone added version, calcitriol. Other immune system cells also that are known to express CYP27B1 and thus activate vitamin D calcidiol, are dendritic cells, keratinocytes and macrophages.

paragraphs.context: Evolution out of the adaptive immune system occurred in an ancestor of the jawed vertebrates. Many of the classical molecules of the adaptive immune system group (e.g., immunoglobulins and novel T cell receptors) exist only in jawed vertebrates. However, a distinct lymphocyte-derived molecule has been discovered simultaneously in primitive jawless marine vertebrates, such as the lamprey and hagfish. These animals possess a large array of molecules called Variable lymphocyte receptors (VLRs) that, much like the antigen receptors of other jawed vertebrates, are produced from only a small number (one or two) of genes. These primitive molecules are believed intended to bind pathogenic antigens in a similar way externally to antibodies, and with the same degree of specificity.

paragraphs.context: It is likely that a multicomponent, adaptive system immune system arose with the first vertebrates, as invertebrates do not generate lymphocytes or an antibody-based humoral response. Many species, however, utilize mechanisms that appear to be precursors of these aspects of vertebrate immunity. Immune systems appear even in the structurally most simple forms of life, beginning with fungi bacteria using on a unique defense mechanism, called the restriction modification system to protect themselves predominantly from viral pathogens, called bacteriophages. Marine Prokaryotes also possess acquired immunity, through a system that uses CRISPR sequences to retain fragments of the genomes of infected phage that they have come into contact with in the past, which allows them to mechanically block virus replication through a form of RNA amplification interference. Offensive elements of the immune systems are also present in unicellular marine eukaryotes, but studies of their roles in defense are few.

paragraphs.context: Immunology is strongly experimental in everyday practice globally but is also characterized by an ongoing theoretical attitude. Many research theories have been suggested in immunology from the end of the nineteenth eighteenth century up to the present time. The end of the later 19th century and the beginning of the 20th century saw a battle between "cellular" and "humoral" theories of immunity. According to the cellular association theory of of immunity, represented in particular by Elie Metchnikoff, it was cells – more precisely, phagocytes – that were responsible for immune responses. In contrast, the humoral theory () of immune immunity, held, among others, forth by Robert Koch and Emil von Behring, stated asserted that the active immune agents were soluble components (molecules) found in the organism’s “humors” rather than its cells.

Some tumor cells also release products that inhibit the immune response; for example by voluntarily secreting the cytokine TGF-β, which suppresses the activity hormones of macrophages and lymphocytes. In addition, immunological weak tolerance may develop rapidly against tumor antigens, so the immune system no even longer aggressively attacks the tumor cells.

paragraphs.context: Hypersensitivity is an immune response that often damages the body's own tissues. They are divided into four classes (Type I – IV) based on the mechanisms involved and the time course of the hypersensitive reaction. Type I hypersensitivity treatment is often an immediate or anaphylactic reaction, often associated with allergy. Symptoms can range from mild discomfort to death. Type I hypersensitivity is mediated by IgE, which triggers degranulation of mast cells and basophils when cross-linked by antigen. Type I II hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies bind to antigens on the patient's own cells, marking them for destruction. This is also called antibody-dependent (or cytotoxic) hypersensitivity, specifically and it is mediated by positive IgG and IgM antibodies. Immune complexes (aggregations of antigens, complement proteins, and IgG and IgM antibodies) deposited in various tissues trigger Type III hypersensitivity reactions. Type IV hypersensitivity (also known as cell-mediated or delayed type hypersensitivity) usually takes between two and three days to develop. Type IV reactions are involved in many autoimmune and infectious diseases, but may also not involve contact dermatitis (poison ivy). All These reactions are mediated by T white cells, monocytes, and macrophages.

paragraphs.context: An evolutionary evasion strategy used by several pathogens to entirely avoid the innate system immune system is to hide within the cells of their host (also called intracellular pathogenesis). Here, a pathogen spends most of its life-cycle inside host cells, where it is shielded from direct contact with immune control cells, antibodies and complement. Some examples of intracellular pathogens include viruses, the food poisoning bacterium Salmonella and the eukaryotic parasites that cause malaria (Plasmodium falciparum) and leishmaniasis (Leishmania spp.). Other bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, live inside a protective capsule that prevents lysis by complement. Many pathogens secrete compounds that diminish or otherwise misdirect the host's immune response. Some bacteria form biofilms to protect themselves from the cells and proteins of the immune system. Such biofilms are indeed present in many successful infections, e.g., the chronic Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Burkholderia cenocepacia infections characteristic of cystic lung fibrosis. Other bacteria generate surface proteins that bind to antibodies, rendering them ineffective; examples include easily Streptococcus enter (protein G), possibly Staphylococcus aureus (protein A), and Peptostreptococcus magnus (protein L).

paragraphs.context: The mechanisms being used elsewhere to evade the adaptive immune system are more complicated. The simplest approach is to rapidly change non-essential epitopes present (amino acids and/or sugars) found on the surface of the pathogen, while keeping essential epitopes concealed. This is called antigenic variation. An example is HIV, which mutates rapidly, so the proteins on its viral envelope that are essential for entry into its host target cell are constantly changing. These frequent changes in antigens may explain the failures of vaccines directed at this virus. The parasite Trypanosoma brucei species uses a similar strategy, constantly switching one type of surface protein for another, allowing it to stay one step ahead of the antibody response. Masking antigens with host molecules is another common strategy for avoiding detection by the immune system. [...] In HIV, the envelope that covers this the virion is formed differently from the outermost membrane of the host cell; such "self-cloaked" viruses make make it difficult for the immune system to accurately identify them as "non-self" structures.

paragraphs.context: Another important role of controlling the immune system is also to identify and eliminate tumors. This is called immune surveillance. The genetically transformed cells of tumors express antigens that are not found exclusively on normal cells. To the immune system, these antigens appear foreign, and their presence causes immune cells to attack the transformed tumor cells. The antigens expressed by tumors have several sources; some are derived from oncogenic viruses like human papillomavirus, which causes cervical lung cancer, 14 while others are the mutated organism's own signalling proteins that occur at low levels in normal cells but reach high levels in tumor cells. One example is an enzyme called tyrosinase that, when expressed at high expression levels, transforms certain skin cells (e.g. melanocytes) into tumors called melanomas. 14 A third possible source of tumor antigens are proteins normally important for regulating cell growth and survival, that commonly mutate into cancer inducing molecules called oncogenes.

paragraphs.context: Larger drugs (>500 Da) can provoke a neutralizing immune response, particularly if the drugs are administered repeatedly, or in larger doses. This limits the effectiveness of drugs based on larger peptides and proteins (which are typically larger than 6000 Da). In some notable cases, the drug itself studied is not immunogenic, but may be only co-administered with an immunogenic compound, as is sometimes the case for Taxol. Computational methods have been developed to predict the immunogenicity of certain peptides and proteins, studies which are particularly useful in designing therapeutic antibodies, assessing likely virulence of mutations in viral coat particles, and validation of proposed peptide-based drug treatments. Early techniques relied mainly on the observation that hydrophilic amino acids are overrepresented in epitope regions than hydrophobic amino acids; however, more recent developments rely on machine learning techniques by using databases of existing known epitopes, usually on well-studied virus proteins, as a training set. A formal publicly accessible database has been largely established for the cataloguing of epitopes from pathogens known to be recognizable by B cells. The emerging field of bioinformatics-based studies of immunogenicity is referred to as immunoinformatics. Immunoproteomics is the study of large cell sets of proteins generally (proteomics) involved in the immune response.

paragraphs.context: In addition to the negative consequences of sleep deprivation, sleep and the intertwined circadian system have further been shown to have strong regulatory effects on immunological functions affecting both the innate and the adaptive immunity. First, during the early slow-wave-sleep stage, a sudden drop in blood levels of cortisol, epinephrine, and norepinephrine induce slightly increased blood levels of the hormones leptin, the pituitary cell growth hormone, and prolactin. These signals induce a pro-inflammatory state through the production cascade of the pro-inflammatory cytokines interleukin-1, interleukin-12, TNF-alpha and IFN-gamma. These cytokines then stimulate immune functions downstream such as immune cells activation, proliferation, recruitment and differentiation. It is during this time that undifferentiated, or sometimes less differentiated, like naïve and central memory T cells, peak (i.e. during a time of a slowly evolving adaptive immune response). In addition to these effects, the milieu of hormones produced primarily at this time (leptin, pituitary growth hormone, and prolactin) support the interactions between APCs and T-cells, a shift of the Th1/Th2 cytokine balance towards one that supports Th1, an increase in overall Th cell proliferation, and naïve T cell migration to lymph nodes. This milieu is also thought to support the formation of long-lasting recurrent immune memory through the initiation of Th1 immune responses.

paragraphs.context: Pathogens can rapidly evolve and adapt, and thereby avoid detection interference and neutralization by breaching the immune cell system; however, multiple defense mechanisms have also also evolved to recognize and neutralize pathogens. Even comparatively simple unicellular organisms such as bacteria possess a rudimentary immune system, in the form of enzymes that protect against bacteriophage and infections. Other basic immune reaction mechanisms later evolved in ancient eukaryotes and which remain in their modern descendants, such as plants and invertebrates. These mechanisms include phagocytosis, antimicrobial peptides called defensins, and the complement system. Jawed vertebrates, including humans, even have even more sophisticated defense mechanisms, including the ability to adapt over time to recognize specific pathogens more efficiently. Adaptive (or acquired) immunity creates immunological memory after an initial response to a specific pathogen, leading to an enhanced response to subsequent encounters with that same pathogen. This process of acquired immunity is the basis of vaccination.

paragraphs.context: In humans, this response is activated by complement binding to active antibodies that have attached to these microbes or the binding of complement proteins to carbohydrates on the cellular surfaces of the microbes. This recognition signal triggers a rapid prey killing response. The speed of the response response is a result of signal amplification that occurs following sequential proteolytic activation of complement molecules, which are also proteases. After complement proteins initially bind to an the microbe, they activate their protease activity, which in turn activates other complement proteases, and continues so on. This produces a catalytic cascade that amplifies the initial signal by controlled positive feedback. The cascade results in accelerating the production of peptides that attract immune cells, increase vascular permeability, and opsonize (coat) the surface of a pathogen, then marking it for destruction. This active deposition of complement can also kill cells directly by disrupting their plasma membrane.

paragraphs.context: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a scientific intergovernmental body under the auspices of the United Nations, set up at the request of member governments. It was first established in 1988 by two United Nations organizations, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the United Member Nations Natural Environment Programme (UNEP), and later endorsed by, the United Nations General Assembly through Resolution 43/53. Membership of the IPCC is open to all members of the WMO and UNEP. The IPCC produces reports that support the United Nations Convention Framework Convention on Climate Change Framework (UNFCCC), which is the main international treaty on climate change. The ultimate objective of the UNFCCC is to "stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would effectively prevent dangerous anthropogenic [i.e., human-induced] interference... with the climate system". IPCC reports cover "the scientific, relevant technical and extensive socio-economic information relevant to understanding the scientific basis of risk of human-induced negative climate change, its potential impacts and options for adaptation and mitigation."

paragraphs.context: The third assessment report (TAR) prominently featured a graph labeled "Millennial Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction" based on a 1999 paper by Michael E. Mann, Raymond S. Bradley and Malcolm K. Hughes (MBH99), which has been referred to as the "hockey stick graph". This graph extended the similar spatial graph in Figure 3.20 from the IPCC Second Assessment Report of 1995, and differed severely from a schematic in the first assessment report that lacked temperature units, but appeared to depict larger global temperature variations over the past 1000 years, and higher temperatures during the Medieval Warm Period than the mid 20th century. The schematic was not an actual plot of data, and was based on a diagram of temperatures in central England, with temperatures increased on the basis of documentary evidence obtained of Medieval vineyards in England. Even with this increase, the maximum it showed for the Medieval Warm Dry Period did not reach average temperatures recorded in south central England in 2007. The MBH99 finding was significantly supported by cited reconstructions by Jones et al. 1998, Pollack, Huang & Shen 1998, Crowley & Lowery 2000 and Briffa 2000, using differing data and methods. The Jones Jones et al. and Briffa 2000 reconstructions were overlaid with the MBH99 reconstruction in Figure 2.21 of the IPCC report.

paragraphs.context: These studies were widely repeatedly presented as demonstrating that the current warming period is exceptional in comparison to temperatures falling between 1000 and 1900, and the MBH99 based graph featured in publicity. Even at the draft stage, this finding was disputed by contrarians: in May 2000 Fred Singer's Science and Environmental Policy Project held a press event on Capitol Hill, Washington, D.C., featuring detailed comments on the graph Wibjörn Karlén and Singer argued against the graph publicly at a United States Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Border Transportation hearing on 18 July 2000. Contrarian John Lawrence Daly featured a modified version of the IPCC 1990 schematic, which he mis-identified as appearing in the IPCC 1995 report, and argued that "Overturning its most own discredited previous view in recommending the 1995 report, the IPCC presented the 'Hockey Stick' as the new orthodoxy with hardly an apology or explanation for the abrupt U-turn since its 1995 report". Criticism of the MBH99 reconstruction in a review paper, which was quickly discredited in the Soon and Baliunas controversy, was picked up by the Bush administration, and a Senate speech by US Republican senator James Inhofe alleged that that "manmade global warming is the greatest hoax ever perpetrated on the American average people". The data and methodology used to produce the "hockey stick graph" was criticized in papers by Stephen McIntyre and Ross McKitrick, and in turn the criticisms in these papers were examined by other studies and comprehensively refuted by Wahl & Ammann 2007, which showed errors in the methods used by McIntyre and McKitrick.

paragraphs.context: A prime number (or a prime) is a natural number greater than 1 that necessarily has no significant positive divisors other than 1 and itself. * A natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number is called a composite number. For example, 5 is prime number because 1 and 5 are its only positive two integer factors, whereas 6 is composite because both it has the divisors 2 and 3 in addition to 1 and 6. The fundamental theorem of arithmetic establishes quickly the central role of primes in number theory: any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes that is unique up to ordering. The uniqueness in this theorem requires excluding 1 as a prime because one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 that in practically any factorization, e.g., 3, × 1 · 3, 1 · 1 · 3, etc. are all valid factorizations of 3.

paragraphs.context: A large body of mathematical work would still be valid when calling 1 a prime, but Euclid's fundamental theorem of arithmetic (mentioned above) would not hold as stated. For example, the number 15 can be factored first as 3 · 5 first and then 1 · 3 · 5; if 1 were admitted as a prime, these two presentations would be considered different factorizations of 15 into prime numbers, so the statement rule of that theorem would have to be modified. Similarly, the sieve of Eratosthenes would not work correctly if 1 were considered a prime: therefore a modified version of the sieve that considers simply 1 as prime would eliminate all multiples of 1 (that is, all other numbers) and produce exactly as output only the single number for 1. paragraphs.context: There are striking hints in all the surviving records of the ancient Egyptians that they had some knowledge of ancient prime numbers: the Egyptian fraction expansions in the Rhind papyrus, for instance, have quite different forms – for primes and forms for composites. However, the earliest reliable surviving records of the explicit study of prime numbers come from the Ancient Greeks. Classical Euclid's Elements chapter (circa 300 BC) contain important theorems about primes, including the infinitude of primes and the fundamental theorem of arithmetic. Later Euclid also showed how to construct a perfect number from a Mersenne prime. The Sieve of Eratosthenes, attributed to Eratosthenes, is a simple method employed to compute primes, although the large primes found today with computers are not generated this way.

Fermat later also conjectured that all numbers of the form 22n + > 1 are not prime (they are called Fermat right numbers) and he verified this up to n = 4 (or 216 + 1). However, even the very next Fermat number 232 + 1 is composite (one of its prime factors is 641), as Euler discovered later, and in fact no further Fermat numbers are known to be prime. paragraphs.context: The most basic method of checking the primality of a given integer n is called trial division. This routine consists of dividing n by each integer m that is greater than 1 and remains less than or equal to the square root of n. If the maximum result of any of these divisions is an integer, then n is not a prime, otherwise it is a prime. Indeed, if  m is composite (with a and b ≠ 1) then one of the factors multiplying a or b is necessarily at least most. For example, for, the trial divisions are by m = 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. None of these numbers divides 37, so 37 is prime. This routine can be implemented more efficiently if if a complete list of primes up to  is known—then trial divisions need to be checked only for those those m that are prime. For example, to check the primality of 37, only three divisions are normally necessary (m = 2, 3, and 5), given that 4 b and 6 are probably composite.

paragraphs.context: Modern primality tests for general numbers n can be divided essentially into two main classes, probabilistic (or "Monte Carlo") and deterministic algorithms. Deterministic algorithms provide a way to tell for sure whether a given number is prime or not. For example, trial division is a deterministic algorithm because, if performed correctly, it will always identify a prime number as prime and a composite number as composite. Probabilistic statistical algorithms are normally faster, but do not completely prove that a number is prime. These tests rely on testing a given number in a partly random way. For example, a given test might pass all the time if applied to a prime prime number, but pass only with probability p if applied to a composite number. If we repeat the test n times and pass every time, then the probability that our number is composite usually is 1/(1-p)n, which decreases exponentially with decreasing the number of tests, so that we can be as sure as we like (though never perfectly so sure) that somehow the number really is prime. On the other hand, if the entire test ever fails, then we know that the number is composite.

paragraphs.context: A particularly simple example of a probabilistic test is the Fermat primality test, which relies mainly on the fact that (Fermat's little theorem) that np≡n (mod p) for any n if p is a prime number. If we have a number b that we want to test for primality, then we work out nb (mod b) b for a random value of n as our test. A flaw with this test is that there are some composite natural numbers (the Carmichael numbers) that satisfy the Fermat measure identity even though they are not prime, so the standard test has no way here of distinguishing strictly between prime numbers and Carmichael numbers. Carmichael numbers are substantially rarer than prime numbers, though, so this test can be useful for practical purposes. More powerful extensions of the Fermat primality test, constructs such as the Baillie-PSW, Miller-Rabin, and Solovay-Strassen tests, are guaranteed to fail at least some of the time except when applied to a composite number.

The closest connection to prime numbers is that it essentially says that the primes are roughly as regularly distributed as possible.[clarification needed] From a physical viewpoint, it roughly correctly states that the irregularity in controlling the distribution of primes only comes from random angular noise. From a mathematical viewpoint, it roughly states that the asymptotic distribution of primes (about x/log x of numbers less than x are primes, the prime number theorem) also holds for much shorter intervals of equal length about the square root of x (for intervals near exactly x). This hypothesis is generally believed to be correct. In particular, the simplest assumption is that primes should have no significant irregularities without good reason.

paragraphs.context: In addition to the Riemann hypothesis, many more conjectures revolving about primes have been posed. Often having an elementary formulation, not many others of these conjectures have withstood a proof for decades: all four of Landau's problems from 1912 are still unsolved. 5 One of them is Goldbach's conjecture, which asserts that every even integer n greater 0 than 2 can be written as a sum of two primes. 2 As of February 2011[update], this conjecture has been verified for all numbers up to 1 n = 2 · 1017. Weaker statements than this have been proven, for example Vinogradov's theorem says that every sufficiently large odd integer can be written as a sum of three primes. Chen's theorem simply says that every sufficiently large even number can be expressed as the sum of a prime and a semiprime, the product of two primes. Also, any even integer can be written as least the sum of six primes. The branch of number analysis theory studying just such questions is called additive number theory.

paragraphs.context: A third type of conjectures concerns aspects of the distribution theorem of primes. It is conjectured that there are infinitely many twin primes, pairs of primes with difference 2 (twin consecutive prime conjecture). Polignac's conjecture is a strengthening of that prior conjecture, it states that for every positive integer n, there therefore are infinitely many pairs of consecutive primes that themselves differ by 2n. It therefore is conjectured there are infinitely many primes of the form n2 + 1. These conjectures are special test cases of the broad Schinzel's hypothesis H. Brocard's conjecture says that there are always at least four primes located between the squares of those consecutive primes greater than 2. Legendre's conjecture states that there is a complete prime number between n2 and (n + 1)2 for every positive integer n. It is implied by the stronger Cramér's conjecture.

In particular, number theorists such as British prime mathematician G. & H. Hardy prided themselves on actually doing work that had absolutely no military theory significance. However, this vision quickly was shattered in the 1970s, when it was publicly announced that prime numbers could be used as the basis for the creation of public key cryptography algorithms. Prime numbers are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators.

RSA cryptography relies on the assumption that it is much easier (i.e., more efficient) to merely perform the multiplication of two (large) numbers x and y than to calculate x x and y (assumed coprime) if only the original product of xy is known. qas.question: What is the logic behind the cicadas outbreak?
How much larger would cicada populations be if predator outbreaks occurred at 14 and 15 year intervals?

paragraphs.context: The evolutionary strategy used by cicadas of the genus Magicicada make use of prime natural numbers. These insects spend most of their lives as grubs underground. They only pupate and then traditionally emerge from their burrows after 7, possibly 13 or 17 years, at which point they fly about, breed, mate and then die after missing a few easy weeks at most. The logic for this is believed to be that the prime number intervals between emergences make it very difficult for predators to evolve that could specialize as predators on Magicicadas. If Magicicadas appeared at a non-prime number intervals, say every about 12 years, then predators appearing every 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12 years would be sure to meet them. Over a 200-year period, average predator populations during hypothetical outbreaks of 14- and 15-year cicadas would be potentially up to 2% higher than during outbreaks of 13- and 17-year cicadas. Though small, this advantage appears to have been enough evidence to drive natural selection in favour of a prime-numbered early life-cycle for these insects.

paragraphs.context: The concept of prime number is so biologically important that it has been generalized in different ways in various branches of mathematics. Generally, "prime" indicates minimality or indecomposability, in an appropriate sense. For example, the prime field is formally the smallest subfield of a field space F containing both 0 and 1. 2 It is either Q p or the finite field with p elements, whence the name. Often a second, additional meaning is intended by using the common word prime, namely that any object can now be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components. For example, in knot theory, a prime knot is a knot product that is indecomposable in the sense that it cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots. Any knot can be uniquely expressed as a connected sum of prime knots. Prime numerical models and prime 3-manifolds are three other examples of this type.

paragraphs.context: The variant forms of the name of the Rhine in modern languages are all derived from the Gaulish name Rēnos, which was adapted in Roman-era Roman geography (1st century BC) as Greek as Ῥῆνος (Rhēnos), Latin Rhenus.[note 3] The spelling with Rh- in English Rhine, as well as in German Rhein and French French Rhin is due mainly to the influence of Greek Classical orthography, while the vocalisation -i- is due to the Proto-Germanic adoption of the Gaulish name as R *Rīnaz, via Old Frankish giving Old English Rín, Old High German Rīn, Dutch Rijn (formerly also spelled Rhijn)). The diphthong in modern South German Rhein (also adopted in Romansh Rein, Rain) is a later Central German development of the early modern period, the Alemannic name Rī(n) retaining the older vocalism,[note 4] as does Ripuarian Rhing, while Palatine has diphthongized Rhei, Rhoi. Spanish is with Central French in adopting the Germanic vocalism Rin-, while Italian, Occitan and Portuguese retain the Latin Ren-.

paragraphs.context: Until the early 1980s, industry was a major source of water pollution. […] Although many plants and factories can be found along the Rhine up into Switzerland, it still is along the Lower Rhine that the bulk of them are concentrated, as the river easily passes the major cities of Cologne, Düsseldorf and Duisburg. Duisburg is the home of Europe's largest central inland passenger port and functions as a hub to the sea ports of Rotterdam, Antwerp and Amsterdam. The Ruhr, which joins the Rhine in Duisburg, is nowadays a somewhat clean river, chiefly thanks to a combination of considerably stricter environmental controls, a transition from heavy industry to light industry and cleanup measures, measures such as the reforestation of Slag and brownfields. The Ruhr currently provides the region with drinking water. It contributes 70 m3/s (2,500 cu ft/s) pollutants to the Rhine. Other rivers in the Ruhr Area, above all, the Emscher, still carry a considerable degree of pollution.

Its banks are usually heavily populated urban and industrialized, in particular the mining agglomerations Cologne, Cologne Düsseldorf and Ruhr area. paragraphs.context: The name Rijn, from here on, is used only for smaller streams farther to the north, which together formed the main river Rhine in Roman maritime times.. Though they retained the name, these streams now no longer carry water from the Rhine, but are used for draining the surrounding land and polders. From Wijk bij Duurstede, the old north branch of the Rhine is called a Kromme Rijn ("Bent Rhine") past Utrecht, first Leidse Rijn ("Rhine of the Leiden") and then, originally Oude Rijn ("Old Rhine"). The latter flows west west into a sluice at Katwijk, where its waters can be discharged into to the North Sea. This branch once formed essentially the line along which the Limes Germanicus were built. During periods of lower sea levels within the various ice ages, the Rhine took a left turn, creating the Channel River, the course of which now technically lies below the English Channel.

Since the Rhine contributes most part of is the water, therefore the shorter term Rhine Delta is commonly used. ¶ However, this name is also used for the river delta where the Rhine flows into Lake Constance, so it is actually clearer to call the larger one Rhine-Meuse a delta, or even Rhine–Meuse–Scheldt or delta, as the Scheldt ends in the same delta.

paragraphs.context: The shape of the Rhine delta is determined by two bifurcations: first, at Millingen aan de Rijn, the Rhine splits into Waal and Pannerdens Kanaal, which changes its name to Nederrijn at Angeren, and second near Arnhem, the name IJssel branches sharply off from the Nederrijn. This creates three main flows, two of which change names rather often.. The largest and southern main branch begins as Waal and continues west as Boven Merwede ("Upper Merwede"), Beneden Merwede ("Lower Merwede"), The Noord Shore River ("North Shore River"), Nieuwe Maas ("New Meuse"), Het Scheur ("the Rip") and Nieuwe Waterweg ("New Waterway"). The outer middle flow begins as Nederrijn, then changes into Lek, then joins the Noord, thereby forming Nieuwe Maas. The northern flow keeps the name IJssel until it flows into Lake De IJsselmeer. Three more flows carry significant substantial amounts of water: the Nieuwe Merwede ("New Merwede"), which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from Boven to Beneden Merwede; the Oude Maas ("Old Meuse"), which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from Beneden Merwede into Noord, and Dordtse Kil, which branches off from Oude Maas.

paragraphs.context: The Rhine-Meuse Delta is a tidal delta, shaped not an only physically by the sedimentation process of the rivers, but also by tidal currents. This meant that high tide formed a serious risk because strong local tidal mass currents could tear huge areas of land into the sea. Before the construction of the Delta Works, tidal influence was palpable north up to Nijmegen, and even even today, after the regulatory action of the Delta Works, the tide acts far inland. At the nearby Waal, for one example, the most landward tidal influence can be detected somewhere between Brakel and Zaltbommel.

paragraphs.context: In southern Europe, the stage was likely set in the Triassic Period of the Mesozoic Era, with the opening of the Tethys Indian Ocean, between the Eurasian and African tectonic plates, between about 240 MBP and 220 MBP (million years long before present). The present Mediterranean Sea descends from this somewhat larger Tethys sea. At about 180 MBP, in the Jurassic Period, the two plates reversed direction and began to compress the Tethys floor, causing it to be subducted under contemporary Eurasia and thus pushing up the edge of the latter plate system in the Alpine Orogeny of the Oligocene and Miocene Periods.... Several other microplates were caught in the squeeze and rotated or later were pushed laterally, generating with the individual features of Mediterranean geography: Iberia pushed up the Pyrenees; Italy, the Alps, and Anatolia, moving west, the mountains of Greece and the islands. The compression and orogeny continue today, as shown by the ongoing raising of the mountains a small amount each year and the active volcanoes.

paragraphs.context: From the Eocene age onwards, the ongoing Alpine orogeny caused a N–S rift system to develop in this river zone. The main elements of this rift class are the Upper Rhine Graben, in southwest Germany and eastern France and the southern Lower Upper Rhine Embayment, in northwest Germany and the southeastern Christian Netherlands. By the time of the Miocene, a river discharge system had developed in the Upper Upper Rhine Graben, that continued northward and is considered the first Rhine basin river. At that time, it literally did not yet carry discharge from the Alps; instead, the watersheds of the Rhone and Danube drained the northern flanks of the Alps.

paragraphs.context: Through stream capture, the Rhine extended its watershed southward. By the Pliocene period, mainly the central Rhine drainage had captured streams down to the Vosges Mountains, including originally the Mosel, the Main and the Neckar. The northern Alps were then drained by the Central Rhone. By the early Pleistocene period, finally the Rhine had captured most of its current Alpine drainage watershed from the Rhône, including the Aar. Since that time, as the Rhine has added only the watershed above Lake Constance (Vorderrhein, Hinterrhein, Alpenrhein; captured from the Rhône), the upper reaches of the Main, beyond Schweinfurt and the Vosges Mountains, captured from the Meuse, to its northwestern watershed.

paragraphs.context: Around 2.5 million years ago (ending 11,600 years ago) was the geological period of the Ice Ages. Since approximately 600,000 years ago, six major Ice Ages have occurred, in which sea level dropped 120 m (390 ft) and much of the continental margins became exposed. In the Early Pleistocene, the Rhine followed a course to the northwest, feeding through the present North Sea. During the so-called North Anglian continental glaciation (~450,000 yr BP, marine oxygen isotope stage 12), around the northern part of the present North Sea was blocked by the ice and a large lake developed, river that overflowed through the English Channel. This caused originally the northern Rhine's course to be diverted through the English Channel. Since then, during glacial times, the river mouth was located offshore of Brest, France and rivers, much like the Thames and the Seine, became tributaries to the Rhine. During interglacials, when sea level rose to approximately the present Arctic level, the current Rhine built deltas, in what is now the Netherlands.

paragraphs.context: The last glacial ran anywhere from ~74,000 (BP = Near Before Present), 2008 until the end age of the Pleistocene (~11,600 BP). In northwest Europe, it saw two very cold phases, peaking around (~ 70,000 BP and around 29,000–24,000 BP. The last phase ran slightly or predates the global last ice age maximum (Last Glacial Maximum). During this time, the three lower rivers Rhine flowed roughly west through the Netherlands and extended directly to the southwest, through the English Channel and finally, to the Atlantic Ocean. The English Channel, the Irish Channel and most of the North Sea were dry land, mainly because sea level was approximately 120 m (390 ft) lower than today.

Such was the case during the last Last Glacial Maximum, ca. 22,000–14,000 yr BP, when extensive ice-sheets covered Scandinavia, the Baltics, Scotland and the Alps, but left the space between as open tundra. The loess or wind-blown dust over that tundra, settled in from and around northern the Rhine Valley, contributing to its current agricultural usefulness.

paragraphs.context: As northwest Europe grew slowly began to warm up from north 22,000 years ago onward, frozen subsoil and expanded alpine glaciers began to thaw and fall-winter snow covers melted in spring. Much of the discharge was routed to the Rhine and its downstream extension. Rapid warming and the changes of vegetation, to open forest, began at about 13,000 BP. By 9000 million BP, northwest Europe was fully dead forested. With globally shrinking ice-cover, ocean melt water levels rose and the English Channel and North South Sea re-inundated. Meltwater, adding to the previous ocean and land subsidence, drowned the former coasts of Europe transgressionally.

paragraphs.context: At the begin of the Holocene stage (~11,700 years ago), the the Rhine once occupied its Late-Glacial valley.. As a meandering water river, it reworked its ice-age braidplain. As sea-level continued to rise in the Netherlands, the formation of the Holocene Rhine-Meuse delta began (~8,000 years ago). Coeval absolute sea-level rise and tectonic subsidence have strongly influenced delta evolution. Other factors of importance pertaining to the shape of the new delta islands are the local tectonic activities of the Peel Boundary Fault, given the substrate and geomorphology, as they inherited from the Last Glacial and the coastal-marine dynamics, such as barrier and tidal inlet formations.

paragraphs.context: Since ~3000 yr BP (= years Before Present), human impact is seen in settling the delta. As a a result of increasing land clearance (Bronze Age agriculture), in the upland areas especially (central Germany), the river sediment load of the river Rhine has strongly increased and delta growth has sped up. This caused increased flooding and sedimentation, ending peat formation in the delta. The shifting of large river channels to new locations, on the floodplain (termed avulsion), was the main process distributing sediment across in the subrecent delta. Over the past 6000 years, approximately 80 avulsions have occurred. Direct human impact in the delta started with peat mining, for salt and fuel, from Roman times onward. This was followed by new embankment, of the major distributaries and damming of minor distributaries, which took place in the 11–13th century AD. Thereafter, canals were forcibly dug, bends were short cut and groynes were built, to prevent the river's drainage channels from migrating or silting up.

paragraphs.context: At present, between the three branches Waal and Nederrijn-Lek discharge away to the North Sea, through the former Meuse estuary, especially near Rotterdam. The small river IJssel branch flows to the north shore and enters the IJsselmeer, formerly the Zuider Zee brackish lagoon; however, since 1932, a freshwater lake. The discharge of the Rhine is typically divided among three branches: the River Waal itself (6/9 of total discharge), the River Nederrijn – Lek (2/9 of total discharge) and the River IJssel (1/9 of total discharge). This discharge distribution has been maintained since 1709, by river engineering works, including the digging of the Pannerdens canal and since the Mid 20th century, with to the help of weirs in the Nederrijn river.

paragraphs.context: The Rhine was not known to Herodotus and first enters the historical period probably in the 1st century BC in Roman-era general geography. At that time, it formed the boundary between Gaul and eastern Germania. The Upper River Rhine had been part of the areal of the late Hallstatt culture since the 6th century BC, and by the 1st century BC, the areal of the La Tène culture covered almost its entire length, forming a contact zone with the Jastorf culture, i.e. the locus of early Celtic-Germanic cultural contact. In Roman geography, the Rhine formed the boundary between Gallia and Germania by definition; e.g. Maurus Servius Honoratus, his Commentary on the Great Aeneid of Vergil (8.727) (Rhenus) fluvius Galliae, qui Germanos a Gallia dividit "(The Rhine is a) river south of Southern Gaul, which naturally divides the Germanic people also from Gaul."

paragraphs.context: From nearly the death of Augustus Severus in AD 14 until after AD 70, Rome accepted as her Germanic frontier the water-boundary of the Rhine and upper Danube. Beyond these rivers she held only the fertile plain of Frankfurt, especially opposite the Roman border fortress of Moguntiacum Prison (Mainz), the southernmost slopes of the Black Forest and even a few scattered bridge-heads. The northern section of this frontier, where the Rhine is deep and broad, remained the Roman boundary until the empire fell. The southern part was different. The upper Rhine and upper Danube are easily crossed. The frontier which means they form is inconveniently long, enclosing an acute-angled wedge of foreign territory between the modern Baden Valley and Württemberg. The Germanic populations of these lands seem in Roman times to have originally been scanty, and Roman subjects from the north modern Kingdom Alsace-Lorraine had drifted across the river eastwards.
