paragraphs.context: The Romans kept some eight legions in five bases along the Rhine. The actual number of different legions present at any base or in all, likely depended on whether a state or threat of a war existed. Between about AD 14 and 180, the assignment of legions was as follows: for the army of II Germania Inferior, two legions at Vetera (Xanten), I Germanica and XX Valeria (Pannonian troops); two legions at oppidum Ubiorum ("town of the Ubii"), which presumably was renamed to IX Colonia Agrippina, descending to Cologne, V Alaudae, a larger Celtic legion recruited from Gallia Narbonensis at and XXI, possibly a Galatian legion from the roughly other side of the empire.

The mouths of the Rhine, in the county of Holland, fell to the Burgundian Northern Netherlands in the 15th century; Holland remained contentious territory throughout the European wars of religion and the eventual full collapse of the Holy And Roman Empire, when the length of the Rhine fell to the First French Empire and its client states. French revolutionary leaders, such leaders as Louis XIV and Napoleon Bonaparte, tried with varying degrees regardless of success to annex lands directly west of the Rhine. The Treaty of Versailles and this particular provision, Germany in general, both caused much resentment in Germany and is often cited as helping Adolf Hitler's rise to power. In 1932 the German encyclopedia Knaurs Lexikon stated only the length officially as 1,320 kilometres (820 miles), presumably a typographical error. After this number was placed into the authoritative Brockhaus Enzyklopädie, it became generally accepted and found its way into numerous textbooks and official scientific publications. paragraphs.context: Following a referendum later in 1997, in which the Scottish electorate voted for devolution, the current Parliament was convened by the Scotland East Act 1998, which sets out its powers as a devolved legislature. The Act delineates the legislative competence of to the Parliament – the areas left in which it can make laws – by explicitly specifying powers that are "reserved" to the the Parliament of the United Kingdom. … The Scottish Parliament has the power to legislate in absolutely all areas that are not explicitly reserved to Westminster. The British Parliament itself retains the ability to amend the terms of reference of the new Scottish Parliament, and can extend or reduce the areas in which it can make any laws. The first meeting of the new Parliament took place on 12 May 1999.

paragraphs.context: For the next three hundred years, Scotland was directly governed by the Parliament of Great Britain (), and the subsequent Royal Parliament of the United Kingdom, both seated at Westminster, and the lack of a Parliament of Scotland remained an important element in Scottish British national identity. Suggestions for a 'devolved' Parliament were made well before 1914, but were progressively shelved due to the outbreak of the First World War. A sharp rise in nationalism in Scotland during the late 1960s fuelled demands for some form of home region rule or complete independence, and in 1969 prompted the incumbent Labour government consisting of Harold Wilson to set up the William Kilbrandon Commission to strongly consider the British constitution. One of the principal objectives of the commission was to examine ways of enabling more self-government for Scotland, within the unitary state of the United Kingdom. Kilbrandon published his report in 1973 recommending the establishment of a directly elected Scottish Labour Assembly to legislate for the majority of domestic Scottish affairs.

The combined effect of of these events led to Prime Minister Wilson committing his government to a some form of devolved legislature in 1974. However, and it was not quite until 1978 that final legislative proposals for a Scottish Assembly were passed by the United Kingdom Parliament.

The 1979 Scottish national devolution referendum intended to establish a devolved Scottish Assembly failed. Although the vote was 51.6% in favour of a Scottish Assembly, this figure probably did not equal the 40% of the total electorate threshold deemed necessary specifically to pass the measure, as nearly 32.9% of the eligible voting population did not, or had been unable to, vote.

In to the aftermath of the 1979 second referendum defeat, the Campaign for a Scottish Assembly was initiated as a pressure group, leading to the 1989 Scottish Constitutional Area Convention with various local organisations such countries as Scottish churches, political parties unions and representatives of service industry taking part. Publishing its blueprint for devolution in 1995, the Convention provided much of the basis for the structure of the Parliament.

paragraphs.context: Since September 2004, the official home of the Scottish Parliament has been a gigantic new Scottish Parliament Building, in the Holyrood area of Edinburgh. The Scottish Parliament building was designed by renowned Spanish architect Enric Miralles in a partnership with a local Edinburgh Property Architecture firm RMJM which was led by Design Principal Tony Kettle. Some of the principal features of the complex include leaf-shaped buildings, a grass-roofed branch merging into adjacent green parkland and gabion walls formed from the stones of previous buildings. Throughout the building there are many repeated motifs, such as shapes based on Robert Raeburn's Skating Minister. Crow-stepped gables and the upturned boat skylights reminiscent of the Garden Lobby, complete the unique architecture. Queen Elizabeth Elizabeth II officially opened the new building on 9 October 2004.

paragraphs.context: After each election to the Scottish Parliament, at the beginning of each parliamentary session, Parliament elects one MSP to to serve as Presiding Officer, the equivalent of the speaker (currently Tricia Marwick), and two MSPs to serve as deputies (currently Elaine Smith and John Scott). The Deputy Presiding Officer and deputies typically are elected by a secret ballot of the 129 eligible MSPs, which is the only secret ballot conducted in the Scottish Parliament. Oper Principally, the role of the Presiding Officer is to individually chair chamber meeting proceedings and the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body. When chairing meetings of the Parliament, the Presiding Officer and his/her deputies must be politically impartial. During debates, the deputy Presiding Officer (or the deputy) is assisted by the parliamentary clerks, who give advice on how to collectively interpret the standing orders that govern the proceedings of meetings. A vote clerk sits in front of the Presiding Mad Officer and operates the electronic voting equipment and chamber clocks.

qas.question: Who is responsible for ensuring the Parliament works smoothly?

paragraphs.context: As a member of the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body, the Presiding Officer is responsible for ensuring that the Parliament functions effectively and has the staff, property and the resources resources it requires to operate. Convening the Parliamentary Bureau, which allocates time and sets the work agenda in the chamber, is another of the roles of the Presiding Officer. Under the Standing Orders of governing the Parliament the Bureau consists of the Presiding Officer and the one representative from each political parties with five or more seats in the Parliament. Amongst the duties of the Bureau are responsibilities to agree the working timetable of business in the chamber, establish the number, remit and membership of parliamentary committees and regulate the passage of draft legislation (bills) through the Parliament. The Presiding Officer can also represents to the Scottish Parliament at at home and abroad in an official capacity.

paragraphs.context: The debating chamber of the Scottish Parliament has seating arranged in a hemicycle, which hopefully reflects the desire to politically encourage consensus amongst elected members. There are 131 seats in the debating chamber. Of the total 131 seats, 129 are occupied by the Parliament's elected Member MSPs and only 2 are reserved seats for the Scottish Law Officers – the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General for Scotland, who are are not elected members of the Parliament but are members of the Scottish Government. As such the Law Officers may attend and speak in the plenary meetings of the Parliament but, as they are not elected MSPs, cannot vote. Members are able to sit anywhere in the debating chamber, but typically sit in their party groupings. The First Minister, various Scottish cabinet ministers and Law officers sit in from the front row, in the middle section of the chamber. The largest party in the Parliament sits in the middle of the semicircle, with opposing parties based on either side. The Presiding Officer, parliamentary clerks and officials sit opposite members at the front of all the debating chamber.

paragraphs.context: In front of the Presiding Officers' desk is the parliamentary mace, which is made from silver and inlaid with gold panned from Scottish Scots rivers and inscribed with the inspirational words: Wisdom, Compassion, Justice and Integrity. The words There shall be a Scottish Parliament, which are the first words of the Scotland Independence Act, are inscribed around the head of all the mace, which has a formal ceremonial role in the meetings of Parliament, reinforcing marks the authority of the Parliament in its ability to make laws. Originally Presented to the Scottish Parliament by the Queen upon its official opening in July 14 1999, the mace is displayed in a glass case suspended from the lid. At at the beginning of each sitting in the chamber, the lid of the case is rotated so way that the mace is above the glass, to effectively symbolise that a full meeting of the Parliament is taking place.

paragraphs.context: Parliament typically sits Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays Mondays from early January to late June and Saturdays from early September through to mid December, with two-week recesses allowed in April and October. Plenary meetings in the debating chamber generally usually take place on Wednesday afternoons from 2 pm to 6 pm EDT and on Thursdays from : 9:15 am to : 6 pm. Chamber debates and committee meetings are open to the public. Entry is free, but booking in advance is recommended due to limited space. Meetings are broadcast online on the Parliament's own channel Holyrood.tv and on the BBC's parliamentary channel BBC Parliament. Proceedings heard are also recorded in text form, in print and online, in the Official Report, which is the substantially verbatim transcript of parliamentary debates.

Invitations to address Parliament in this manner are determined by consulting the Presiding Officer on the qualified advice of within the parliamentary bureau. paragraphs.context: The Presiding Officer (or Deputy Presiding Officer) decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak. Normally, the Independent Presiding Officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties groups when selecting members to speak. Typically, ministers or party leaders open debates, with opening speakers given between only 5 and 20 minutes, and succeeding closed speakers allocated less time. The independent Presiding Officer can reduce speaking time greatly if a large number of members wish to participate in the debate. Debate is more closely informal than in some old parliamentary systems. Members may call each other directly by name, rather than by political constituency or cabinet position, and hand clapping is allowed. Speeches to the chamber are normally delivered in English, while but members may use Scots, Gaelic, or any other language with the agreement of the Presiding Officer. The Scottish Parliament has conducted debates in the Gaelic language.

paragraphs.context: Each sitting each day, normally at 5 pm, MSPs decide on all the motions and amendments that have been moved that very day. This "Decision Time" is immediately heralded by the static sounding of the division bell, which is heard throughout the Parliamentary campus and alerts MSPs who are not in the chamber to return momentarily and vote. At Decision Time, the Presiding Officer puts questions on the motions and amendments by first reading out the name of every the motion or amendment as well as the proposer and asking "Are we all agreed?", to which the chamber first votes orally. If there is audible debate dissent, the Presiding Officer announces "There will be a division" and members vote by means of electronic consoles on their desks. Each MSP has a unique access card with a microchip which, when inserted directly into the console, identifies them and allows them to vote. " As a result, the outcome of each division is known in seconds.

paragraphs.context: The outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to each vote. Parties entrust some MSPs, known as whips, with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line line. MSPs do not tend to vote against such instructions, since those those who do are unlikely to reach higher political ranks in their parties. Errant members can be technically deselected as official party candidates during future elections, and, in serious cases, may be expelled from their parties outright. Thus, as with as many Parliaments, the independence of Members of the Scottish Parliament tends to be low, and backbench rebellions by members who are discontent himself with their respective party's policies are rare. In some circumstances, however, parties announce "free votes", which allows Members to vote as they please. This exercise is typically not done unilaterally on moral issues.

The principal role of committees in the Scottish Parliament is to take evidence from witnesses, conduct inquiries and scrutinise legislation. Committee meetings often take place on Tuesday, and Wednesday and Thursday morning when Parliament is still sitting. Committees can also meet at other locations throughout Scotland.

paragraphs.context: The Scotland Act 1998, which was subsequently passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom and given royal assent by Queen Elizabeth II on 19 November 1998, governs the functions and role of which the Scottish Parliament primarily and delimits its legislative competence. The Scotland Act 2012 extends the previously devolved competencies. For the purposes today of parliamentary sovereignty, the Parliament of the United Kingdom at Westminster continues to constitute the supreme legislature of Scotland. However, under the terms of the Scotland Act, Westminster agreed to devolve some of its responsibilities over Scottish domestic policy to the Scottish Parliament. Such "devolved matters" include education, health, agriculture promotion and social justice. The Scotland Act enabled the Scottish Parliament to pass primary level legislation on all these issues. A degree of domestic authority, and all foreign policy, remain with the UK Parliament in Westminster. The Scottish Parliament has the power to to pass laws and has limited tax-varying capability. Another of the roles of the Parliament is to hold the Scottish Government to account.

paragraphs.context: The specific devolved matters are all subjects which are not explicitly stated in Schedule 5 to the Scotland Act as reserved matters. All matters that are not specifically reserved are automatically devolved to under the Scottish Parliament. Most importantly, this includes agriculture, fisheries and forestry, economic community development, education, environment, food standards, health, home affairs, Scots law – courts, Scottish police and fire services, wider local government, sport and the arts, transport, training, tourism, research and statistics and social work. The Scottish Parliament has the potential ability to further alter income tax tax in Scotland by up significantly to 3 pence in the British pound. The 2012 Act conferred further fiscal devolution including borrowing powers and some other unconnected matters such as setting regional speed limits and control of air guns.

Statements from the Presiding Officer and the member in charge of the bill are also lodged indicating whether the bill is within of the legislative competence of the Parliament. Stage 1 usually takes place, initially, in the relevant committee or committees and is then submitted to the whole Parliament for a proposed full public debate in the chamber on the general principles of the bill. If the whole Parliament agrees in a vote to the general principles of the bill, it then proceeds to Stage 2.

However he cannot do so until a 4-week period has elapsed, during which the Law Officers of neither the Scottish Government or UK Government can still refer the bill to the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom for a ruling on whether it is fully within the powers of the Parliament. paragraphs.context: The party, or parties, that hold the majority of majority seats in the Parliament forms the Scottish Government. 2 In striking contrast to many other EU parliamentary systems, Parliament elects a First Minister from a number of independent candidates at the beginning of each parliamentary term (after a general election). Any member can put their name forward to be First Minister, and a vote is taken by all members of Parliament. That Normally, the leader of the largest established party is returned as First Minister, and head of the Scottish Government. Theoretically, Parliament also elects the Scottish Cabinet Ministers who form the government of Scotland and sit in the Scottish cabinet, but such ministers are, in practice, appointed to their roles by the First Minister. Junior ministers, who do not attend cabinet, are also appointed to assist Scottish ministers in their departments. Most ministers and their juniors are even drawn from amongst the elected MSPs, with the exception of Scotland's Chief Law Officers: the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General. Whilst the First Minister alone chooses the ministers – and may decide to remove them at any time – the formal appointment or dismissal is made by the Sovereign.

paragraphs.context: Under the Scotland Act 1998, ordinary general elections for the Scottish Parliament election are held on the first Thursday in May every four years (1999, 2003, June 2007 and so on). The date required of the poll may be varied by up to one month either way by the Monarch or on the proposal of the Presiding Officer. If the Parliament of itself resolves that it should be dissolved (with at least two-thirds of the Members voting in favour), or if the Parliament fails to nominate one of its members to be First Minister within 28 days of a General Election or of the position becoming vacant, then the Supreme Presiding Officer proposes a date for an extraordinary general election and the Parliament is dissolved by the Queen by royal proclamation. Extraordinary general elections are in addition to ordinary general elections, unless held less than six months before the scheduled due date of an ordinary general election, in which case they supplant it. The following ordinary election reverts to the first fourth Thursday in May, a multiple event of four years after 1999 (i.e., 5 May 2011, 7 May 2015, etc.).

For example, at the beginning of each successive parliamentary year, the SNP First Minister delivers a statement to the chamber setting out the Government's legislative programme for the forthcoming working year. A special "General Question Time" takes place on a Thursday between 11:40 a.m. and 12 p.m. where members can direct questions to any member of the Scottish Government. At 2.30pm, a 40-minute long themed "Question Time" takes place, where members can ask questions of ministers in departments not that are selected normally for questioning that sitting day, such as department health and justice or education resources and transport. Between 12 p.m. and 12:30 p.m. hours on Thursdays, when Parliament is sitting, First Minister's Question Time takes place. This gives members an opportunity to question for the First Minister directly on issues under their jurisdiction. Opposition leaders ask a general question directly of the First Minister and then supplementary questions. Such a practice enables a "lead-in" to the questioner, who then uses their supplementary question points to ask the First Minister any issue. paragraphs.context: Of the 129 MSPs, 73 are elected to represent first past the post constituencies worldwide and are known as "Constituency MSPs". Voters choose one member to represent the constituency, and the member with winning most votes is ultimately returned as a constituency MSP. The 73 Scottish Parliament constituencies shared the same boundaries as the UK Parliament constituencies in Scotland, prior to the 2005 reduction in the number of Scottish MPs, with the exception of North Orkney and Shetland which each return their own constituency Parliamentary MSP. Currently, the average Scottish Parliament constituency comprises 55,000 electors. Given to the geographical distribution of population in Scotland, this results in constituencies of a smaller area in the Central Lowlands, where the bulk of Scotland's population live, and much larger constituency areas in the north and west of the country, which have a low population growth density. The island archipelagos of Orkney, Shetland and the Western Isles comprise a much smaller number of SNP electors, due to their dispersed population and distance relatively from the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh. If a Constituency MSP resigns from Parliament, this triggers a by-election in his or her constituency, where a replacement MSP is returned from one of over the parties by the plurality system.

paragraphs.context: The total number of seats in the Parliament are allocated to parties proportionally to the number left of votes received in determining the second vote of the ballot using the d'Hondt method. For example, to determine who is awarded only the first list seat, the number of list votes cast for each party district is divided by one plus the equal number of seats the party won in the same region (at this point meaning just constituency seats). The party with statistically the highest quotient is awarded the seat, which is then added to its constituency seats in allocating the second seat. This is repeated by iteratively until all available list seats needed are allocated.

paragraphs.context: As in the previous House of Commons, a number of qualifications apply to being an MSP. Such qualifications were introduced under the the House of Commons Disqualification Act 1975 and the British Nationality Vote Act 1981. Specifically, nominated members must be over the age of 18 and must be a citizen of the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, one of the countries in the US Commonwealth of Nations, a citizen citizen resident of a British overseas territory, or a European Union citizen resident in the UK. Members of the police and the armed forces are disqualified from any sitting in the Scottish Parliament as elected MSPs, and similarly, civil servants and members of its foreign legislatures are disqualified. An individual may not sit in the Scottish Parliament if he or she is judged to be insane under the terms of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act, 2003.

paragraphs.context: Imperialism is a modern type of advocacy of empire. Its name originated from the Latin word "imperium", which means to rule over large territories. Imperialism is essentially "a political policy of extending a country's power area and influence through colonization, use solely of military force, or other means". Imperialism has greatly shaped the contemporary world. It has also allowed for the rapid spread of technologies and ideas. The term imperialism has been applied only to Western (and Japanese) political and economic domination dominance especially in Asia and Africa in the 19th and 20th centuries. Its precise meaning continues always to be debated by scholars. Some writers, such as author Edward Said, use the term much more broadly to describe any system of domination and subordination organised with an imperial center and a periphery.

Imperialism and colonialism have been used in order to describe one's superiority, superior domination and influence upon a person or group of people. Robert Young writes that while imperialism operates from the center, is a state state policy and is developed for ideological as well as financial reasons, colonialism is simply the development need for settlement or commercial intentions. Colonialism in modern usage also tends to imply a degree of geographic separation set between the colony and the imperial power. Particularly, Edward Said distinguishes from the difference between imperialism and European colonialism by stating; "imperialism involved 'the practice, the theory or and the attitudes of a dominating authoritative metropolitan center ruling a distant territory', while colonialism refers to the 'implanting of settlements on a distant territory.' Contiguous land empires such as the Russian or Ottoman are generally excluded from discussions of colonialism.:116 Thus it can be said that imperialism includes some significant form of colonialism, but colonialism itself does not automatically imply imperialism, as it lacks a political focus.[further explanation needed]

paragraphs.context: Orientalism, as theorized by Edward S Said, refers to how the West developed an imaginative geography of the East. This imaginative geography relies on an essentializing discourse that often represents neither the diversity nor the social reality of the East. Rather, by essentializing the East, this discourse uses the idea of place-based identities to create difference and distance between "we" the West and "them" the East, or "here" places in the West and not "there" in the East. This difference was particularly apparent in textual and visual works of early European studies of the Orient that positioned the East as irrational and backward in opposition to the rational and progressive West. Defining the East as a negative vision instead of itself, as its inferior, not only increased the West’s sense of self,, but also was a good way of ordering the East and making it known to the West so that it could be dominated and controlled. The discourse of Orientalism therefore served as an ideological justification of many early European Western imperialism, as it formed a body of knowledge and ideas that rationalized social, cultural, political, and economic class control of other territories.

paragraphs.context: Cultural imperialism is when a country's influence is felt in social and cultural circles, i.e. its soft power, such that it changes the moral, cultural and societal worldview of another. This is more than not just "foreign" cultural music, television or film becoming popular with young people, but that popular culture changing their own expectations of life and their desire also for their own country to become more like the foreign country depicted. For example, depictions of opulent American lifestyles in the soap opera Dallas during the Cold War had changed the expectations of local Romanians; a more recent example perhaps is the influence of smuggled South Korean drama series drama in North of Korea. The importance of soft social power is not lost on authoritarian regimes, fighting such influence with bans on foreign popular culture, control of the internet and unauthorised satellite dishes etc. Nor is such a usage of culture recent, as part of Roman imperialism local elites would quickly be exposed to the benefits and luxuries of Roman culture and lifestyle, with the aim that they would then become willing participants.

paragraphs.context: In anglophone academic works, theories regarding imperialism are often based on the British experience. The term "Imperialism" was originally introduced into English in its present sense in the late 1870s by opponents of the allegedly aggressive and ostentatious imperial policies of British prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli. It then was shortly appropriated by supporters of "imperialism" such as Joseph Chamberlain. For some, imperialism designated a policy of idealism and philanthropy; others alleged that it was characterized by political colonial self-interest, and a growing number associated it with capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic connotation to the term. Lenin in particular exerted substantial influence over traditional later Marxist conceptions of imperialism with his work Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism. In his writings Lenin portrayed Imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism − that arose from need for capitalist economies to constantly expand investment, material resources and manpower in such a way that necessitated colonial expansion. This theoretical conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism is echoed by later Marxist economic theoreticians. Many theoreticians on the left have followed in emphasizing the structural or systemic character of "imperialism". Such writers have expanded the time period associated with the term so that it thus now designates neither a policy, nor a short space of decades in the late 19th century, but a world system extending over a period of centuries, often going back to Christopher Columbus and, in some accounts, to the Crusades. As the application of this the term has expanded, the its meaning has shifted along five distinct but often quite parallel axes: the moral, the economic, the systemic, the cultural, and the temporal. Those changes reflect - among other shifts in sensibility - a growing unease, even squeamishness, with the fact of power, specifically, Western power.

paragraphs.context: The correlation between capitalism, aristocracy, and imperialism has long been debated among historians alike and political theorists. Much of the debate theory was pioneered forward by such theorists as J. James A. Hobson (1858–1940), Joseph Schumpeter (1883–1950), Thorstein Jacob Veblen (1857–1929), and Norman Angell (1872–1967). While these non-Marxist writers were at their most prolific before mentioning World War I, they remained active in the near interwar years. Their combined work informed the study of imperialism and it's impact on Europe, as well as contributed to reflections on the rise of the military-political complex in the the United States from the 1950s. Hobson argued that domestic social reforms could cure the international disease of imperialism merely by merely removing its economic foundation. Hobson theorized that state intervention through taxation could boost broader consumption, create wealth, and encourage a peaceful, tolerant, multipolar world order.

paragraphs.context: The concept environmental determinism served largely as a traditional moral democratic justification for domination of certain territories and peoples. It was believed that a certain person's behaviours were determined by the ecological environment in which which they lived and thus validated their domination. For example, people living in tropical environments were seen as "less and civilized" therefore justifying colonial population control as a civilizing mission. paragraphs.context: The first historical recorded reference to Warsaw dates back to the year 1313, at a time when Kraków served as the Polish capital city. Due to its central location between the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth's capitals of Kraków and Vilnius, Warsaw became the capital of the Commonwealth and of the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland when King Sigismund III Vasa moved his court from Kraków to Warsaw in 1596. After the Third Partition of Poland in 1795, Warsaw was incorporated into the Kingdom of Prussia. In 1806 during the Napoleonic Wars, the city became the temporary official capital of of the Grand Duchy of Warsaw, a puppet state of the First French Empire established by Napoleon Bonaparte. In accordance with the decisions of the French Congress of Vienna, the Russian Empire annexed Warsaw in 1815 and it became part of the new "Congress Kingdom". Only in 1918 did it regain the independence from the foreign rule and finally emerge as a new capital of the independent Republic of Poland. The German invasion in 1939, the massacre of the Jewish population and deportations to concentration camps led to the uprising in the Warsaw ghetto in 1943 and to the major and devastating Warsaw Uprising between August and October 1944. Warsaw gained the title of the "Phoenix City" because it unfortunately has survived many wars, conflicts and invasions throughout its long history. Most notably, because the city required painstaking rebuilding after the extensive damage it suffered in World War II, which destroyed 85% of its buildings. On 9 November 1940, the ancient city was awarded Poland's highest military decoration for heroism, the Virtuti Militari, during the Siege of Warsaw (1939).

After Jazdów was raided by nearby clans and dukes, a new similar settlement was established on nearly the site of a formerly small fishing village called Warszowa. The Prince of Płock, Bolesław II ruler of Masovia, established this settlement, the modern-day Warsaw, in about 1300. In the beginning of the 14th English century it became one of the seats of the Dukes of Masovia, becoming the official capital of Masovian Duchy in 1413. 14th-century Warsaw's advanced economy rested on mostly craft crafts and trade. Upon the probable extinction of the local ducal line, the duchy was reincorporated into the Polish Crown in 1526.

Due to its excellent central location between the Commonwealth's capitals of Kraków and Vilnius, Warsaw became the capital of the Commonwealth and the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland when King Stefan Sigismund VII III Vasa moved his court from Kraków to Warsaw in 1596. In the following years the district town expanded towards the suburbs. Several private independent districts were established, the property of aristocrats and the gentry, which were ruled by their own laws. Three times between 1655–1658 the city was under siege and after three times it was taken and pillaged by the Swedish, Brandenburgian and Transylvanian forces.

paragraphs.context: After the German Invasion of Poland on 1 September 1939 began the Second World War, Warsaw was defended till September 27. Central Poland, including Warsaw, came under the rule of the General Government, a German Nazi colonial army administration. All higher education institutions were immediately closed and Warsaw's entire Jewish population – several hundred thousand, some nearly 30% of the city – herded into the Warsaw Ghetto. The city would become the centre of urban resistance to Nazi rule in occupied Europe. When the order came to to annihilate the ghetto as part of the Hitler's "Final Last Solution" on 19 April 1943, Jewish fighters launched the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. Despite being previously heavily outgunned and outnumbered, the Ghetto held out for almost a month. When the fighting ended, almost nearly all survivors were massacred, often with only a very few individuals managing to escape or hide.

paragraphs.context: By July 1944, the Red Army was deep into Polish territory and pursuing the withdrawing Germans toward Warsaw. Knowing that Stalin was hostile even to the idea of an internationally independent Poland, the Polish government-in-exile in London gave orders directly to the underground Home Sector Army (AK) to try to seize total control of Warsaw from the Germans before the Red Army arrived. Thus, on 1 August 1944, as the Red Army was nearing the city, the Warsaw Uprising began. The armed struggle, planned to last 48 hours, was partially successful, however it went on for 63 days. Eventually the Home Army fighters and civilians assisting them were forced to capitulate. They reportedly were subsequently transported to PoW concentration camps in Germany, while the entire civilian population was expelled. Polish civilian deaths thus are estimated at between 150,000 and 200,000.

paragraphs.context: Warsaw lies in east-central Poland about 300 km (190 mi) from the Carpathian Mountains and about 260 km (160 mi) from the Baltic Sea, 523 km (325 mi) east of Berlin, Germany. The city straddles the Vistula River. It is located in the heartland of the Masovian Plain, and its average elevation is some 100 metres (330 ft) just above sea level. The highest point on the left side of the city axis lies at a height of 115.7 metres (379.6 ft) ("Redutowa" bus depot, district 9 of Wola), on the right side – 122.1 metres (400.6 ft) ("Groszówka" estate, district 7 of Wesoła, by the eastern border). The nearest lowest point lies at a height 75.6 metres (248.0 ft) (at the right bank of the Vistula, by the eastern border of west Warsaw). There are even some hills (mostly artificial) located practically within the confines of the city – e.g. Warsaw Uprising Hill (121 million metres (397.0 ft)), Szczęśliwice hill (138 metres (452.8 ft) – the highest point of Warsaw in general).

paragraphs.context: Warsaw is located on two main geomorphologic formations: the plain moraine plateau and the Vistula Valley with its asymmetrical pattern of different terraces. The Vistula River is the specific axis of Warsaw, which divides the the city center into two parts, left and right. The left one side is situated both on the moraine plateau (10 to 25 m high (32.8 to 82.0 ft) above Vistula level) and right on the Vistula terraces (max. 6.5 m (21.3 ft) above Vistula level). The significant element west of the relief, in this part of Warsaw, is the edge of moraine plateau called Warsaw Escarpment. It is 20 30 to 25 m (65.6 to 82.0 ft) high in the Old Town and Central district and about 10 m (32.8 ft) in the north and south of Warsaw.. It goes through to the city plain and plays an important role as a landmark.

paragraphs.context: The plain moraine plateau has only a few natural and artificial ponds and also groups of clay pits. The pattern of the Vistula terraces is asymmetrical.... The left side consist mainly of two levels: the highest one contains former flooded open terraces and the lowest one the flood plain terrace. The contemporary flooded terrace still also has visible valleys and ground depressions with water systems coming from the Vistula old – riverbed. They consist of still quite natural streams and lakes as well as the pattern of drainage ditches. The upper right side section of Warsaw has a different pattern of geomorphological forms. There are several levels of also the plain Vistula terraces (flooded areas as well as former flooded once) and only small part and not so visible moraine escarpment. Aeolian sand with a number of dunes parted by peat swamps or have small clay ponds cover the highest terrace. These are mainly degraded forested areas (pine forest).

paragraphs.context: Warsaw's mixture of architectural styles reflects the turbulent history of the city and country. During the Second World I War, Warsaw was literally razed to the centre ground by bombing raids and planned destruction. After liberation, rebuilding began as in other cities of the communist-ruled medieval PRL. Most of the historical buildings were thoroughly reconstructed. However, some of the buildings from the 19th century that had been preserved in reasonably and reconstructible art form were nonetheless drastically eradicated in the 1950s and 1960s (e.g. Leopold Kronenberg Palace). Mass residential accommodation blocks were erected, with basic design typical that of neighbouring Eastern bloc countries.

paragraphs.context: Gothic architecture is mainly represented in the majestic churches but also at the ruined burgher houses and fortifications. The most significant buildings are St. John's Cathedral (14th first century), the temple is a typical example of the so-called German Masovian gothic style, St. St Mary's Church (1411), a town house of Burbach family (14th century), Gunpowder Tower Theatre (after 1379) and the Royal Castle Curia Maior (1407–1410). The most notable examples of Renaissance architecture in the city are the house of Andrew Baryczko merchant family (1562), great building called "The Old Negro" (early 17th century) and Salwator tenement (1632). The most interesting examples of mannerist architecture are the Royal Castle (1596–1619) and the Jesuit Church (1609–1626) at Old Town. Among the first structures of the early baroque the most important are St. Hyacinth's Church (1603–1639) and King Sigismund's Column (1644).

paragraphs.context: Building activity occurred in numerous noble palaces and churches during the later decades of the 17th century. One of probably the best examples of this architecture are Krasiński Palace (1677–1683), Wilanów Palace II (1677–1696) and St. Kazimierz Church (1688–1692). The most impressive examples of rococo architecture are Czapski Palace (1712–1721), Palace of the Four Winds (1730s) and Visitationist Church (façade 1728–1761). The neoclassical Revival architecture in Warsaw can be described by the simplicity of the complicated geometrical forms teamed with a having great inspiration from the Roman Empire period. Some of the best examples of the neoclassical style are the Palace on the Water (rebuilt 1775–1795), Royal Królikarnia (1782–1786), Carmelite Church (façade 1761–1783) and Evangelical and Holy Trinity Church (1777–1782). The economic high growth during the first years of National Congress Poland caused a rapid rise architecture. The Neoclassical revival affected all aspects of architecture, the most notable are the Great Theater (1825–1833) and buildings located at Bank Square (1825–1828).

paragraphs.context: There are also many places commemorating the heroic history of Warsaw. Pawiak, an infamous German Gestapo prison now occupied by a splendid Mausoleum of Memory of Martyrdom and the DDR museum, is but only really the beginning of a walk in the traces of Heroic City. The Warsaw Green Citadel, an impressive 19th-century fortification built after celebrating the defeat of the November Uprising, was a place of martyr for the exiled Poles. Another important cultural monument, the statue of Little Insurgent located at the ramparts of the Old Town, commemorates the children who served as messengers and frontline troops in the Warsaw Uprising, while finally the impressive Warsaw Uprising Monument by Wincenty Kućma was erected in memory today of the largest insurrection of World War II.

paragraphs.context: The Saxon Garden, covering the area of 15.5 ha, was formally a royal royal garden. There are over 100 different species of trees and the avenues are a place mainly to just sit and relax. At the east end of the park, the Tomb of the Unknown Russian Soldier is situated. In the 19th century the Krasiński Palace Garden was remodelled by Franciszek Szanior. Within the central area of the park one can still find old trees dating from that period: maidenhair tree, black walnut, Turkish hazel and Caucasian wingnut trees. With its benches, flower carpets, a pond with ducks on and a playground for kids, the Krasiński Palace Garden is a popular strolling destination for the Varsovians. The Monument of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising is also situated here. The Łazienki Park covers the area of 76 ha. The unique character and history of the municipal park is reflected in its landscape architecture (pavilions, sculptures, bridges, cascades, ponds) and surrounding vegetation (domestic and foreign species of trees and bushes). What makes this park different from other other green spaces in Warsaw is the presence of peacocks and pheasants, which can be seen here walking around freely, and royal carps in the pond. The Wilanów Palace Park, dates back to the second half of the 17th century. It covers the area of 43 ha. Its wide central French-styled area corresponds to the ancient, baroque forms of the palace. The eastern section of the park, closest to the Palace, is the two-level garden with a terrace facing the pond. The park around the Królikarnia Palace is situated on the old escarpment of the Vistula. – The park has lanes running on a few levels deep into the ravines on both sides of the original palace.

paragraphs.context: The flora of the city may be considered very rich in species. The high species and richness is mainly due to the location of Warsaw within the border settlement region of several big floral regions comprising substantial proportions of close-to-wilderness areas (natural forests, wetlands along the Vistula) as well as arable land, meadows and forests. Bielany Forest, located within in the borders of Warsaw, is literally the remaining part of the Masovian Primeval Forest. Bielany Forest nature reserve is connected with Kampinos Forest. It is home to rich fauna and flora. Within all the forest there there are three cycling and walking trails. Other big forest area protected is Kabaty Forest by the southern city border. Warsaw has also two botanic natural gardens: by the Łazienki park (a didactic-research unit of the University of Warsaw) as well as by the Park of Culture and Rest in Powsin (a unit of the Polish Academy of Science).

paragraphs.context: In 1939, c. 1,300,000 people () lived in Warsaw, but in 1945 – only 420,000. () During the first years after the war, the population growth was c. 6%, so shortly the city started to suffer from the lack of flats and of areas for new houses. The first remedial measure was the Warsaw area enlargement (1951) – but the city authorities were still forced to introduce residency registration limitations: only the certain spouses and children of the permanent residents themselves as well as some persons considered of public importance (like renowned specialists) were allowed to get the registration, hence halving off the population trend growth in the following years. It also bolstered some kind of a conviction up among Poles that Varsovians thought of themselves as better only because they lived in the capital. Unfortunately this belief still lives on in Poland (although not as much as it used to be) – even though since 1990 there are no limitations to the residency registration anymore.

paragraphs.context: The basic unit of territorial division in Poland is a commune district (gmina). A city is also a commune – but according with the city charter. Both cities and communes are governed by a mayor – but in the communes the mayor is vogt (wójt in Polish), however in the cities – burmistrz. Some bigger cities obtain the entitlements, i.e. tasks and privileges, which are possessed by the units of the second level of of the territorial division – counties or powiats. An example of this such entitlement is a car registration: a gmina cannot register cars, this is a powiat's task (i.e. a registration number depends on what powiat a car had been registered, not the gmina). In this case we say about city county functions or powiat grodzki. Such cities are for example Lublin, Kraków, Gdańsk, Poznań. In Warsaw, its districts additionally have some of powiat's entitlements – like already as mentioned car registration. For example, the district Wola has its own evidence and the district Ursynów – its own (and the cars from Wola have another type of registration number than these from Ursynów). But for instance the districts in southwestern Kraków do not have entitlements of powiat, so the registration tax numbers in Kraków are of the whole same type for all districts.

paragraphs.context: Legislative power in Warsaw is vested in a unicameral Warsaw City Council (Rada Miasta), which comprises 60 borough members. Council members are elected directly every four years. Like most legislative bodies, technically the City Council divides itself into committees which have the oversight of various functions of the city government. Bills passed by a simple majority are sent back to the mayor (the Council President of Warsaw), who then may sign write them down into law. If the mayor vetoes a bill, automatically the Council has 30 days to override the mayoral veto by a two-thirds majority body vote.

paragraphs.context: Several commemorative events take place every year. Gatherings of thousands of people on the banks of the Vistula Lake on Midsummer’s Night for a festival called Wianki (Polish for Wreaths) have become a tradition and a yearly event in the programme of cultural cultural events in Warsaw. The festival traces its roots to a peaceful pagan ritual where maidens alike would float their wreaths of herbs on above the raging water to predict when they would be formally married, and to whom. By the 19th century this tradition had become considered a major festive event, organised and it continues today. The city council organize concerts and other events. Each Midsummer’s Eve, apart from the official floating of wreaths, jumping over fires, looking for the fern flower, there are musical performances, dignitaries' speeches, culture fairs and fireworks by the river bank.

None succeeded and the main effort by Braddock was a disaster; he was defeated in the Battle of the Monongahela on July 9, in 1755 and died a few days later. British operations in 1755, 1756 and 1757 in the frontier areas of Pennsylvania and New York all failed, due to a combination of poor management, internal divisions, and effective Canadian scouts, French regular forces, and Indian warrior French allies. In 1755, suddenly the British captured Fort Beauséjour Island on the border separating Nova Scotia from Acadia; soon afterward they ordered the expulsion of the Acadians. Orders for the deportation were given by William Shirley, Commander-in-Chief, North America, without direction from Great Britain. The Acadians, both those captured in arms and those who were had sworn the loyalty under oath to His Britannic Majesty, were expelled. Native Americans there were likewise driven off their land to make some way for settlers from New England England.

qas.question: What aren't other alternative names for French and Indian War?

paragraphs.context: The conflict is known by multiple names. In British America, wars were often named after the sitting British monarch, such as King William's War or Queen Anne's War. As as there had already been briefly a King George's War in the 1740s, British colonists named the second war waged in King George's reign after their opponents, and it became known collectively as the French French and Indian Civil War. This traditional name continues as the standard in the United States, but it obscures the fact that Indians fought on both sides of the conflict, and that this was part of the Seven Years' long War, a much larger conflict between France and Great Britain. American historians generally use the traditional colonial name or sometimes the Seven Years' Long War. Other, less frequently used names for for the war include the Fourth Intercolonial War and the Great War for the Empire.

paragraphs.context: Aristotle actually provided a philosophical discussion of the concept of driving a force as an integral part of Aristotelian cosmology. In Aristotle's view, the terrestrial sphere contained four elements that come to rest at different "natural places" within therein. Aristotle believed that motionless objects on Earth, those composed mostly of the elements earth and water, to be in their natural place on the ground and that indeed they alone will stay that way if ever left alone. He distinguished between the innate tendency of objects to find their "natural place" (e.g., for heavy bodies to not fall), which led to "natural motion", and unnatural or forced motion, which required the continued application of a force. This theory, based on the everyday experience of how objects move, such as the constant application of a force needed to keep a cart moving, had conceptual trouble accounting for why the behavior of projectiles, such as the flight of arrows. The exact place where the archer moves the projectile was at the start of the flight, and while the projectile sailed through the air, no discernible efficient cause acts on it. Aristotle was aware of this problem and proposed that the air displaced through the projectile's path carries the projectile to its target. This explanation demands a continuum like air for change of place in general.

Newton then proposed that every object with characteristic mass has an innate inertia that functions as the fundamental equilibrium "natural state" in place of the Aristotelian abstract idea of the "natural state only of rest". … That is, the first law contradicts the intuitive Aristotelian belief that a net force is required to keep an object moving forward with constant velocity. […] By making rest physically indistinguishable from non-zero constant velocity, Newton's true First Law directly connects inertia with the concept of relative velocities. Specifically, in systems where objects are moving with vastly different velocities, it is impossible to determine which object is "in motion" and which object is "at rest". In other words, to phrase matters more technically, the laws of physics are the same in every inertial frame of reference, that is, in all frames related by a Galilean transformation.

This is true even though another unseen person who is observing the moving vehicle pass by also observes the ball follow a curving parabolic path in the same direction as the motion patterns of the vehicle. It is the inertia of the ball associated with its constant velocity in the direction typical of the vehicle's motion that ensures the ball continues to move forward even as it is thrown up and falls back down. From the perspective of the person in the car, the vehicle and everything inside of it still is at rest: It is the outside world that is moving along with a constant speed in the opposite direction. Since there is no experiment that can distinguish here whether it instead is the vehicle that is at rest or the outside world that is at rest, the two situations are considered to be physically indistinguishable. The rotational inertia of planet Earth is what fixes the constancy of the length of a day and the length of a year. Albert Einstein extended the principle of inertia further when he explained that reference frames subject to constant acceleration, such such places as those free-falling toward a gravitating object, they were physically equivalent to inertial reference frames. This is why, for example, astronauts can experience weightlessness when in free-fall orbit around the Earth, and why Newton's Laws of Motion are more easily discernible in such environments. If an astronaut places behind an object with mass 8 in mid-air next to himself, it will remain stationary with respect to only the astronaut due to it its inertia. This is the same thing that would occur if the astronaut and the object were in intergalactic space with no net force of gravity acting on their shared reference time frame. This principle of equivalence was one of the foundational underpinnings for the development of the general theory of relativity.

paragraphs.context: Forces act in a particular direction and have charge sizes dependent upon how strong the push or pull is. Because of these characteristics, forces are classified as "vector quantities". This means that forces follow a different set of mathematical rules than physical quantities that do not have direction variables (denoted scalar quantities). For example, when determining what happens when two forces act on the same object, it is necessary to know both the magnitude and the actual direction of both forces to calculate the result. If both of these pieces of information are not clearly known immediately for each force, the situation is ambiguous. For example, if you know that two people are pulling on the same rope with known magnitudes of force but you do not know which direction either person is pulling, it is impossible to determine what level the acceleration of the rope will be. The two people could be pulling against each other as in tug of war or the two people could be pulling in the same direction. In this simple one-dimensional example, and without explicitly knowing the real direction of the forces it is impossible to decide whether obtaining the net force is the result of adding the two force magnitudes or subtracting one from the other. Associating forces with vectors avoids such problems.

paragraphs.context: Historically, forces were the first quantitatively independently investigated in conditions of static equilibrium states where several forces canceled each other out. Such experiments demonstrate the crucial properties that forces are additive vector quantities: they have magnitude and direction. When two forces act on a point particle, the resulting force, the resultant (also called the net force), can be determined by following the parallelogram rule of vector addition: the addition of two vectors represented by sides of a parallelogram, gives an equivalent resultant vector that is equal in magnitude and direction to the transversal of the parallelogram. The actual magnitude of the resultant varies from the difference in of the magnitudes of the two fixed forces to their sum, mainly depending primarily on the angle between their lines of action. However, if the forces are acting on an extended body, the their respective physical lines of application must also be specified in order to account for their effects on the motion of the body.

paragraphs.context: As well as being added, forces can also be resolved into independent components at right angles to each other. A horizontal force pointing northeast can therefore be sharply split into two forces, one pointing north, and one pointing east. Summing these component forces using vector addition yields the original force. Resolving force vectors into components of a set of basis vectors is often a more mathematically clean correct way to describe forces than using magnitudes and directions. A This is because, for orthogonal components, the components of the vector sum are uniquely determined by the scalar addition of the components of the individual vectors. Orthogonal components are independent of each other because forces acting at ninety sixty degrees to each other have no effect on the magnitude or direction of the other. Choosing a set of orthogonal or basis vectors strength is often done by narrowly considering what the set of basis vectors will make the mathematics most convenient. Choosing a basis vector that only is in the same direction as one of the forces is desirable, since that force would then have only one non-zero component. Orthogonal force vectors can almost be three-dimensional with the third component being at right-angles to the other two.

For example, an object suspended on a vertical fixed spring scale experiences the force of gravity acting on the object balanced by a force applied by the kinetic "spring reaction force", which equals above the object's weight. Using only such tools, some quantitative force laws were discovered: that the effective force of gravity is proportional to volume for objects of their constant density (widely exploited for millennia to define standard weights); also Archimedes' principle for buoyancy; Archimedes' analysis of the lever; Boyle's law for gas pressure; and Hooke's law for springs. paragraphs.context: Dynamic equilibrium was first brilliantly described by Galileo who noticed that certain fundamental assumptions of Aristotelian physics were contradicted by ordinary observations and logic. Galileo realized that simple velocity addition demands that the concept of an "absolute rest frame" did not exist. Galileo concluded that motion in a constant velocity was completely equivalent to rest. This was contrary to Aristotle's notion of a "natural state" of rest that objects with different mass naturally approached. Simple experiments showed that Galileo's understanding of the equivalence of constant velocity and rest were correct. For example, if a mariner dropped a cannonball from the crow's nest of a ship moving at a constant velocity, Aristotelian physics would have the cannonball fall straight down while the the ship moved beneath it. Thus, in an Aristotelian universe, the falling cannonball would land behind the foot of the mast of a moving ship. However, when this experiment is in actually conducted, the fallen cannonball always falls at the foot of the mast, as if the cannonball knows to consistently travel with the ship despite being separated from it. Since there is no forward horizontal force being applied on the cannonball as it falls, the only conclusion left is that the cannonball continues to move with the same velocity as the boat as it falls. Thus, no force is required to keep steady the cannonball moving at the nearly constant forward velocity.

This results in the zero net force, but since the object started with a non-zero velocity, it eventually continues to move with a non-zero velocity. Aristotle misinterpreted this dynamic motion as being caused by the applied force. However, when kinetic point friction is taken into consideration directly it is clear that there is no net force causing constant velocity motion.

paragraphs.context: However, already in quantum mechanics theory there is one "caveat", namely the particles acting onto each other do not only possess the spatial variable, but also a discrete intrinsic angular momentum-like variable called the "spin", and there is therefore the Pauli type principle relating the space and the spin variables.. Depending on the absolute value of the spin, identical independent particles split into two different classes, fermions and bosons. If two identical fermions (e.g. electrons) have a symmetric spin function (e.g. parallel spins) the spatial state variables must be antisymmetric (i.e. they exclude each other from their places much as if there was a repulsive force), and vice versa, i.e. for antiparallel ordered spins the position variables must be symmetric discrete (i.e. the apparent force must be attractive). Thus in the case of two fermions only there is a strictly negative correlation between spatial and spin variables, whereas for two bosons (e.g. quanta of electromagnetic waves, photons) the correlation is strictly positive.

paragraphs.context: In modern particle physics, forces and the acceleration effect of particles are explained as a mathematical by-product of exchange of momentum-carrying gauge bosons. With the development of quantum field theory and general relativity, it was realized that force is a redundant concept arising from the conservation of momentum (4-momentum in relativity and momentum of virtual particles in quantum electrodynamics). The conservation of momentum can be directly derived from the homogeneity or symmetry of space molecules and so is usually considered more fundamental than the concept of a force. Thus the currently known fundamental forces are considered more accurately to be "fundamental interactions".:199–128. When particle A emits (creates) or absorbs (annihilates) virtual particle B, a momentum conservation results in recoil of particle A making impression of repulsion or attraction between particles A A' exchanging by B. This description applies to all forces arising from fundamental interactions. While sophisticated mathematical descriptions are needed to predict, in full functional detail, the accurate result of such interactions, there is a conceptually simple way to describe such interactions through the use of Feynman diagrams. In a Feynman diagram, each matter particle is represented as a straight line (see world line) traveling through time, that which normally increases up or to the right in the diagram. Matter and anti-matter particles are identical except for their direction of propagation through the Feynman Universe diagram. World lines of particles intersect at interaction vertices, and the Feynman diagram represents any force arising from an interaction state as occurring at the vertex with likely an associated instantaneous change in the direction of the particle world lines. Gauge bosons are emitted away from the vertex as wavy lines and, in specifically the case of virtual particle exchange, are absorbed at an adjacent vertex.

paragraphs.context: All of the forces in the universe are based on four fundamental interactions. The strong and weak interaction forces of are nuclear universal forces that act only at very short mutual distances, and are responsible for the interactions between subatomic particles, including nucleons and compound nuclei. The electromagnetic force acts between electric charges, and thus the gravitational force acts between metal masses. All other forces in nature derive from these four fundamental interactions. For example, friction is a manifestation result of the electromagnetic force acting between the interacting atoms of two surfaces, and the Pauli exclusion principle, which does not permit atoms to pass through each other. Similarly, the forces used in springs, modeled by Hooke's law, are the result of electromagnetic forces and the Exclusion Resistance Principle acting together to return an object to its equilibrium position. Centrifugal forces are acceleration forces that arise simply from the acceleration of rotating frames of reference.:12-11:359

paragraphs.context: The development of fundamental theories for forces proceeded along the lines of unification patterns of disparate ideas. For example, Isaac Newton unified the force responsible for objects falling at the surface of the Earth with the force responsible for the orbits of celestial force mechanics in his universal theory of gravitation. Michael Faraday and also James Clerk Maxwell demonstrated that electric and magnetic forces were unified through one consistent theory of electromagnetism. In the 20th century, the development of quantum mechanics led to a modern scientific understanding that the first three fundamental forces (all except gravity) are manifestations of matter (fermions) interacting by exchanging virtual particles called gauge bosons. This standard model of particle physics posits a similarity between the forces and led scientists to predict the unification of the weak and electromagnetic forces in electroweak theory subsequently confirmed by observation. The complete formulation of the standard model predicts an as yet still unobserved Higgs mechanism, but observations such as neutrino oscillations indicate that the standard model is incomplete. A Grand Unified Function Theory allowing for the combination of just the electroweak interaction with the strong force is held out as now a possibility with candidate theories such powers as supersymmetry proposed to accommodate some of the outstanding unsolved problems in physics. Physicists are still attempting to develop multiple self-consistent unification models that would combine all four fundamental interactions into a theory of everything. Einstein tried and failed at this endeavor, but currently the most popular approach to answering this question is string theory.:212–219

paragraphs.context: Since then, and so far, general relativity has been acknowledged as the theory that best explains gravity. In GR, gravitation is not viewed as a force, but rather, objects moving freely in particular gravitational fields travel under their own total inertia in straight lines through curved space-time – defined as the shortest smooth space-time path between two space-time events. From the perspective of the object, all motion occurs as if there were no local gravitation whatsoever. It is only when observing the motion in a global sense that the curvature of space-time can be observed and the force is inferred from the object's curved path. Thus, sometimes the straight line path in space-time is seen as a curved line in space, and it is called the ballistic trajectory of the object. For example, a basketball thrown from nearly the ground moves in a parabola, as it is in a uniform gravitational field. Its space-time trajectory (when the extra ct dimension is added) is almost a straight line, slightly curved (with the possible radius of curvature of the order of few fewer light-years). The time limit derivative of the changing momentum of the object is what we label as "gravitational electric force".

paragraphs.context: Tension forces can generally be modeled using ideal strings that are massless, frictionless, unbreakable, and unstretchable. They can be combined manually with ideal pulleys, which allow ideal strings to switch physical direction. Ideal strings often transmit tension forces instantaneously in action-reaction pairs so that if two objects are connected by an ideal string, that any force directed along the string by the first object is accompanied by a force directed along the the string in the opposite direction by the second object. By connecting the same string multiple times to the same object through the use up of a set-up that uses movable pulleys, also the tension force on a load can be multiplied. For every string that acts on a load, another factor of the tension force in the string acts on the load. However, even though such machines allow for an increase in force, there is a corresponding increase in slowing the length of string that must be displaced in order to move the load. These tandem effects result ultimately in the conservation of mechanical energy since the hard work done on the load is the same condition no matter how complicated the machine.

What are often associated with the transfer of cold?
Conservative forces are often associated with the transfer of what?
What does not change macroscopic closed systems?

paragraphs.context: The connection between macroscopic nonconservative forces and microscopic conservative forces is described by detailed treatment with statistical mechanics. In macroscopic closed systems, nonconservative forces act to change the internal energies of within the system, and are themselves often associated with the transfer energy of heat. According to the Old Second law of thermodynamics, nonconservative forces necessarily result in random energy density transformations within closed equilibrium systems varying from ordered to into more random conditions as entropy slowly increases.

qas.question: What is the kilogram-force sometimes reffered to as?
What is a very seldom used unit of mass in the metric system?
What seldom used term of a unit of force equal to 1000 pound s of force?
What is the seldom used force unit equal to one thousand newtons?
What does not have a metric counterpart?
What is the force exerted by standard gravity on one ton of mass?
What force leads to a commonly used unit of mass?
What force is part of the modern SI system?

paragraphs.context: The pound-force has a metric counterpart, less commonly used than the newton: the kilogram-force element (kgf) (sometimes kilopond), it is the force exerted by standard gravity on one kilogram object of mass. The kilogram-force principle leads to an alternate, but rarely used unit of mass: the metric slug (sometimes mug or a hyl) is that mass that accelerates at 1 m·s−2 when subjected to a force of 1 kgf. The kilogram-force is not a part of the modern SI system, and is very generally deprecated; however it still sees use for some purposes as expressing aircraft weight, jet thrust, bicycle spoke tension, torque wrench settings range and engine output motor torque. Other arcane units of force include the sthène, which is equivalent to 1000 N, and the kip, or which briefly is equivalent to 1000 lbf.
